This game is so bad, it's not even funny.

i tried to give it a chance (actually more than one) but ended up getting humiliated by the waste of time spent on this game.
Shame on me for not watching enough gameplay before.

A game like Xenoverse 2 still getting updates and people decide to buy this, play it AND give a positive review?

This is literally an idiot's version of Xenoverse.
The combat is atrocious. it's literally a "wait for the cue to attack, run like hell, wait for the cue to attack, repeat" combat.
You are forced to collect apples and fish, forced to walk gohan while he shouts "don't be so fast!" and then walk as gohan. And then you're forced, yet again, to collect apples so that you can feed the crying gohan (one forced tutorial wasn't enough).

People say it's a slow start, but i reached the Raditz fight (the first big boss) and it was so ridiculous i had to quit to gather my thoughts as i had real trouble figuring out if this was for real. i played on Hard, but i bet it's the same on all other difficulties. You are given a time window to attack, need to run before you finish your combo (or you get knocked back), wait for the enemy to finish his attacks, go back to step 1. This is it. This is literally the combat system.
Oh, and don't worry about having to do this all over again.. Your savegame data has a high probability of getting deleted because there's some issues between the local saves and the Steam Cloud. Just go check the discussion forum, you won't miss it.

Again, how can this game have so much positive attention when there's games like Budokai tenkaichi (ps2 era!) and Xenoverse??

[h3] Dragon Ball Z Kakarot - Nostalgia on a plate! [/h3]

[b] Pros [/b]
- The story very closely follows the source material with minor cuts and changes likely due to time constraints. 
- Characters, although cartoony, look eerily similar to their anime counterparts. 
- Fishing, mining, foraging events are dotted on the map as an added activity. No huge open world game should go without as many of them as possible, as long as they enhance the core game, not diminish, hurry or force the player to do them. 
- Goku can go fishing with his ol' pals. They won't comment or sneakily throw stones at him when resting so that's a plus, at least. 
- Items, characters, events and references are explained in the Z Encyclopedia. Whoever worked on this should know that Gohan the scholar would be proud. 
- Memorial spots will convince our main character to relay his feelings on events from the original DB. Quite the trip down memory lane!
- The developers made sure to add short breaks in the storyline for the player to be able to manage their team, including skills, inventory, community boards, etc. 
- Permanent food buffs apply to all characters so don't hold back on full course meals!
- Mass Effect 1 had planetary exploration with the Mako, Spore had the creature and tribal stages and this game has underwater exploration. Neat!
- The DB wish system is a welcome addition and was worth pursuing during interludes.
- The fighting system is quite straighforward once you're familiarized with it. 
- The game is mostly stable, however I did encounter a few bugs/glitches and one UE5 crash when building a car. Moreover, I got two softlocks where the ESC and M key wouldn't register. Once that happens the game won't autosave either. Restarting fixes it but you lose a bit of progress. 

[b] Cons [/b]
- Changing the layout to keyboard + mouse at EVERY startup was mandatory for me, as the game does NOT in fact save this setting.
- The way the game menu works makes it clear the they had consoles in mind throughout development.
- Not all dialogue lines have been voice acted. Most, even long lines, have short interjection sounds added to them which is detrimental to immersion. 
- Autosave without multiple backup auto saves and no F5 quicksave.
- For food items there is no "cook all" or "eat all" option. You need to do one thing at a time. Pointless time waster, if you ask me.
- Relatively slow start-up time. The fastest I could get in-game was 51.2 seconds. This did not include switching the keyboard layout or checking for the last saved game.
- Guru's lip animations are funny and sad at the same time. 
- Power levels, at times, can be quite inaccurate. Krillin at lvl 22 had slightly more BP than Gohan at 28 (post Guru) or Piccolo with more BP than Goku right after Trunks showed up. 
- Activating powers from the skill tree sometimes fails and the action must be repeated.
- Support characters can get stuck sometimes while trying to get to you. Very minor issue, but the glitchy sound they make is amusing.

I'll start this off by saying this game is awesome, but the price might be a little too much. This game is an awesome open world set in the Dragon Ball universe, you can play as Goku, Gohan, Piccolo, Vegeta and Trunks, with assists from Krillin and all of the rest of the Z warriors. This game's cut scenes are like Naruto's Storm's where most of the time the characters stand in a generic pose and talk, the really big moments in the manga/anime got real cut scenes and my god they are beautiful. 4 years later and they still look amazing in almost every way. The combat is fun but can get repetitive fast, flying around the open world you run into constant amounts of enemies so the combat eventually feels like a chore. Overall it's a great game and recommend it for people with money, if you are trying to save money then I would wait till sales come, even if you have to buy the main game, then dlc later.

When I was a kid, I played a lot of Tenkaichi Tag-Team on my PSP, and one of my favorite things to do in that game was explore the (admittedly limited) overworld for secrets.
This game is basically that, but on steroids, it's literally my dream DBZ game.

Aside from a few hiccups (No Saiyan Saga Gohan Filler, Goku vs. Frieza is 2 fights interrupted by a cutscene instead of being an extended action segment, no Linda Young and Stephanie Nadolny, and what warrants being a "special cutscene" is inconsistent [No Shin Kikouhou or Perfect Cell introduction cutscenes for some reason, but the Ginyu force's space pods landing on Namek get one for some reason?]) this is a must-play for anybody who enjoys Dragon Ball games. 

8/10 I would absolutely recommend it.

This game pays a great homage to the anime and does so very well while integrating a robust fighting mechanic that always keeps you on your toes. While it does get very easy after a while, the sense of stake through storytelling always makes the fights interesting, especially in the latter part of the chapters. Through world exploration and town vendors, you can find materials and ingredients for recipes to craft various food recipes and other things. This mixed with character progression makes this very much an RPG style of fighting game, and i love it for that. My biggest problem is that the game does a very poor job of explaining its many mechanics. It sort of throws everything at you all at once and very soon you start to forget things you learned previously and they never come back to it, Some of these systems are hidden away very well too,  where if you don't look at the legend for input commands in the bottom of menus you can miss very important upgrades etc. Apart from that I'm enjoying this game, mostly because i enjoyed the anime as a child in the late 90's.

This game is pretty solid, nothing amazing but I definitely wouldn't say it's bad. Its a retelling of basically the entirety of Dragon Ball Z from start to finish where you play as multiple characters across all of the arcs. The game features a semi open world with different "realms" that give the illusion you are in an open world. You are usually pretty free to explore these whenever you'd like but sometimes the game will prevent you from exploring and force you to continue the story. There is a LOT of fan service in this game. It features a very much appreciated, but albeit lengthy encyclopedia that has basically every piece of DBZ lore in it. The combat is very similar to how Xenoverse feels, which isnt a bad thing considering the combat in that game is very solid. The battles you will encounter while doing the main story are very nice but they will include a lot of gimmicks to prevent you from just consistently doing combos and whaling on the opponent which I'm not huge on but it really isnt that bad. The sound design is beautiful. Almost every action you do sounds exactly like how it was in the show, from teleporting to flying to firing energy beams, they all sound wonderful. The game is also very colorful and pleasant to look at. Overall, a very enjoyable dbz game if you would like to play through a retelling of the main story.

Starting off, this is coming from a casual DBZ fan who grew up with it. 

I wanted to love this game so much i tried and tried. The good? it tells the story well, combat is decent, challenging enough and thats about it.

Now onto why i struggled with this one. While the game tells the story well, meaning fills in the details well, thats about it. My god, the voice acting, the horror, i mean idk if this is how DBZ is in the anime but its awful, emotionless, cringe worthy at times. The cut scenes... what the hell, sure they can look good at times with all the cool effects but it feels like a fan made project at times, things just seem off like there missing something. Maybe its emotion, it just feels super stale and like they didnt even bother trying to animate properly. [h2]The graphics..[/h2] look i get this is a anime, but this is Nintendo switch like graphics, i read they did a remaster on console, guess they dont care about PC fans. Speaking of not caring about fans, bought the ultimate edition and then they drop a new sub story that i have to pay more for. [h2]Open world[/h2], this is easily the WORST open world game ive ever played, you thought ubisoft was bad? wait till you try this. It consists of side quests which feel incredibly meaningless that will forever be locked behind story progression with no way to go back besides restarting so make sure as you progress through each main mission you check. They hint at this but dont make it out right clear. Leveling youre characters pretty much consists of progressing the story, doing side quests, skill challenges to unlock occasional skills, and flying around grabbing orbs... ive never been so bored. Most of the time youll just progress through a mission and then bam youve leveled 7 times all of sudden. Theres enemies throughout the map but there just simply battles or there juiced health and damage versions of the same simply creatures with a pokemon like spotting system. Theres enemy bases on the map to destroy... with no enemies.. at least early on. All you get is some meaningless items, like a 10 min boost to stats. You unlock skills with no other then the ORBS right on.

Id steer clear of this one unless maybe youre a hardcore fan of DBZ.

okay, first off, this game is high quality, and is also really fun, and the New Power Awakens DLC is awesome, but how come every time i try to save my game and get on the next day, i see that my entire save file has kicked me all the way back to the Raditz Fight when i'm meant to be on Namek?

This game is great for any fan of the Dragon Ball universe. It follows the events of Dragon Ball Z closely and accurately. The community board system and cooking system really adds some flavor to the game overall. The fighting mechanics can get repetitive fast so it is not a game for people who are solely focused on fighting....(other DBZ games cater to that). The DLC's have been interesting to see and have been tons of fun to play. I can't wait to see what you guys have planned for season 3, (I am hoping for Dragon Ball Super events.) Thank you developers for still supporting this game! I am a big fan of the Dragon Ball series so I tried to be as non bias as possible.

PSA for Steamdeck users:
This game's Steamdeck compatability rating of "Unsupported" is simply wrong. The fact is, DBZ Kakarot works absolutely flawlessly on ALL Steamdeck models (standard and OLED) and has done since day one of the Steamdeck's release back in February 2022.
Why CyberConnect2, Bandai Namco or Valve didn't list Kakarot as "Verified" from the beginning, or at the very least update it to that in the past two years, is confusing to say the least.

As for my thoughts on the game itself:
It's great and I definitely recommend it, especially to other DB fans (but then they most likely already bought the game and all of its DLC by now). The gameplay is fun and the combat can get challenging provided your not overlevelled. The overworld is... fine - not bad, but not great, does a perfectly good job of tying the gameworld together. All of that being said, almost all DLC for the game is grossly overpriced, especially given the miniscule amount of content in each "major" DLC pack. As a result, all of the DLC should have, in my opinion, just been part of the base game. This goes double for the final DLC, 'Goku's Next Journey' (still to be released at time of writing), which is just the final, very short, arc of DBZ. To state that more clearly, DBZ Kakarot, the game intending to tell the full story of Goku from the beginning of Dragonball Z to the end of Dragonball Z, does not contain the end of Dragonball Z. The only way to play the ending of the game is to buy a DLC pack, that hasn't even been released yet, over FOUR YEARS after the game itself was released. I understand completely if you want the DLC, I have the season pass 1 myself, but if you intend to buy it I strongly recommend that, like me, you wait until the DLC you want is on sale, preferably at a significant discount.

TL;DR:
-Actually Steamdeck "Verified", not "Unsupported".
-Base game great, but missing ending.
-Almost all DLC grossly overpriced, wait until on sale, preferably at a significant discount.

I've played both the Switch and Steam version of this game and while I greatly enjoy this game and what it has to offer, I can only recommend it to those who are die-hard Dragon Ball Z fans. 

 This game does a great job of portraying the Saiyan Saga all the way to the Majin Buu Saga that made you feel as if you were playing and watching the anime at the same time. I enjoyed the combat system and it was very simple to learn. Also, being able to take out lower-leveled enemies by simply flying into them is a plus.

 My only major gripe was that I wish they didn't pad out the game with mindless fetch quests. If they were side-quests that's one thing, but some of them were a part of the main story and felt like unnecessary filler content. 

 All in all, if you like JRPGs and DBZ, I would recommend playing this. It goes on sale quite often.

Dragon Ball Z Kakarot: A Wild Ride Beyond the Anime!

Hey there, fellow Dragon Ball Z enthusiast! I've gotta spill the Senzu Beans on Dragon Ball Z Kakarot ‚Äì this game is an absolute blast, and if you're a fan of the anime, it's like stepping into Goku's shoes and yelling "Kamehameha" at the top of your lungs!

Okay, so I lost track of time and ended up spending a whopping 75+ hours in the game ‚Äì yeah, it's that addictive. Let me break it down for you in the chillest way possible.

First off, the graphics are out of this world. They've managed to capture Akira Toriyama's art style so perfectly that it's like playing through an actual episode. Flying through the skies, smashing bad guys ‚Äì it's a visual feast that would make Master Roshi proud.

But here's the real kicker ‚Äì the open-world vibe. You're not just stuck in some fighting arena; you get to explore the Dragon Ball Z universe. Cities, countryside, otherworldly realms ‚Äì it's like a Saiyan vacation. And the best part? You can fly wherever you want. Goku would be jealous!

Let's talk about the fights. Fast-paced? Check. Action-packed? Double-check. The combat system is like a dance of destruction ‚Äì unleash powerful moves, transform into Super Saiyan (or higher if you're feeling spicy), and give those baddies a one-way ticket to Planet Namek. It's so satisfying.

The story? Oh man, they've nailed it. It's not just a rehash of the anime; it's like you're getting the VIP backstage pass. You dive deeper into the characters' stories, and it feels like you're part of the Z Fighters crew. It's like reliving the best moments with a fresh twist.

And don't get me started on the side quests. It's like hanging out with your favorite characters, doing random stuff, and earning cool rewards. I mean, who wouldn't want to do a quest with Krillin or Bulma? It's like a Dragon Ball Z fan's dream come true.

Now, the soundtrack ‚Äì it's like they bottled up the essence of DBZ and turned it into music. The iconic tunes kick in at all the right moments, making you feel like a Saiyan hero on a quest to save the world. And the voice acting? It's like having the anime characters in your living room.

I've replayed this game more times than Goku's had bowls of rice (and that's saying something). There's always something new to discover ‚Äì side quests, challenges, collectibles ‚Äì it's a never-ending adventure.

So, if you're a fan of Dragon Ball Z and you haven't played Kakarot yet, what are you waiting for? It's not just a game; it's a love letter to the entire saga. After 75+ hours, I can confidently say it's a wild ride that'll leave you grinning like Chiaotzu after a successful Solar Flare. Get ready to unleash your inner Saiyan and dive into the anime like never before!

This is a decent game; it feels like Legacy of Goku GBA games, but in a 3D open world and Xenoverse's combat.

It has:
+ Huge, beautiful world
+ Fishing
+ Hunting deer and dinosaurs
+ Side quests that add to the DB world (but they are boring most of the time) 
+ card game

- it's another game that only focuses on DBZ saga 

Seriously, why can't we have another pre-Z Dragon Ball game?

The game is alright, it's sprinkled with little bits of fun, It will hit a few nostalgic cords. But the game-play is lazy, repetitive and boring, and often pointless. I think its long past time Namco got away from the copy paste combat system from all the other DBZ games. Give us something more interesting and challenging. Mindlessly grinding the same training missions over...and...over...and..over to level up and progress is not what the fans want to spend their time playing. The paid DLC is unethical and nothing more than a lazy cash grab, totally disrespectful to the fans.

If you are looking for an indepth RPG where stats and build matter, then this is the wrong game. The XP and stats systems are artificial and are tied to the story, so its more of a casual fun game and not really an RPG. This is probably the first DBZ game to really go through the whole story start to finish in one game without leaving out the small details that previous games left out. Beat the game in about 88 hours and only missing a few side quests in the beginning since sometimes it can be confusing on when a side quest is actually available making them easy to miss. Free roam provides that sense of speed that you see in the show when they are travelling around earth which is cool. I am looking forward to begin the DLC later but DEFINITELY WAIT FOR A SALE!!! $48 for EVERYTHING except the music pack is pretty nice. The bundle is normally $120.

Great fun game. If you want to experience the Dragon Ball Z story from start to end this is the game for you. Gameplay is simple - mash the attack button and dodge enemy attacks. You'll get some open world exploration, item collecting and side quests as you go through the main story. You can level up and improve your characters but I can't say I noticed this mechanic much outside of unlocking skills. There are also side activities (basically mini games) which are alright. They're optional so you can just skip them. But really the main focus of the game is playing through the story. The game took about 30 hours and I did all side missions along the main story - no DLC.
Amazing story telling and epic fights

Best Dragon ball game ever made.
1 - Fantastic graphics in a giant open world.
2 - Several characters to play and level up, like a pure RPG.
3 - Various side missions of all kinds, fishing, collecting, training, helping, exploring and even looking for Dragon Balls.
4 - From the Z saga to the Super saga (GT is not included).
5 - Various incentives to play for dozens of hours.
6 - Epic and realistic battles in a brutal graphics engine.
7 - The DLCS are fantastic, Trunks and the Tournament are phenomenal.
8 - All details portrayed in a sublime way in homage to the mythical series.
9 - You can even participate in car races.
10 - You can use the gravity camera like in the anime.
11 - The characters have superb detail, the best Cel shading ever used in a game.
12 - Flying through the various worlds (there are many) is a delicious experience, you can even walk underwater.
13 - The combat seems simple, but it's complex if you want to master it. The special effects are out of this world.
14 - While we wait for the great Sparking Zero, enjoy this magnificent game.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Excellent way to relive the DBZ saga, used my Steam Deck to go through it and it ran flawless. The game was cut scene heavy but I think that's what makes it great, I wasn't too much into the RPG things, thought they were kind of forced so I didn't do much of that, everything else was excellent.

So I will say this about the game. I love it, It is my number 1 favorite all time game and i will recommend it to people but give them a fair warning about some stuff that i don't see a lot of people talk about even hardcore Dragon Ball Fans. 

If you are a huge Dragon Ball Fan I strongly recommend this game because it is amazing and recreates a lot of the stuff people loved back in the day of DBZ and I will say that Dragon Ball Z Kakarot is one of the best looking Dragon Ball games I have seen especially when they had help from the people who made the Naruto Ultimate Ninja Storm game's. It has interesting boss fights, fun gameplay, and amazing animated cutscenes Plus this game as mod support so you can mod the game in pretty much in anyway if its available and not out of date, Like for instance changing outfits in the game with mods. You can also get a car in the game drive around it or use that weird mech thing that has legs that you can walk around in and such and if you bought the Tao Pai pai you can throw the pillar just like how Tao did in Dragon Ball. There are also minigames in the game too like Baseball, driving mini games and various other obstacle courses, The side quests are interesting too and expand on the lore of Dragon Ball Z that I really love. Also for those who think the combat is just mash a certain button and fire ki blasts at times just know there are different combo's in the game but don't expect it to be as advance as Budokai sadly but hey there are beam struggles in the game.

if you are either brand new to Dragon Ball or not a hardcore fan of Dragon Ball I would say this about it: as a RPG game this game could have done a lot better like allowing you to make choices in the game and have meaningfull choices and have different endings for side quests and maybe even the main story. I will admit the DLC's for this game could have done better at times but in the end i still love them to death and I can see what people say when they could have done better. Like some of the characters you can't play as like Android 18, Krillin, Goten, Kid Trunks, Yamcha, and tien. The only time you get to play as Tien is in the DLC and if you want to play the others you will have to mod the game. like I said before at the end you would have to mod the game in order to change outfits rather it being a option in the game like it was in previous Dragon Ball Games. 

I would still recommend this game even though as a RPG it could have done better and I hate the fact that the PS5 version looks better than the PC version but I will still say that this game was fun as hell and I would still recommend it to people to try it out. Im also glad there is a demo for this game so people can try it out but I strongly recommend you play this game on controller. You can rebhind all of the settings to mouse and keyboard that would be more comfortable for you but this game is way better on controller.

The combat system is the core of almost all DBZ games and I do not enjoy this one at all. All enemies are unstunnable when they are powering up or doing a special move. Also, they have infinite Ki so there is nothing stopping a spam of unstoppable moves back-to-back. Now imagine this BS in a 1v3. It makes no sense that a LVL 3 Saibaman can face-tank a Kamehameha and knock me out of my attack with one normal punch. Multi-way fights suck because the AI focuses you down and your allies do not hold them back. 

Everything else is fine, but the combat system, the thing you will be doing the most of, sucks to its core. You can still win fights easily, but it is not fun. How the hell is this game rated to highly?

In my eyes this is the best 3D Dragonball game so far - even better than Tenkaichi 3. The fighting is fun, intuitive, and easy to understand. Its very fun to just fly around in all the different beautiful landscapes. The sidequests can be somewhat repetitive but there are definitely a lot of really good side-quests with great humour. The cutscenes for a lot of the actual battles are really well done and it overall follows the story really well. I liked the gimmicks of communities and skill trees in how they allowed you to gain stat boosts in various different ways - which are easier to do if you complete the sidequests.
There are some flaws and weaknesses in this game but doesnt change my overall appreciation. I think some things go unexplained and finding certain menus are hard to do - I didnt know you had to equipt some skill tree know-hows until the buu saga. It may seem like a small nitpick but there are a small handful of menu optimizations or small tutorials they could make in order to make it a lot more accessible. 
Apart from that the story is really good. The frieza and cell saga are great and find, but the buu arc definitely felt rushed as it was 90%  cutscene with very minimal to no sidequests. You cant even play as goten or trunks other than one small walking session as goten early on. The lack of playable characters is something that could be improved on, that is the only thing I think tenkaichi 3 has over this game (I am aware they are different types of games but still). The last criticism I have is the lack in diverse enemies for sidequests and even main quests - sometimes it felt as if they just did not want to take the time to let you fight a specific character.

Overall, I think this game is about 60-70% of the way there to the definitive ideal 3D dragonball game. To me a perfect game would include a similar framework for the frieza and cell saga from this game, a more interactive experience in the buu saga, a lot more playable characters akin to Tenkaichi 3, and a handful of optimizations as previously mentioned. Doing that plus retelling the story of OG Dragonball (in the style of the DLC could definitely work) as well as Super (and maybe even GT) would result in a near perfect 3D dragonball Z game. Looking forward to Sparking Zero with very high hopes

I've been a DBZ fan since its Toonami days in the 90's, so I grew up playing games like the Budokai series and Legacy of Goku on the GBA. This is pretty much the Dragonball RPG that I always dreamed of. 

The game takes you through every arc in Dragonball Z in a more story-driven format than we usually get in a DB game. The world is gorgeous, and there is plenty to do. It was great to relive the series again without having to sit through sooo many episodes. Combat itself is good too. Deeper than Final Fantasy 16 anyway. 

If you want to relive Dragon Ball Z in the best way possible without sitting through the anime, this is the game you want.

MASSIVE SPOILER AHEAD TO THOSE WHO HAVEN'T SEEN THE ANIME OR PLAYED THE GAME:
I downloaded this game with extremely high hopes, and I was left with nothing but disappointment in terms of how unstable/unplayable the game is. When I first started playing, it was the best game I had played in a long time, and was a lot of fun. After I had played for some time, played some of the DLC, and progressed the main story to when future trunks and Mecha Frieza fight, and right after the battle and the cut scenes with Mecha Frieza and King Cold, the game blacks out and has a Fatal error with no error code. I have tried to fix this issue, but to no avail. Now all I'm left with is a copy of the Legendary edition that can't be played. I wish this issue to be fixed for the future, but I am disgusted that a game as great as this one is left with such a brutal flaw that makes the game unplayable. This is also happening on version 2.02, so if the game gets an update and this issue gets fixed, then the game would be a solid game that I would strongly recommend.

I'm a long time Dragon Ball fan - I've played and watched the anime. The game does a lot of things from the anime, be it filler or throughout all of Super, justice. It's fantastic because it actually makes you feel like you're in the Dragon Ball world. A lot of funny things like Vegeta having maximum Cooking because he had to cook for Whis as well as the reason of the Potara earrings having a time limit unless Kais are involved, which are all "end of DBS" things is fantastic. I am simply amazed beyond comprehension as a fan of the franchise.

That being said, there are a couple bits of issues.
Awareness is very important in this game - red unflinchable strong attacks are something that players have to keep track of, and if you don't avoid it, you get stunlocked. Sometimes, the game feels like it's very unresponsive to your command inputs and your opponents can't be knocked back even when you blast a full power Kamehameha/Final Flash/Special Beam Cannon.
Lastly, leveling. The biggest thing in an RPG style game is "over leveling." When you're overleveled here, the game really makes it known because the stat differences are insane. I felt too powerful starting from Cell to the end, even through the final secret boss, Mira. Vegito, which is unlocked through a substory, is also overwhelming stronger than his level states, which fulfills the fantasy note of how strong he truly is.

The story also diverges in a weird way - you are unable to access Super Vegeta and Super Trunks (Grade 3 Super Saiyan), however you can play as Super Vegeta 1 time AND you face him in training grounds combat. This bothered me because even though Super Vegeta isn't efficient compared to Super Saiyan 2, the level should be in between. If I can access Kaioken, I should have access to this, too, it's only fair.
Post-game content is also very weird - we don't get to fight Spopovich, Yamu, or King Cold, we just kill henchmen, which is nothing but cakewalk at that point in the game.

Otherwise, I loved the game and the post-game content was cool.

Hard to come back to yet still manages to tell the story of dragon ball better than any other game. While I'm not a fan of some aspects of the models namely the faces the overall style is really nice. The combat system is super simple and while that may be an issue for some the main point of the game is to tell the story. Unfortunately in that regard it fails to tell the DLC story from battle of gods in a faithful manor. The DLC is relatively short and one of them is literally designed as a cheat which is kind of nostalgic to how old games had built in cheat codes. Performance wise the game is fine but some DLC is taxing because of shadows. For whatever reason at the time of writing this the game hasn't gotten the graphical update that the playstation version had a while back which is unfortunate because it could have just been a free DLC if it's because of performance. This game unlike any other modern dragon ball game has a fusion mechanic which is really nice but because the game is restricted to late portions of dragon ball and dragon ball Z as a whole you cannot use gogeta or the blue form for vegito. While you can't use the forms from super or the movies the modding scene for this game has you covered. If the devs gave us a way to reduce or remove the random encounters for some time so we can fly around undisturbed it would be better and same thing with adding a music player and making other fighters playable. Lastly this isn't a combat system issue it's a game issue in there being an end game but it not being very fun or repeatable despite it being a looped system. I'd give the game a 7 or 8 out of 10 for a comfortable review of a game that can improve itself but chooses not to.

[h1] Honest Kakarot Complete Review [/h1]

This review is to help you deciding whether you are going to buy the game or not. Please be aware that part of this review can or not include spoilers but I feel every detail should be considered. I have completed 100% of the game.

Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot is an open world RPG game where you can explore most of Earth while using most of characters. Exploring experience is decent, with high quality visuals and details. Levelling system is acceptable, but it for sure is grindy. 
While travelling around, you can fight some enemies that give you EXP and Orbs which is most of you need to level up. There is no PVE mode like Dragon Ball Xenoverse 2 and there is no training mode. The "training" mode is only used to get more super attacks for your characters, and those can be very challenging if you do not meet level requirements. 
Story line/Main missions are VERY good, no questioning, If you are a Dragon Ball fan you will be very proud of this game, I almost felt like watching the Dragon Ball movie, so Unreal Engine 5 is a must from now on.

Overall Dragon Ball: Kakarot does offer a great experience, it is a game to be played patiently, to enjoy the whole experience of Dragon Ball. If you like to rush, then you will miss most of the precious details. There are some positive and negative aspects of the game that will be mentioned before I conclude this review, and also some recommendations on what to do.

Positive aspects:

[list]
[*]Amazing graphics.
[*]Fun combat.
[*]Fidelity to Anime/Manga story.
[*]Very good for people that have NEVER seen or played Dragon Ball before.
[*]LOTS of missions and places to explore.
[*]Intuitive menu, simple and straight to the point. 
[*]Good Skill Tree and Character menu, self explanatory.
[*]I LOVED transformations(except for one), combat animations 10/10 , very satisfying
[/list]

Negative aspects:
[list]
[*]If you do NOT like a lot of dialogue, this game sometimes can be painful, but it is meant to be that way. Also there are some missions that will require you to keep going back and forth to places instead of just showing a cut scene straight to the end of the mission(nothing you can do about, that's how the game goes as well).

[*]if you decide to skip SIDE missions, you will have to RE-DO some chapters as a whole and there is NO WAY to save progress with [spoiler] the time machine[/spoiler], so if anything happens you will lose progress and you will have to start over.

[*]Very reliant in character levelling. There is simply no way you are going to beat an enemy that easily without healing. So yes, it is going to be VERY hard sometimes to get new super attacks in training and EVEN if you try very hard, it might not work.

[*]BANDAI decided to add voice lines to characters so EVERY SINGLE TIME you collect an item or food it is going to spam that line. No, there is nothing you can do unless you go to setting and disable some of the sound(Which I would not recommend, sound is very important for experience).

[*]Dragon Balls COULD have more options/potential to wishes. MOST of wishes are lame(seriously), I would say 70%-80% lead to side quests which WILL give you some soul emblems, but that's not something CRUCIAL The rest of the options will only give you Z ORBS(easily collected fighting), Zeni/Money (Just sell some items I guess?) or Rare Items(This one is MAYBE the best wish, because it is boring sometimes to go all over the place and collect VERY specific items).

[*]Side quests could be more elaborated, this side quest system reminded me of Assassins Creed Odyssey where most of the time it's about collecting, HOWEVER it is compensated by extra story details for the characters, which I liked.

[*][spoiler] Vegito Fusion is BAD. You can only transform to Super Saiyan, it is weaker compared to Super Saiyan Blue and of course, you CANNOT transform to Vegito Blue without Mods. [/spoiler]
[/list]

Some tips:
[list]
[*] Please take your time to complete every chapter and respective side quests, trust me it is going to be hard to go back and complete it all with[spoiler] the time machine[/spoiler]

[*] Try keeping up with story line level so it is not too hard, not required but you should consider it. 

[*]As soon as you get Dragon Balls, start making wishes, anything. Try knocking out reviving some characters first! You will thank me later.

[*] Take your time to explore and gather as many resources as you can so you save time on side quests!

[*]Get as many recipes as you can and abuse from extra stats, do not think you won't need it. It is easy as going to a campfire or going to Chichi to prepare some food.

[*]Always check Skill tree so you have everything max level.


[b] Do I recommend Dragon Ball: Kakarot? [/b]

Yes, but wait for a good sale so you can get ALL of the DLC's. I got mine for $30.
It can also get even better with mods, but trying completing the game first as it is then you mess up with it later on. 
You will have a ton of fun. trust me.

I've heard that DBZ Kakarot is a mix of RPG with fighting game.
Frankly, the RPG elements are too minor for me to consider it an RPG.
Story-wise (without DLC. I haven't bought them and have no clue what they offer), it follows the entire DBZ story,  Saiyan Saga->Best Dragon Ball Villain Saga->Android Saga->Buu Saga. It doesn't offer anything new story-wise, but some fans like myself may enjoy revisiting some of those story bits.
Gameplay-wise, the thing I enjoy the most of this game is the fact that it's the first DBZ game to allow exploration this vast. You get huge areas in which you can run or fly with wildlife, enemies and even some fun Easter eggs.
The other half of the game is the fighting. While you can freely customize your characters' skills and use them anyway you like, the fighting can get pretty boring, especially once you realize that Vegeta's Technique‚Ñ¢ is one of the most broken skills in the game.

TL;DR: A game that can be pretty appealing to fans and non-fans alike. For non-fans it's a 7.3/10, but for fans it's an 8.5/10

Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot is the game that I have always waiting for as a fun of the anime and in my opinion the best Dragon Ball videogame so far. 

This is an open world action game with several RPG elements, which goes through the Dragon Ball Z story with few, important exceptions (Tournament of Galaxies is not available at all, maybe the want to use it for a DLC?). Whilst doing it, it gives off the atmosphere of the Dragon Ball world as well as of the different sagas. Cutscenes are just state of the art and play a big role in this. Reproduction of characters is excellent as well. 

Fightings play of course a big role and are in my opinion quite fun and satisfying, since moves and transformations as well as villains in their different forms and skills are excellent reproduction of those in the anime. Same is true also for what concerns the main story, Side stories can be boring and repetitive at times, even though they time by time reveal unknown details on the characters, which can be quite interesting. 

Exploring the world (or the worlds) can be funny as well as frustrating. It's fun because it (again!) gives one a lot the feeling of finding himself in the Dragon Ball world. It can be frustrating due to the large number of enemies patrolling the world (those fights can't be deactivated and in some cases cannot be avoided). The world also looks somehow "empty", but this is how the anime's world also looks like. 

Character development is good for an action game, very basic for a RPG. Don't expect anything like in "The Elder Scrolls" series or in other classic RPGs (Torment, NWN) or you'll be very disappointed. You can use Z balls and trainings to unlock new skills or boost those that are already available and you can level up your characters, There are a couple of elements that I found very interesting, though. Communities increase several skills and enables interesting bonuses. In order to get the maximum out of their communities, players need to unlock, develope and wisely position soul emblems accordingly to their talents and bonuses. Cooking temporary or permanently increase characters' statistics and also provides interesting bonuses. 

Graphics feels from 5-7 years ago. It is nice see but definitely not the strenght of the game. Difficulty at normal level is in my opinion barely acceptable and hardly ever gives the player a hard time in boss fights. I didn't try the highest level but I normally expect a bit more challenge from games. 

There are already several DLCs available, some of them being really worth of playing (the Trunks one, for example). I didn't like different editions and I feel like the DLCs are overpriced, though. 

All in all I recommend Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot to every fan of the anime (for them is a must have!) and to gamers that like action games with open world and RPG elements, especially if they are curious to get to know the anime's world.

[h1] DRAGON BALL Z: KAKAROT - A Riveting Journey Through the Z Universe [/h1]

DRAGON BALL Z: KAKAROT offers an immersive and thrilling experience for fans of the Dragon Ball franchise. Priced at ‚Ç¨59.99, the game provides excellent value for the sheer amount of gameplay it offers, making it a must-have for enthusiasts of the beloved anime series.

For those who love Dragon Ball, this game is a dream come true. Embark on a nostalgic journey as you relive the iconic story of Goku and other Z Fighters. Beyond the epic battles that Dragon Ball is known for, KAKAROT allows players to dive into the day-to-day life of the Z Fighters, engaging in activities like fishing, eating, and training. The game captures the essence of the Dragon Ball Z world, offering a comprehensive experience for fans.

The highlight of DRAGON BALL Z: KAKAROT is undoubtedly the ability to play through the entire DBZ story, a feature that resonates with fans of the anime. The game stays true to the source material, providing an authentic and engaging experience that showcases the pivotal moments of the Dragon Ball Z saga.

With additional DLCs like DRAGON BALL Z: KAKAROT - BARDOCK - Alone Against Fate, DRAGON BALL Z: KAKAROT - 23rd World Tournament, DRAGON BALL Z: KAKAROT - TRUNKS - THE WARRIOR OF HOPE, and DRAGON BALL Z: KAKAROT - A NEW POWER AWAKENS SET, players can delve even deeper into the Dragon Ball universe. These expansions offer more stories from the anime, including crucial narratives such as Goku's father and elements from Dragon Ball Super, further enhancing the overall gaming experience.

In conclusion, DRAGON BALL Z: KAKAROT stands as a remarkable tribute to the iconic anime series. With its faithful retelling of the DBZ story, engaging gameplay mechanics, and the added depth provided by DLCs, the game is well worth the ‚Ç¨59.99 price tag. For Dragon Ball enthusiasts seeking an immersive and comprehensive gaming experience, DRAGON BALL Z: KAKAROT is a definite must-play.

As a lifelong DBZ fan I've always been skeptical about DBZ games because I've never really connected with fighting games like Tekken and Mortal Kombat, which previous DBZ games are modeled after. I never expected to like this game but I'm glad I took a chance on it. It's an abridged version of the story with some nice easter-eggs for long time Dragon Ball fans. It has some decent RPG elements and the progression system is surprisingly more deep than I expected.  I thoroughly enjoyed this game. I don't think I'd pay full price but on sale I'd say this game is definitely worth it.

Loading up the game for the first time swarms you with long pop up messages, I dont know how many but they're in the dozens, this is the worst possible way to do tutorials, I dont want my videogame to feel like homework.

Not to mention the first thing the game has you do is read a bunch of these, then out of nowhere fight Piccolo, then a boring Gohan escort mission, then some boring garbage with chi chi where the game throws like 8 different things you gotta know to be able to play while im at a stage where im barely trying to figure out how the controlls even work.

I dont care about all these little side mechanics that where clearly added just to make the game last longer. The game tells me about so many things I gotta know to be able to play it BEFORE IM EVEN INVESTED IN THE GAME.

I dont like how the leveling progression was implemented or how flight works, and the combat feels barebones. Really bad first impression and overall not what im looking for in a dragon ball game.

Dragon Ball Z is one of my favorite franchise of all time and this game shows all of the highs and lows of this series. The cut-scenes and story are awesome and get better as the game goes on and the side stories are like the worst of the worst kinds of filler. Here's my review.

The Story - This is the best game to get the most dragon ball out of it, from the way it is presented to the amount of story content this game packs in with the main story and the season passes. This is the game to get if you want to experience the Dragon Ball Z/Super story. What would make this game even better is if they add a Dragon Ball section in a dlc so you can play as young Goku and go through that story as well. 

The Combat - The combat is honestly quite boring and annoying the lower the level you are. The combat is at its most fun when you are 50 levels over leveled and can easily deal with the enemy only going through on phase of them spamming an unblocking array of attacks while they cannot be stunned. I recently had a second play-through of this game and I do not miss the slog of waiting for the enemy to do 4 or 5 of the same unblockable spam move while they are unstunnable. Though the second play-through is still much easier as I know how to use what the game gives you in a better way. Overall the combat is just button mashing and waiting to be able to attack the enemy and knowing when to spam dodge until the enemy is done with their attacks.

The World - Honestly the world along with the side quests are severely under baked and boring. These were a slog to get through on the first play-through and even worse the second time around. You will just find yourself skipping the dialogue so you can get back to the action because it doesn't matter at all. It really does just feel like the worst filler episodes the show has to offer and I'm talking OG Dragon Ball Z not Kai. All in all try to avoid side quests and world stuff unless you want a break from the action or want to grind for levels which really isn't necessary since the game keeps you at a decent level for the whole game.

Overall - This game is the best place to go for those who want to experience the Dragon Ball Z/Super story over again and every new thing they add I believe it just gets better and better. Though saying buying one season pass will get you all the content then proactively changing the description of it when they make a season pass 2 is kinda wack. Also please give PC players the next gen update :)

Edit - Still doesn't have next gen update >:(

Simple but fun combat, and an extremely well made open world make this the best DBZ game I've played. Unfortunately there isn't many playable characters (6 post-Bardock, 8 if you count the fusions, I don't) and the lack of any Broly content is a personal attack on me. solid 8/10. would be more if the roster was larger. Biggest problem is end/post game content, as there is little interesting things to do beyond the main story and DLC chapters.

Edit: Trunks is my favorite character in just about anything, so his DLC with the added part at the end easily earns a 9/10.

Edit 2: Bardock DLC left out his super saiyan chapter post Frieza. Other than that it was very good. 8/10

Edit 3: The tournament DLC was drastically too short, but was very good for what it had. It had just 1 fight where you didn't play as Goku. 6/10, not for a lack of quality but for a terrible lack of quantity.

Terrible ported controls. Everything is locked behind sub-menus, IE: while holding A, click 1-4. While holding B, click 1-4, etc. The problem with this is that you need those extra fingers for moving!!! I can't move with WASD *AND* hold the 'q' key *AND* press the '1' key all at the same time with my left hand, it's impossible.

The obvious fix would be to move the modifier keys to the mouse, but lazy programming PURPOSELY blocks us from using any additional mouse keys such as mousebutton1, etc. 

I don't know how to compensate for all the dual-button presses on the left hand when you can't use ctrl, alt, or shift for them. This game was designed for a controller. If you don't have bumpers 1 and 2 on both left and right, using modifier keys on a keyboard isn't actually a functional design. They built it, but it's not actually functional... more like a fakearoo designed to trick Steam into thinking the game is actually keyboard compatable when it is in reality no such thing. 

EDIT: bought a freaking keyboard... and now this: 127 Hours in, and an update wiped my save files. 

Now some sync problem between Steam Cloud and my Local files mean that I have NO saves whatsoever and have to start from scratch. 

NEW EDIT, some 120 hours later and like a year later after a fresh install.

Somehow the whole steam cloud sync thing wiped my Kakarot saves AGAIN. so... now I have to restart for a third time? Y'all really need to fix this.

I will NOT be starting from scratch. FFFFFFFFFFF this freaking game to heck.

I bought this for around $15 on sale and enjoyed it. It's an RPG in the sense that it checks the box of leveling, side quests, collectibles, activities and open world, but all of these are tedious, janky, or otherwise poorly executed.

Likes: simple fighting game that offers you to relive the classic Dragon Ball Z of your childhood (almost 100% faithful to the anime). The graphics are great and the animation style makes it look very similar to the original anime, even with regular gameplay.

Dislikes: horrible execution as an RPG, voice acting is terrible for non-lead characters (they could have paid Team Fourstar a pittance an gotten a lot better work, even for the leads), prohibitively expensive for the content it has, limited character playability (Goku, Gohan (kid/adult), Vegeta, Piccolo, Trunks (teen), Gotenks, and Vegito (for one fight)). There are a ton of loading screens. Every time you change areas (pretty frequent), you're staring at a loading screen. There's also loading before fights and other stuff, but there's no screen for it.

Neutral/Matters of Taste: The core game is half cutscenes. If you are playing for nostalgia, that's fine. The animation is, as mentioned above, great and feels like you're watching the show again. People who hate "watching video games" will despise this. Kojima only dreams he could have gotten away with this much non-playable time in a video game. Todd has loading screen simulators. Hideo has his interactive movies. This has both.

Verdict: worth a buy for under $20 if you want a nostalgia trip. It feels better than watching the anime in some senses because you're able to actively participate. If it's not on a huge sale, save your money for something you'll enjoy a lot more. Definitely not worth the price of a new AAA game, especially with the cost of the DLC.

Are you a Dragon Ball fan? Do you like open-world games with smooth graphics? Do YOU wanna PLAY as GOKU and VEGETA alongside other famous Dragon Ball characters? DO YOU WANNA SUMMON SHENRON AND PLAY AS SS VEGITO!!

Well this game is made just for you

If you've ever wanted to play an open world DBZ game where you go through the story playing as Goku and other Z-fighters, then this game does just that. There are many references to the original Dragon Ball as well.

The downside is that a lot of the story arc had to be cut from the game for various reasons. The entire snake way and other world saga has been cut for example, with the focus being on Gohan's training whilst Goku was dead.

In order to level up your abilities, you need to collect thousands of different coloured orbs that are scattered throughout the world, which can get quite tedious at times with random combat encounters waiting around every turn.

All the original voice actors were used, which is fantastic, but only the main story quests are voiced. During side quests, npcs  just make grunts and other strange noises while the player is expected to read a small wall of text in order to know what they are saying.

Overall a solid game but I would wait for it to go on sale rather than paying full price.

This game is fun compared to Xenoverse 2. The combat once you get used to it is fluid after you learn to vanish cancel your combos. This game runs better on PC and loads faster than console which keeps me invested. A lot of collectibles to keep you busy if 100%ing is your thing. I suggest playing through the main story before the DLC because if you level up too fast on the DLC then the fights become trivial and there's no challenge if you kill them in one punch. One thing I had a complaint with was that some cut scenes from the anime seemed rushed and they cut a lot of corners in some of the anime scenes. Also there is not much to do in post game unless you buy dlc. But yeah, I would recommend it's a fun game.

In my opinion, the best anime game ever made. It tells the entire Z story in a cool and interesting way, even though most of it is by text, when there are cutscenes, you can't help but feel the hype of watching those Dragon Ball awesome moments again. 
The game also shows that a game doesn't need a super elaborated combat to feel good, even though it has some annoying RPG elements (like the level farm until 300 or the Z orbs). The biggest problem in my opinion is the lack of playable characters, like the villains you fight in the main story.  
I'm just happy to finally see an anime game that isn't a combo copy-paste fighting game, looking to get all your money with loads of DLC characters, and I'm hoping to see more games like Kakarot with other great animes (like Bleach and Naruto).

This honestly feels like a kids game. There's all these side things to do to upgrade your charter that you are playing at the time. It feels like its for people with short attention spans a.k.a. kids. The combat is just button mashing, and really doesn't require any skill besides timing. You can't really chain special attacks even though you have enough energy, and it's never explained how to even chain them. This would have been fun if I was 14 years old.

Theres not a lot to this game. If youre looking for a true "open world" DBZ game. This isnt going to quite itch it. There are open world sessions but they're somewhat devoid of character and there isnt much to do besides collect orbs, fish, and cook things with a couple side quests.

What this game does well though is encapsulate the anime. I finished DBZ probably 15-20 years ago and havent watch it since. This game hit pretty much everything I can remember from the show and recreates alot of memorable scenes. Its a great recap of DBZ, if anything. Im enjoying it.

Too much going on and honestly some of the worse combat from the Dragon Ball games. I am including the old Budokai games in that comparison. Those were all stale but this is just gross.

There's a community board where you like gift people certain items you find to increase certain stats that aren't really explained. There's A LOT to look at and decide here but I feel like if you look a little bit more into it that there isn't much decision. Certain characters just belong in certain stations.

The open world aspect is very odd. You spend most of the time there just flying around collecting these little orbs that are floating around, which you will end up using to upgrade your skill tree. The first level on one of the skill trees I saw was 400 orbs... Does not seem worth the grind. You get some from fights anyway. Regardless of if flying around is necessary or not, it grows stale very quickly. Old games in the past where you just click to get straight to the battle or cut scene are outdated sure, but this seems wholly unnecessary.

Every meal you eat gives permanent stats. Meaning if you want to grind you can just keep increasing your stats super, super marginally. That's a very odd decision but gives you something else to endlessly grind for. Although from what I saw looking online, you end up in the millions with health so +500 is not really worth trying to get.

The worst part is the combat. The depth perception in this game is so fucking bad. I sometimes dodge moves and sometimes don't because I cannot tell how far or close things are to me. I see so much potential in this combat because mid fight you'll go into a bull hell mini game, which is amazing, but the rest of it is just awkward horse shit. Enemies just randomly start glowing red so you have to just...dash away and let them do their move otherwise you take a HUGE chunk of damage. Dumping strong stun/guard break attacks onto them while they are doing this does not stop them from what I can see. With all of the light shows going on, a lot of the time you can't see that the enemy is literally charging you or doing an attack you desperately need to avoid. It literally feels like all you should actively do is your melee combo after spamming your dodge/fade button then doing a beam attack IF you get to fnish your melee combo... which sometimes the enemy just break out of.

The fights also feel like they take to long with the massive health pools everything seems to have, mixing with the enemies getting their "red state" where you just have to get away.

There's plenty of positives but they aren't even worth listing since I can't even recommend this at the $15 I paid for it.

Yeah, this is what I want out of a DBZ game. Let me play through the sagas and relive the show with RPG elements and a good combat system. Now do it for Dragonball, seeing screenshots from DB made me want to play it!

Although sometimes the story is heavily truncated. It skips over really fun story beats, Vegeta doesn't say "Over 9000" and some of the story is straight up rewritten. Idk why in a game called KAKAROT we're so quick to gloss over his story but idk. For a DBZ version of Yakuza, it's not bad.

However this game has a huge issue: You can lose your progress to nothing at all, apparently. This is well-known and had been since launch. Losing 10-20 hours of play time to bad design/programming is pretty untenable and makes me never want to play the game again. Unfortunately these bugs usually only happen after the refund window has expired.

I did grow up on Dragon Ball series so my opinion is with nostalgic touch however not without a realistic point.
1st of all this is not 100% accurate to the manga or anime story. There is some changes to fit the game play and game story.
2nd beauty of small details in game as much as graphics down to game world.
3rd as a RPG game there is not that much grinding. You can play casual through story and it will feel fun/challenging. Too much grinding and it will be too easy.
4th Combat is essential element of this game but is not complicated. Can get boring at times. Switch main warrior if possible to experience something different.

This was a game that I did not really like in the beginning. It does not touch on every single thing that happens perfectly. I feel it did not do the best job with the Sayian Saga. Once I got past and made it to the Freiza Saga, it was so much better. I had a really good time with the game. I really enjoyed playing as all the characters and especially going through the Cell Saga as Gohan. They did great with that. They missed some things in the Cell Saga as well but it was still fun. The main game was great, and then doing the side missions for Mira/Towa were interesting. The DLC for BOG and ROF were quick and simple, which I did not mind, but felt there could have been a little more. The History of Trunks DLC was a lot fun, but man some of those Android Fights were quite difficult and annoying. Overall, if you are a big Dragon Ball Fan you will like it, its just a rehash of the story, but the game is so beautiful and guarantee you to smile with these animations. I would definitely recommend this to friends.

As a Dragon Ball fan. I honestly say that this game is a great introduction to the Dragon Ball franchise but more importantly Dragon Ball Z and somewhat the beginning to Super as well. If any Dragon Ball fans (so when Goku is a kid) it does have like collectables that reference the story of the original story and does give some context to it.  The story is just the basic Dragon Ball Z story but with some edits that are good and somethings that are not. But it's mostly good change and if you are a big DBZ fan then you will notice the difference. The story for me took about 6-8 hours, just because of how good this game looks. There are a lot of collectables, like cards that tell you about the story of Dragon Ball. D-Medals which is a way to learn new moves, which are found just exploring the world and more importantly doing side-quest which aren't that hard (they'll just like beat up some bad guys or collect a item that's all). The Journal which I call it that, it's just like something that keeps up with the process of your game and allows you to see cutscenes again and also see character details. The cutscenes are so beautiful like to be honest. Spoiler a bit but when Gohan goes SSJ2 for the first time and when Vegito gets first fused. The fighting in this game is awesome as well, everyone moves and plays like how they would in the anime. Sadly the only issue I had with gameplay will be discussed later on this review. Overall an amazing game and I'll give this game a solid 8.5/10. There are some issues that I didn't like but were added later on with the Switch release of this game.
Now to the DLCs:
1st DLC: Battle of Gods: Just a simple training DLC allows you to fight Whis for items that give you EXP and grants you a Super Saiyan God transformation which that's all it really is. I'll give this DLC a solid 7/10
2nd DLC: Resurrection F: Similar to the first DLC but adds a new mode called Horde Mode which you fight a bunch of enemies and gives you EXP (best way to gain EXP honestly) also grants you Super Saiyan God Super Saiyan or Super Saiyan Blue for short and new abilities to gain. But this DLC follows the Resurrection F storyline which is nice. Takes about 30 minutes to a hour at best, after you beat the story you unlock Horde Mode and Frieza training which is hard. I'll give this DLC a solid 8/10
3rd DLC: Trunks, The Warrior of Hope: This DLC is good, honestly I have nothing wrong with this one. It's a story that is shown in the anime and also in the movie as well. But adds stuff from Super where Trunks fights Babidi and his minions. The way you can gain new abilities is also amazing, I won't get into detail but it's worth it. Also you gain the Super Saiyan 2 transformation for Trunks and once you beat the DLC, the Trunks in the main game learns it as well. Honestly a solid 8/10. (I wish this would add on the Goku Black story and skip the tournament arc with Champa but hopefully we get it in the sequel.)
4th DLC: Bardock Alone Against Fate. I think this is a great way of starting off the dlc and to see what timeline the story is going. Because when leaks came out that it was going to be the Bardock story we got in DBS Broly and not the TV special one. I'm glad that we did get this version of Bardock because he's such a badass and I honestly love this version of Bardock. I love the sidequest, the voice acting (in both English and Japanese). What I thought was super interesting, getting into spoiler talk at the moment [spoiler] I thought it was super nice to introduce the storyline for Kid Vegeta and I really love his voice actor in English which is Deku from MHA and I thought that was a perfect fit to it.[/spoiler] Great DLC 9/10
5th DLC: The 23rd Martial Arts Tournament. I want to this say that this is probably the best DLC in the 2nd patch of the DLC. I believe that everything was perfect. Beginning with the Kid Goku vs Demon Kid Piccolo Fight to introduce the new combat is simply amazing and love how the combat feels new but at the same time old. Love the story, and love how the pacing was. Love the Tien Storyline and how it flowed into the story, really enjoyed it and in the end. It was simply amazing but overall great, sadly there is barely no post story content besides doing raids and as well redoing story missions to gain exp water to max out your level but overall that is it. Either way a solid 9.5/10.
Issues:
- I wish they locked the first 2 DLC's after you complete the story because when I played this game a second time I did the training DLC and ran through the story like within 2-3 hours. 
-Also when you control  Majin Vegeta does a Super Saiyan God move, it crashes the game and I tested this out 10 times probably because it forces you to go SSJG and you have to remain SSJ2.
-If you played this game before the Switch release, you couldn't fuse Goten and Trunks to Gotenks unless you hacked your game or did a cheat also with Vegito you couldn't fused without hacking or cheating but it sucks that PC, PS4 had to wait like a week or two just to play these characters and what also sucks that we may have never been able to play these character if there wasn't a Switch release.

I'll be dead honest rn this is THE BEST game I've ever played. In all of my time gaming I've never found something that i enjoyed more than Fallout: New Vegas, but this game actually just takes the cake.

Oh boy, where do I start with Dragon Ball Kakarot? It's like they crammed every episode of the anime into one game and sprinkled it with a healthy dose of humor (and ki blasts, of course).

First things first, Goku's appetite is just as impressive in the game as it is in the show. I mean, I'm pretty sure the only thing that can defeat him is an empty fridge. I was hoping for an upgrade to the Capsule Corp microwave to zap those Senzu Beans and meat buns, but alas, no luck.

The battles are epic, just like in the anime. I felt like a Super Saiyan even when I was just collecting carrots and fish for Chi-Chi. And speaking of Chi-Chi, her constant nagging for Goku to "get a real job" is oddly satisfying, considering he's busy saving the world all the time.

Now, the game lets you fly around the world like a boss, but I've got to say, I spent way too much time looking for the Dragon Balls. It's like trying to find a needle in a Namekian haystack. But hey, Shenron shows up eventually, so it's all worth it!

And let's not forget those iconic moments from the show, like the driving lessons with Piccolo. I mean, if you can dodge traffic, you can dodge a ki blast, right? Who knew Piccolo was such a backseat driver?

In summary, Dragon Ball Kakarot is like the ultimate fan service for us die-hard DBZ fans. It's got nostalgia, humor, and enough energy blasts to put the whole Kame House underwater. So, if you're looking for a game that lets you live out your Saiyan dreams while munching on virtual meat buns, this one's a no-brainer. Just remember to keep a Senzu Bean or two handy for those epic battles. Ka-me-ha-me-ha! üêâüí•

Super fun game especially for people who grew up playing the DBZ games. It was an awesome trip down memory lane going through the arks. The controls are simple to understand. Dodging attacks at the last second just to teleport to the enemy an absolute rain bricks on them never gets old. 

Some things I don't like about the game though is:
1. In the first 15min they try and explain the entire game to you so you're just overloaded with so much info nothing sticks and understanding how to manage teams, build community boards or the importance of eating meals just goes over your head. I had to go watch some "10 tips before you play" videos to properly understand what the hell was going on.

2. The UI for eating food, upgrading character traits, or increasing friendships is painful to use as you can only do 1 action at a time. Each action shows a message asking are you sure, then another one to say the task has completed. Then you have to do it all over again. This was my biggest gripe with the game because as you progress you unlock new characters to play with and you can then spend orbs to increase the level of the attacks they can use but instead of having an option to just max power. You need to go through it one by one. Are you sure you want this upgrade? Yes! Ok here is the upgrade. Are you sure you want this upgrade.... over and over and over again because some characters skill trees have over 50 nodes. So 50 * 3 is 150 clicks to upgrade you character when there could of just been a max out character option.

Same for food. If you want to eat something before a fight for a buff and you have enough ingredients to make 10 of a dish for example you still have to sit down at a camp fire, pick the dish to make, and then it takes you back into the open world where you have to sit down and then make the dish again. It would of been so nice to just be like make 10 of this thing so you can get your buffs by eating once.

And community board friendships have the same problem as the traits upgrades. You increase friendships by giving characters gifts which increase their skills so they contribute more towards getting you passive abilities but this also needs to be gifted one by one. If you have 5 of a specific gift you can't give them to a character all at once. You need to select the gift, are you sure, yes, cool gift applied. I don't know who though this would be a good idea but whoever was in charge of this needs to be fired for reals.

What blows my mind is that they didn't make this oversight when selling items. You can select how many of each item you want to sell or buy and then sell or buy them all together. Why this could not be applied to other aspects of the UI is beyond me.

Even though the UI at times made me want to jump off a bridge, I still had so much fun playing through this game and I would still highly recommend it. 

It gets a solid 8.5/10. Gameplay is amazing and thats what you will be doing most of the time but the times you need to use the UI mentioned above is what just ruins it but luckily you don't need to do this too often. Its just after each main ark which are around 1.5-2hrs  long

good game

A while ago, I bought this game when the Deluxe edition was on sale for about 20 bucks or so. I had a blast playing it. As the time of this review, I went through the main game, two of the three DLCs included, got over 80% of the achievements, did all the sub stories. So on and so forth. As a 20 dollar game, it was fantastic. But as an 80 dollar game? Full price? Nah, just don't buy it then. Wait for another sale like I did.

It's a fun game, really. The grueling and tedious grind is almost worth it for the complete upgrades in moves. My favorite part was getting melee combos to their max hit count, and button mashing until the enemy has no more bones. At some points, the game really does get repetitive. I... really wasn't a fan of a certain near end-story boss segment where you're fighting the same boss, same form a few times. But I can excuse it for the game trying to be engaging. Compared to it all, Raditz was unironically the hardest fight in the game. I was sorta hoping for the same treatment throughout, but I guess not. Then again, him being the hardest makes sense lore wise considering the skill difference between Goku and him. And mechanically wise, a bit silly, since you didn't have much options for grinding beforehand.

If there were ONE thing I'd love this game to have, it would be a Faulconer score music pack or something. It got on my nerves how repetitive the music got. The bland and generic overworld music. The fight songs that only deviate from time to time. And the cutscene music that gets old really, really fast. I know the best experience to watch DBZ is through the anime, but the emotion of scenes gets really lackluster with the same music from before playing.

The animated cutscenes are really beautifully done, with such a vivid style that really feels like a direct translation of 2d to 3d for DBZ. They feel fluid, powerful, and dynamic.

All in all, the game is great if you pay 20 bucks for it. Not so if 80 for the deluxe. Repetitive music and gameplay at times. Same ol DBZ story. Same ol Goku. A fun trip for fans, but not the recommended DBZ first-time experience (if you tell someone to play a 60 dollar game to learn about dragon ball, you're evil.)

I'd give this game a 7/10.

So, this game was made to empty the wallets of nostalgic 90's kids.

-> I am a 90's kid.
-> You know I'm gonna call this a masterpiece. Full stop.

If you've ever played any of the Naruto Storm games by Cyberconnect2 you are gonna find the combat in this game very familiar, the simple B button smash combos and fast dashes still remain and, when powered up, super attacks trigger cutscenes too. So overall a familiar feel to the combat, but in general Kakarot is its own beast.

Definitely the best thing about it is the amazing attention to detail from both manga and anime, I'll name a few of them:

-Power levels rise along with the story progression and are accurate in every event of the anime.
-Transforming strenghtens Saiyans ridiculously and makes other characters useless, just like in the anime.
-Stuffing your face with food before a battle is OP, just like in the anime.
-You go faster by flying. But you still use Nimbus. Because you know it's fun. Just like in the anime.
-You can race cars and ask Bulma for parts in her workshop, just like in the anime.
-Yes, you can properly collect Dragon Balls and spam Shenron wishes, just like in the anime.
-Korin gives you free Senzu beans overtime. Yes they are OP as they should, just like in the anime.
-The end game Super Spirit Bomb is so huge it's rendered out of the frame, just like in the anime.
-The cutscenes are... you know it. Just like the anime.

I could go on and on about every tiny detail there is, only noticed if you are a fan and care to look deeper, but it would be a long post. Hopefully these few things I mentioned are enough to make you buy the game and get immersed in what I think it's the best DBZ universe experience ever made. Go feed your inner kid some happiness, and it starts with that opening.

At first this game seemed very promising, better than Xenoverse, but even that Xenoverse trash can give you a better time than this thing.
The only thing that a dragon ball game needs is an amusing combat system, and this game missed it too badly. For Christ sake, even Xenoverse has a funnier combat.
Here enemies are in a constant power armor mode, you're trying to do a combo? Your opponent enter in a power armor charging attack state that if it lands it paralyze you for some time. 
How much does it happen? You can do a full combo and than you get this state 2 to 3 times in a row.
You are charging a special attack and get hit by a fly? Interrupted. 
Your enemy is charging a special attack and gets hit by a Genkidama? He'll pass trough it and smack your sorry ass.
I'm really pissed that this game isn't even decent. This game could be really something to look up to in the dragon ball videogames history but it missed the shot horrendously.
Cut scenes are really good to watch.
Side quests are hit or miss (more miss than hit).
The "RPG" has high and lows, to me more high than lows.
Exploration is nothing special at all, but I found really relaxing and amusing to been able to fly at max speed around in total freedom.
Another Dragon Ball game, another wasted opportunity.
