Alright, my previous review was harsh, that was because I accidentally hit New Game and it overwrote my auto-save, which got me very mad and I lost about half of my progress (at the time) but honestly it was not too bad and I should have properly saved before complaining, any way I really do enjoy the game, graphics are immaculate, stays true to the DBZ story (DLC not so much but we will get there) and it is really fun fighting, I also love all of the fan service towards the original dragon ball watchers/readers, a few references to Carrot Master/Monster Carrot, Android 8 appearing for a few side quests, we even get to meet adult Suno, all of these things help build the world in such a fun way and make the experience that much more immersive, which is obviously a good thing to have

Now I have done a lot of grinding (If Goku, Vegeta and Gohan at Lvl.300 doesnt count as grinding then I have no clue what does) and I plan on getting that sweet 100% of the entire game, which will take a few dedicated months at least, but I remain determined, now this is where the DLC come in because they are great for grinding, DLC 1 gets everyone to lvl 200+ in a few hours no problem, DLC 2 is even better because if you replay it, the support characters will also level up, even if you do not choose them, there is also the new Horde Battles which are amazing for leveling up your characters, though I would prefer that they stay true to the movies or the arcs in Super but I digress

My only real complaints are that there are so many things hindering my 100%, the way they made certain loot based on location, community board is agonizingly slow to max out, the distance and abundance of all the 200+ D-medals, and the amount of useless tasks needed to max out the encyclopedia (I just don't like grinding, many of these may have been positives for those of you who are somehow more addicted to video games than I) , there is also the fact that the controls are pretty un-intuitive (Keep in mind that I'm a filthy Xenoverse player so I'm biased towards that format)

As a lifelong Dragon Ball fan, I must say that Dragon Ball Z Kakarot is nothing short of a heartwarming masterpiece that not only captures the essence of the beloved series but elevates it to a whole new level. From the moment I stepped into the world of Kakarot, I was enveloped in a cocoon of nostalgia, transported back to those cherished childhood days when the adventures of Goku and his friends were our constant refuge.

What truly sets Dragon Ball Z Kakarot apart is its unparalleled ability to be more than just another game. It's a sincere love letter to the entire Dragon Ball universe. The creators have poured their hearts into every moment, ensuring that even the tiniest easter egg resonates with fans on a deep, emotional level. 

The epic cinematics in Dragon Ball Z Kakarot are nothing short of breathtaking. From the earth-shattering battles to the poignant character interactions, every frame is crafted with utmost care and respect for the source material. The sheer scale of the battles is awe-inspiring, and witnessing the iconic moments from the series recreated in such a stunning way is nothing short of magical.

In conclusion, Dragon Ball Z Kakarot isn't just a game; it's a heartwarming, cozy, and nostalgic trip down memory lane. It's a labor of love that celebrates the legacy of the series, surpassing every other Dragon Ball game with its epic cinematics, genuine storytelling, and impeccable attention to detail. It's a true gift to the fans, reminding us of the magic that made us fall in love with Dragon Ball in the first place. Really hope Super gets this treatment.

Pros:

-The destruction on the ground from attacks could be better.

-Doesn't make sense that random protection robots can scale to characters as strong as Goku.
-It would be better if they added more parts from DBS, Goku Black saga and T.O.P.
Overall: 9/10

I can recommend the game only if you are an open minded person that doesn't mind some faults in the design of the game.

Having experienced this game as I have and watched the show up to the end of super I think I can give you a fair assessment of the quality of this game.

Whilst the attention to detail can be quite apparent I felt the game borders on the edge on what I consider "good enough to distract you" but lacks some quality control in some areas. I do enjoy the game tries to fill in the gaps of time between what the characters were doing beyond what the show presents us - that's actually a good quality I didn't expect to see and most of the game's is littered with what are called "memories" that are short bursts of information portraying the original dragon ball content to remind us of Goku's origins.

While an extra eye of detail can be commended unfortunately some of the time spent on that could have gone into improving the combat: often I felt the controls are stiff - using a keyboard just doesn't feel right due to how fast your need to use your fingers to be pull off combos. But that being said, most "combat" ends up with you holding down power, spamming the specials over and over and then repeating the same tired attack, charge use special combination because the ai doesn't know how to challenge the player besides exclaiming what they are about to do while a giant red laser warns players they're about to attack - the health in this game requires you to mundanely collect resources from the map to gain zeni: with the only alternative to use the dragonballs to give you money that isn't that great of a wish when you consider most quests grant you things that you can sell anyway.

I think the game lacks polish in what you can buy, how the upgrades should work and how the game should play out. If it was my design I would have removed the skill tree "abilities" to upgrade only after you had progressed - the selection of skills should have been limited to just the upgraded forms of the attacks and removed the inferior version as most ki costs are the same - redundancy is something programmers should be avoiding.

The combat needed more to it, I felt unchallenged, it felt too on rails and there were no exciting moments other than the occasional cool new move thrown in there the lackluster progression of combat holds this game back.

I do like how this game plays for the lore reasons, but I only wish the game played more like other combat titles which had more flexible controls, better "counters" and the AI would present you with a challenge that wasn't just "spam" health items and "spam" specials and win. The combat is otherwise too slow and clunky for me to even consider this fun. If you're playing this: have an open mind, don't go in with the concept of expecting good fighting, instead enjoy the plotlines - you'll find most of the content cannot really be enjoyed until you do most of the missions themselves: I find this is to purposely make players replay the game and go back to finish off the content they missed. Fortunately you have a time machine to do most of that later on.

To summarise:
- Combat could be better improved.
- Travel is slow and some mundane elements could be shortened to make the game seem less of a chore to get through.
- Maps are overly sized: most of it is just space with nothing in it: while I enjoy the exploration aspects, the lack of content in this aspect is very apparent.
- The Memories seem rather pointless as only hardcore fans of the show would understand the plot-points from the original Dragon ball episodes (not Z).
- The game shines in the story telling elements: but only because it has the content to refer to - so as much as I praise the story, most of this can just be attributed to the fact the game is just regurgitating the same story from the show. I get the impression they really wanted to make their own story in the game but couldn't due to having to stick to the plot from the show: if this was the case, maybe you could have just made the scenes of fighting the main villians short missions rather than make the game revolve around them.

-Most of this game could be summed up as: Have you seen the show? Oh well it's that, but longer and you have to recollect the dragon balls every time you want to fight people you already killed - to fill up your community board: wasn't all that work worth it though? (inner screaming) it's repetitive and the only direction it can go is telling you the plot of DBZ: I feel this game is better suited to those that haven't seen the show and even then I'd still would prefer they watch the series instead rather than have their impression be ruined by bad mechanics in a video game.

I do hope that the later DLC makes up for it's lame repetitive state - I don't plan on buying Goku's dad DLC as it's 15 quid for the opportunity to basically sit there and gawk at a lemming: why would I pay for that? I'm glad I just stuck to paying for the Season pass as I didn't realise just how bad the game felt until halfway through the content. The game feels like it's content has been stretched and not for the right reasons.

I'd advise anyone who is just looking at what content to get in terms of the DLC to stick with the first season pass - the second season pass only offers you promise of content that doesn't exist right now, which is not worth your purchase unless you are willing to wait.

For fans of the DBZ narrative without hours and hours of filler. This will be my second playthrough, as I played it upon its release and nabbed DLC on a sale. Great to play after work with a few adult beverages and turn your brain off.
very kool

This game may not have a complex battle system or a story that deviates from the classic Dragon Ball Z story in any significant ways, but this game is just FUN!! This is the exact Dragon Ball game I would imagine up when I was a kid. 

Travelling around the open world is great fun. You can fly with or without boosting, fly on Nimbus, drive a car or just run at a great speed. There are so many fun little details in the open world, like flying too close to water causing it to splash up, and being able to see explosive auras from strong opponents.

While the combat is extremely simple, it's great fun. A mix of the animation style and the great sound design makes each little punch feel like it has so much weight to it, and combining this with effects such as your Kamehameha getting bigger the more you level up really makes you feel stronger and stronger as you play through the game.

Speaking of the animation, this game looks INCREDIBLE! I'm constantly going back to watch some of the prettier cutscenes, because they're just animated so well.

Overall, don't go into this game expecting a complex set of systems to learn and master. This is just some good, simple fun!
If they expand this game to have Ultra Instinct and Ultra Ego I will donate $100 to starving African children.

Steam really needs a review system better than Thumbs Up and Thumbs Down.

It wouldn't be fair to give Dragon Ball Z: Kararot a Thumbs Down.  On Steam, reaching "Mixed" on overall user reviews tends to indicate a fairly bad game.

Dragon BallZ: Carrot isn't a bad game.  But it also doesn't seem exactly sure what it wants to be.  On one hand, we need to stop with generic fighting games that just tell the story of Dragon Ball Z over and over again.  How many time can we keep rehashing it?  The voice actors must be going bonkers.

But that's what DBZ: Kakacarrot Cake does change... A little bit.  Now it's a fighting game AND an open world JRPG with Gacha elements.  Which is a surprisingly welcome change of pace.  Its actually kind of fun to explore maps that are based from brief glimpses of backgrounds we see in the anime.  They feel stylistically spot on, while older DBZ titles seemed to phone it in a bit.

However, I'm also wondering why these elements need to exist at the same time.  I finished the Freiza saga before I realized I could upgrade super attacks with the Z orbs that are all over the map for you to collect.  But the thing is, you get hundreds of them in random encounters - which sort of renders the delicate trails of 1 at a time feeling kind of meaningless.  Then on top of that, the fights seemed fairly beatable without the upgrades anyway, making collecting them feel even less important.

In a similar vein is cooking.  Every game has to have cooking and fishing these days.  And while it is kind of relaxing and wholesome, the food effects only last 3 minutes, and the recipes worth using can take some doing to have all the ingredients.  Some of the buffs are permanent I guess, but the UI doesn't do favors on making that clear.  And the permanent bonuses seem a lot lesser than just leveling up.

Now the leveling system is something that's actually pretty cool, though I wish they leveraged it even more. In most DBZ games all characters are evenly strong with just different special attack styles.  Which leads to hilarious, but utterly nonsensical matchups like Krillin being able to put down SSJ3 Goku like it's nothing.  Not in this game.  Characters are actually scaled more like the show.  I was actually scared for a moment when I realized I was punching Radditz for 50 damage, and he was hitting me for 300!  Later I was super satisfied when Goku goes super saiyan and I get to demolish Freiza like a strapping young lad beating his meat furiously for the first time.

Like I said though it would be nice if it leveraged it a little further.  DBZ is one game where no-win fights would actually make sense, you're pretty much garunteed to lose and the score is based more on how long you survive, than how fast you beat it.  And the fights with the fun scaling are rare, most of the time the enemy is just the same level you are.

That's most of the major stuff for better or worse, the rest are nitpicks.  It's annoying on first boot up when it has a pop up for every single DLC being available and you have to tap through one by one, and there's over 9000 of them.  During overworld exploration your camera always snaps back into position behind you if you let go of the stick.  Graphics settings are mostly locked.

On a less technical side of things I wish it was Dragon Ball: Kakarot, and not Z.  The more casual and wholesome vibes the game has out of combat are a better fit for early Dragon Ball, not to mention we just haven't seen that stuff in game form in ages.  It would have been new, and fun.  It would also be a good match for the leveling up and training systems too.  It could always lead into Z and Super anyway, it is "Kakarot" so you'd think it would be Goku's story start to finish.  And yeah that would be an insanely long game, but maybe they could have released each series as an big expansion.

So yeah that's my long, rambling review for Kakarot.  If you like DBZ you'll probably like it.  If you find JRPG style crafting mechanics tedius you probably won't.  If you just want a pure fighting game you're probably better off with FighterZ, or waiting for Budakai 4 which I think I heard is coming?

Got when the game was on sale.

Heavily story based and does a great job at following the arcs with only minimal changes.  Good amount of special attacks to use, combat was a touch repetitive but fast paced and with changing character/attacks felt fine.

Cooking is the weird part of the game.  Ignore the flat bonuses, unless you want to accrue thousands of hours farming they will not make any noticeable difference.  The temporary bonuses are all that matter combined with levels.

Played the first three DLC's, the Trunks DLC is quite good and if you liked the base game will enjoy this DLC.  Other two DLC's add some ways to get experience, training with Whis or fighting Beerus, or horde fights against enemies.  

A great play through for a Dragon Ball Z fan, but not one you will play much beyond the story.

[b]‚ÄùAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHhhhhhhhhhhhhh!!!‚Äù[/b]
[i]-AAAAAAAAHHHHHHHHHHHHHhhhhhhhhh[/i]
[hr][/hr]

[b]Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot[/b] maybe the most faithful adaptation of the original anime yet.

[h1]X-Factor[/h1]
Unlike other videogame entries that are almost exclusively fighting games with maybe a recounting of the anime as a little undeveloped extra, here we have the exact opposite situation more focus on the original tale over complex or balanced mechanics.

Especially evident in major battles where a lot of care was put in the moment to moment animations of the fight itself.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
You‚Äôll be able to explore the setting of Dragon Ball flying around the world ad doing sub-quests while in-between major happenings.

The fighting is simple, one button to guard, one to keep attacking with the same long combo string, and characteristic to Dragon Ball games, one button to charge your energy to be used on very flashy moves.

[h1]Story[/h1]
It‚Äôs Dragon Ball... and it‚Äôs dumb, oh so very dumb, only re-experiencing the story again I realized how bad and nonsensical the writing is, it‚Äôs trash, but it‚Äôs the trash I grew up with.

But if you didn‚Äôt know... Follow the adventures of Goku and his friends as they save Earth from increasingly stronger foes.

[h1]Downsides[/h1]

Gameplay also spots a lot odd ducks:
[list]
[*]A long fishing minigame that will NEVER yield you a fish that you need for quests
[*]Vehicles that are way slower than even the slowest speed the slowest character can achieve
[*]A leveling system that is useless in its current form, since doing multiple subquests and fights in the overworld barely increases your exp bar while main fight give you multiple levels at once
[*]The world is filled with these ugly floating orbs that again mean jack since a single story fight will reward you more of these orbs that you will ever find within the overworld in your whole playtime
[*]Some attacks are VERY broken, to the point you can win any encounter by spamming them
[*]Skill trees that are beyond useless as skills will be locked behind story progression and you‚Äôll always have enough resources to purchase them, on top of that, skills are always an updated version of the previous so there‚Äôs no incentive to keep the old ones.
[*]Formations is a nice reference-fest, but another useless addition, they provide a way to gain more experience enhance the damage you deal and other stuff but in Kakarot level difference decides everything, if you are 5 level higher a couple of normal combos will defeat any enemies, if you are 5 lower you‚Äôll do no damage, this isn‚Äôt an exaggeration, you‚Äôll do 1 point of damage against the multi-million pool of the enemy. 
[/list]
[hr][/hr]

I‚Äôll give this game a thumbs up only because it‚Äôs a decent game and plays in my nostalgia, taken by itself and without knowing anything about the source material is a game with huge humps in quality, a bad story, useless additions and even more useless chores.

Honestly, a little disappointed. While the game is definitely fun to play, I would have expected I'd be able to do a bit more in terms of choosing who I want to play. You're really telling me for the base game I can only play as Goku, Vegeta, Trunks, Piccolo, and Gohan? For the number of characters in this game, all with their very own special moveset it was disappointing to say the very least. I thought I'd at least be able to switch to other characters in a "versus" mode of some sort where I get to play as Android 18 or literally anyone else from the roster but I was sorely mistaken.

Genuinely just a little confused by it all, and think it's a tad bit ridiculous that such a huge game could not at the very least create a Versus mode where you can choose who to play as, as well as choosing who to play against.

It starts off good with the classic music, nice curscenes and a solid Raditz fight.
Then you play a few hours, and it starts to fall apart. In a series so full of iconic moves and panels that were already turned into attacks in other games, they give you mostly generic 2-3 hit rush moves.
You fly around the world and it starts out nostalgic and comfy, until you realize the world is just buffer so you're not going throught the story in 5 hours.
None of the side content matters, side quests are funny enough but mostly just useless fetch quests.
Entire mechanics like the community board are absolutely useless, enemies start spamming moves that give them super armor to the point where you can't even stagger them after blocking.
While the cutscenes are gorgeous, many iconic moments get completely left out.
You're better off watching the cutscenes on Youtube

As a avid DBZ fan this was a very enjoyable game to play. The Cut Scenes look amazing and some of them gave me chills on how good it looked. My only personal problem with the game is there are only about 7 songs they use for everything in the game which gets very annoying pretty quick because there not the greatest songs to begin with but the rest of the game is amazing. In my opinion the game gives a great challenge which makes it fun for people who enjoy a challenge like myself (I Played on the Hardest Difficulty). My favorite part of the game has to be the Side Quests or Sub Story's Because they not only give you a load of exp but they also give you experiences you can't see in the show like Goku training goten because he feels bad not being as strong as his fusion partner trunks. That same Sub Story shows how the two boys just want to spend time with the fathers and that training was the best way to do so. I rate this game a strong 8.7 because i love music in games and it was honestly disappointing that there was no custom music made for this game aside from the remixes from the show which don't change much but the the rest of the game is a very enjoyable experience. If you find this game on sale its a must buy which it is on sale alot.

There's a huge skill tree, while linear still very fun to explore due to it's size.

There's a lot of story to get through, I'm around 14 hours in and only just now working on my second saga.

There are so many collectables, while this can also be seen as a bad thing, it tends to satiate my need to loot and find secrets.

Now I do wanna mention the bad of course. (There has to be something)
The difficulty scaling.. It's really quite something. If you're a veteran to these types of games, you're gonna have absolutely no issue at all on any difficulty setting. I'm nowhere near a veteran and I had to play on hard mode because the game doesn't give that much in way of a challenge.

Can I look past this? ABSOLUTELY. 

What I've played so far I can still recommend this game.

This game had so much promise but they continue to drop the ball when it is Bandai Calling the shots.  For starters, past 3 DLC drops which include Trunks and Bardok, which btw have NOTHING really to do with Goku, only indirectly, and soon getting the 23rd World Tournament, is NOT what the DB fans wanted.  Last good DLC drop was the Resurrection F DLC which was from when Frieza came back and became Golden Frieza.  We have yet to see: Goku Black or Tourny of Power which MANY fans have been patiently waiting for.  But this is what you get when you deal with any game that has Bandai as publisher.

I will say this, you want any good game at this point for Dragonball Super to go all the way up to Tourny of Power, go play Xenoverse 2 or FighterZ.  Chances of us getting any DLC of Goku Black or Tourny of Power is slim to NONE.  Plus the repetitive gather missions is absurd.  Only good parts of this game was the story a bit and the fighting.  That was it.

If we get Goku Black and Tourny of power, I will amend maybe my review, but until then, I give this game a Thumbs down.
it really makes you feel like goku

I was excited to hear about a Dragon Ball action/RPG considering I loved the Legacy of Goku games. I know this wasn't going to be a 3D remaster of those but figured it was going to be about what they did with retelling the sagas/arcs with some added stuff for more fun and fluff which makes sense and pretty what they did do. Ultimately however I can't help but feel like the game falls short in the long run. 

A lot of why I feel that way is because the main part of the story is voice acted and all well done which should be since the cast has done this several times now, however going into the side quests which are meant to add to this world end up being just the most mindless fetch quest with dialogue windows being voice acted by a simple grunt, huh or just a word or two which I can't stand. The combat just feels like Xenoverse lite and find no enjoyment in every damn thing having power armor. I get bosses having it to some degree but random encounters quickly and I mean quickly get old due to this. Also, the lack of diversity in moves outside of Special Beam Cannon, Kamehameha ETC added to the already dull combat since there was nothing that made any character stand apart from another like speed, strength and just power-leveled Goku only. 

I want to touch on however my biggest disappointment and that is the DLC (excluding the music ones given I get the whole needing to pay licensing fees and all). I absolutely cannot for the life of me understand why they would shoehorn in segments that were made for the main story into DLC with History of Trunks or Bardock. Literally, they took the dumbest page out of the Final Fantasy 15 playbook and thought it was good. I also can't help but feel like the 23rd tournament arc would have made sense also in the base game. DLC to this should have gone the route of Marvel's Spiderman and used the movies as added arcs and kept this a strict retelling of Z. 

Overall it does retell the story but seeing this going the route of Xenoverse 2 with DLC practice has made me lose any hope that Budokai Tenkaichi 4 will be any different. Also pretty damn lame this didn't get the graphic update of the newer gen consoles which is the only reason I cross bought this game like a dummy. (To be clear I have beat the base game, and first wave of dlc on ps4)

5/5 for fans, 3/5 for non-fans
Good fun jrpg. Story: It's dbz, from bottom to top. Canon-rich, with plenty of scenes from the series recreated within the engine. Combat's regular fun, not super-responsive but enough detail to keep you somewhat on your toes. Devs definitely chose style over substance. Npc's could be a little more alive, they're just standing there doing nothing until you arrive, but it's the original VAs as well, so it's cool. Cutscenes are very pretty, sidequests are a chore. A handful is interesting, everything else is 'go gather this, then beat these minions'. It's labeled 'open-world', but it's the same as SM-Odyssey; different maps to roam around in. I'm having fun with this game. Definitely not inventive, but good enough to keep me entertained. Get it on sale, not worth it's original pricing. I haven't played the DLC, but I feel you don't need it, plenty to do.

I want to give this a mixed rating, but here are the things that pushed me over the edge:

The graphics are not enjoyable to look at. I'd go as far as to say, they're downright ugly. Characters look alright, but the world looks way worse than even Zelda BotW - and this isn't even a handheld exclusive game. The scenery for every fight is basically just a wasteland with like two trees on the background. On PC you can unlock the framerate and the game will easily run upwards of 500 fps on a high end machine which tells you just how little is going on in this game world. For a 2020 release this is lacking.

My other major complaints are the cutscenes and the overall presentation of the story. They basically copied the animated series here because every dialog is just two models stuck in their idle animations standing in front of one another only moving their mouths...it may have been like that in the anime but it should've been obvious that this would make for really boring dialogues in a video game. I had to push myself towards the end of the game to not skip every cutscene and fast forward through every dialog. And whenever characters animate, it just looks painfully bad. In many situations the developers try to mask the bad quality of the animations by choosing awkward camera angles that block your vision over what's happening. 80% of the game, characters spend their time in their idle-, or walk-animation because there simply aren't any others. Overall there are VERY FEW moments in the entire game that have unique animations and this - again, in 2020 - just doesn't cut it.

Also the game is overburdened by completely pointless "rpg"-systems like cooking or building cars (when you can literally noclip through the open world by just pressing the fly-button). When I have a health pool of 1 million HP I don't really want to spend time gathering ingredients for a meal that increases my health by +50. These systems that pretty much never intersect with the actual gameplay could've easily been cut without anyone noticing.

Last thing I'm touching on is the soundtrack. There are so few tracks that in the middle of the game you already will start saying to yourself "jeesh, this one again". Again - there are no unique compositions for the big story moments here. It feels like an artist created like 5 tracks and the devs inserted them wherever possible. This leaves many big story moments without any impact as characters die or do their first time transformations in complete silence. I can't even imagine the epicness if characters or moments had unique musical themes like in other games or movies. In this game it's basically "ah this is a tense moment, let's grab the tense music.".

This was a huge chance to tell the entirety of the Z-Saga in one great game but the big parts of the story that everyone will remember from their childhood look way better in your memory than they do here. What is especially painful about this is that you only get a chance to make a game like this once. A massive chunk of potential was not realized here.

TLDR: 8/10 for DBZ fans, 7/10 for people who are new to DBZ, overall a 7.5/10

If you're a DBZ fan, you will most likely enjoy this because it's literally just the main story. It's not a perfect game but it's fun and engaging, I like the RPG elements, I like leveling up your characters and party, it adds more depth to the story's universe. It's rewarding to play someone like Gohan and watch him grow from a 4 year old kid to one of the strongest people in the universe. It adds depth to the story that was presented in the source material because you yourself are making the character stronger.

If you have never interacted with DBZ or know very little of the story, then this game is still good for you but it is definitely not the best way to experience the story. They make some changes to the story, nothing major because it is still faithful to the source material, but they change some stuff around to make it work better in a game. I understand why they did it, but in my opinion it takes away from the experience of the story.

Game play wise, it does get a bit repetitive. Combat is basically just pressing the B button. If you wanna make it a combo, you could press one of the other face buttons, but you don't have to. If you wanna do a special attack, you hold the left bumper and one of the face buttons together to do the special attack that was assigned to that button combination. If you hold the right bumper and one of the face buttons, then one of your party members will do something to help you out, such as attack an enemy.

To make something clear, this is not really a fighting game with RPG elements like Xenoverse or something, it's an RPG game with fighting elements. The combat isn't super in depth, there aren't any crazy button combos and timing and stuff. The combat is simple but effective.

The fights themselves are not that bad. Fighting the random encounters gets really repetitive because they are littered all over the map and you can usually kill them in a couple seconds because your character is just insanely strong, but you don't get much XP from it, so you do have to grind a lot to level up in that sense. However, there are regional bosses in certain areas of the world, which are much stronger than the average enemy you will encounter. They are usually at the level of a main story villain. These fights are much more rewarding in terms of getting experience. They are more difficult and time consuming, and they will continue to get a little more difficult. Once you defeat all the bosses in an area, a new one will spawn that will be even stronger. Once you defeat that, another will spawn that will be even more stronger. It's a good way to level up your characters and gain XP. Or if you just love to fight, it is really satisfying just absolutely demolishing your foes. While I said the combat is repetitive, that doesn't mean it's bad. As I said, it is really really satisfying just absolutely obliterating your foes and getting an S rank on the fights.

Where the combat truly shines is in the main story villains like the Saiyans or Frieza. It's a great combo of building up the villains that already happens in the story as well as the actual game play element. Like I said, if you're already familiar with the story, then you know how big of a deal someone like Frieza is, and when you finally get to fight him, it is incredibly satisfying. The main fights are definitely done right. 

The open world itself is enjoyable. There are lots of activities you can do, such as the random encounters I mentioned before, fishing, collecting Z Orbs, or doing side quests. A cool thing I like is that if you want to get the XP from the random encounters but don't wanna fight, you can just fly around super fast, and your character will be so insanely strong that you don't even have to fight them, just colliding with them will kill the enemy and you'll get the XP. It's really fun to do that and it makes sense DBZ-wise because most of the characters in DBZ are just that strong. The side quests are kind of a mixed bag. A lot of them are just fetch quests, but the developers usually put some kind of a fight in there to make it worth your time. While the side quests are hit or miss, they give you a ton of XP so it is definitely worth it to do them.

Speaking of XP, leveling up your character is easily the best aspect of this game. I just feel like you are able to connect and grow with the character so much more. I'm gonna use the example of Gohan again. In the show, we know how strong he is and we know what all he had to do to get there. But I also feel like a lot of that growth and training happens off screen. In this game, you go and do those fights, get the XP, and level up your character, so you are literally seeing your character grow into what they will become. You can level up and make your character stronger by of course getting XP, but also through Z Orbs. Z Orbs are collectibles that are found all over the map, and are also dropped through combat, side quests, and other activities. There are also these things called D medals, which are used for getting new moves to use in combat. To get these new moves, you go to training zones that are found in certain areas of the map. Each playable character has their own skill tree, but the moves are pretty similar, a lot of them are just the same. There are prerequisites to get the move, such as being a certain level, having a certain number of D medals and Z orbs, or having learned a certain move already. Once you have met these prerequisites, you enter a fight where you usually fight 3 enemies at once, and they are usually just some shadow version of a villain you already fought. They will usually be around the same level as you, depending on how much time you put into leveling up your character. Defeating them will grant you the skill, and you can assign it to a button combo after that. You can also go into the skill tree and level up your special moves using Z Orbs, as well as gain effects that can be used in combat, such as +5% damage or +3% healing or something like that. It's not super in depth like some other RPGs, but it is still good.

Once the Dragon Balls are available to use, you can spam them just like they do in the anime. You can revive enemies that you've fought before and fight them for XP. You can ask to be rich, you can ask for rare items, for Z orbs, etc. Once a wish is made, the Dragon Balls are on a 20 minute cool down and then you can collect them again.

There are some aspects I haven't mentioned, such as the Community Board, because I haven't delved too much into them. The community board is basically just a way to get more XP and gain some sort of advantage, I haven't put a ton of time into that yet, I'll probably do it later. Some other people said something about racing cars, which I haven't looked into yet.

The soundtrack's alright. Not as good as the Japanese soundtrack for the anime or the Bruce Faulconer soundtrack for the American version of the anime, and not as good as Kai's soundtrack, but it gets the job done. It's usually just a remix of a song from the original soundtrack. The voice acting is great because it's the original cast of the show doing the voices. Sometimes the lines come off as a little cheesy, but it doesn't really ruin anything.

I haven't finished the game yet, I'm on the start of the Android Saga right now, but from what I've experienced so far, it's a really great game.

Overall, this game is definitely worth $60, and if it's on sale, you should most definitely pick it up.

A Nostalgic Journey Through the Legendary Saga

Introduction:
Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot, developed by CyberConnect2 and published by Bandai Namco Entertainment, is an action role-playing game that takes players on an immersive journey through the iconic Dragon Ball Z universe. As a long-time fan of the franchise, I was excited to dive into this game and relive the epic battles and emotional moments that made Dragon Ball Z such a beloved series. After spending hours exploring its vast open world and engaging in thrilling battles, I can confidently say that Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot delivers a nostalgic and enjoyable experience for both fans and newcomers alike.

Gameplay:
The gameplay in Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot strikes a balance between action-packed combat and exploration. Controlling various characters from the Dragon Ball Z series, including Goku, Gohan, Vegeta, and Piccolo, among others, is an absolute treat. The combat system is accessible, allowing players to unleash a wide array of signature moves and flashy techniques with ease. Whether it's launching powerful energy blasts or engaging in intense melee combat, the battles capture the essence of the show's iconic fights.

Furthermore, the open-world aspect of the game adds depth to the experience. Players can freely explore iconic locations such as the bustling city of West City, the desolate wasteland of the Saiyan homeworld, and the serene surroundings of Kame House. These environments are faithfully recreated and filled with side quests, collectibles, and memorable encounters with familiar characters. While some side quests may feel repetitive, the overall exploration aspect adds value to the game and immerses players in the Dragon Ball Z universe.

Story and Presentation:
Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot excels in retelling the story of Dragon Ball Z. It follows the major events and arcs of the anime series, from the Saiyan Saga to the Majin Buu Saga, while introducing a few new narrative elements that add fresh perspectives to the familiar tale. The storytelling is engaging, capturing the essence of the characters and their relationships, which is sure to resonate with fans.

Visually, the game is stunning. The cel-shaded art style faithfully recreates the vibrant and dynamic visuals of the anime. Characters are beautifully designed, and their animations are smooth and impactful during combat sequences. Moreover, the game features iconic cutscenes from the original series, making players feel like they are part of the action.

Audio design is another strong point of Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot. The game features the original Japanese voice cast, adding authenticity to the experience. The soundtrack perfectly complements the intense battles and emotional moments, enhancing the immersion and invoking a sense of nostalgia.

Replayability and Additional Content:
Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot offers a decent amount of replayability. Aside from the main story, there are various side quests, activities, and collectibles that provide additional hours of gameplay. The game also features a robust character progression system, allowing players to level up their favorite characters, learn new abilities, and unlock powerful transformations. While the post-game content may not be as extensive as the main story, it offers enough incentive for players to return and continue exploring the Dragon Ball Z universe.

Conclusion:
Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot successfully captures the essence of the iconic anime series, providing an immersive and nostalgic experience for fans. The enjoyable combat system, faithful storytelling, visually stunning graphics, and nostalgic soundtrack combine to create a memorable adventure. While some minor flaws exist, such as repetitive side quests, they do not detract significantly from the overall enjoyment. Whether you're a long-time fan of Dragon Ball Z or new to the series, Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot offers an engaging and satisfying journey that will leave you craving for more super

This game is a beautiful remastering of the full story of Dragonball Z, in videogame form. You can join Goku and his friends through his journey, from the dynamics beginnings of the Saiyan Saga, to the thrilling finish at the Buu Saga. Fully voice acted from the original Japanese and English VAs

This game truly allows you to FEEL like Goku and co., from driving like a maniac and destroying general riff-raff here and there, this game captures the essence of what it would truly feel like to be in the Dragonball Universe from the perspective of the characters.

The combat is dynamic and beautiful, from particle effects and the feeling of the impact your attacks have. The use of camera angles in a way that feels like an episode from the show.

Frankly, the best part of the game is how frequently it goes on sale, from full price to like 15 AUD, and I'd say thats worth it to live the experience that is Dragonball Z.

after returning to this game ive realised a couple things

the ONLY thing this game has going for it is the graphics

the combat can be cheesed by exploiting almost every single mechanic to even a moderate degree

gameplay outside of the main story is used for basically exclusively getting zeni for heals (not required) as basically anything else gives a completely worthless reward or so little of what you get more than plenty of from the main story

the main story itself is alright in pacing but really drags on during some points, namely intermissions between main arcs and during the beginning of the 3rd arc WAY too many sidequests that are just "go to area, find thing repeat 1-3x turn in, do another" until you get to the actual content of the story

shockingly the dlcs solve none of the issues and almost all of them are a cut below the main story itself and either have either unique issues or exaggerate main issues of the game itself

dlc 1 is a complete nothing burger, it just introduces 2 fights, 1 as a challenge, and 1 as a fight you do dozens of times to just get free exp, but using it in the main story ruins the only even moderately engaging content of it, and afterward is completely worthless as it only carries over to the next dlc

dlc 2 is probably the best one even though its still got a bunch of issues, unlike dlc 1 it actually adapts the story instead of coming up with a couple chatboxes setting up what is essentially a cheat mode for the maingame, and within that it adds the only decent mechanic in the dlcs, raid battles, which while honestly more boring than the main 1v1 combat of the base game, is at least fun to mash punch and onetap 100 npcs until the game decides you can just clear out the remaining number

dlc 3 is one of the most awful pieces of video game ive ever played, it has 2 major segments, trunks v androids, and trunks v dabura, trunks v androids makes up around 70% of the content and consists of ONLY 2 FIGHTS repeated to around a 16 times total, with the androids themselves consisting of around 10 of those fights, and this is excluding all the optional times you can fight them by triggering the drones in the overworld, and to make it worse, the fight itself isnt interesting as its just dodging for a minute straight, doing 1/4 of their healthbar by bursting them down with everything you can and then repeating that till theyre dead 10 TIMES MINIMUM, and while the trunks v dabura fight is much better, it doesnt do nearly enough good to even begin fixing the dumpster fire that was its first act

dlc 4 is shockingly more competent than the others, no annoying gimmicks, no major repeat fights, the main character isnt just a rehash youve already played before, and the enviroment is unique and not just a remade area youve already been to, though this is all brought down by more than half of the dlcs playtime just being raid battles over and over and the assist movesets being AWFUL to fight for the training fights to level up your character

overall while it isnt literally the worst game ever made, its extremely disappointing from the hype the game recieved, hopefully dlc 5 is somehow an absolute masterpiece of gaming but from the quality of almost enjoyable to utterly awful of the base game and its dlcs, i wouldnt get my hopes up

I saw a lot of praise for this game when it came out and it was on sale so I decided to check it out. I was a big DBZ fan as a kid so it was nostalgic to play through the story. That being said, I feel like it wasn't worth it in hindsight. The story is fairly faithful (as far as I remember) but a lot of the big moments felt rushed. The actual game combat was fun for a bit, but got stale for me after about 10 hours or so. The RPG aspects seem interesting at first but are a bit silly as you swap characters to follow the story and seem unnessary for half the playable cast. Overall, I'd say just watch the show if you want to experience the story. The game is not bad but with so many good games out there, you really have to want to play a Dragon Ball Z game for this to be worth your time at all.

So this game is not bad but it is targeted at fans, where I think at times it sticks to the story so well, it keeps you from really enjoying all of it's RPG mechanics.  

Faithful retelling, simple battle mechanics similar to that of games like Xenoverse.  

The reason I can't really recommend this game, is it has so much potential but feels like it falls short.  Mini games are okay but I feel they could have tried a few more things for training, or tightened up the driving controls to feel like something different, same with the other rides in the game, they just feel pointless considering how efficient it is to just fly.
Speaking of pointless, the party system is mostly irrelevant through the main story.  There are intermissions in the story where you get some "freedom" to do side quests, train, gather materials or you can skip these sections if you want.

A really fun aspect of this game is the card game that is included, however, I'm assuming due to gacha mechanics that come with this card game or mabey it was lack of interest, but you cannot get any new cards, login bonuses don't register, you can't unlock new cards in game, and while it seems like there will be a single player mode, as of now it's incredibly difficult to play, which sucks because I really like some of the cards I've played against and this seems like a lot of fun.

Now, this game does a lot of things well.  The battles are handled pretty well but always come down to flying and charging the opponent, that might be over simplifying it but, a better combo system would have really added some depth.  
Crucial battles from the series felt special, the fight with Raditz was intense compared to everything else presented up to that point, and made me hopeful for more complex boss fights.  
This didn't happen to always be the case, but when you fight other bosses you feel like the protagonist, in a way that should satisfy fans. 
The sub stories are simple expansions on lore and I think make the world feel rich.  Also, it's a beautiful recreation of Akira Toriyama's world of Dragon Ball.  I did enjoy spending a lot of time just looking at all the things there are to see in the world, and hearing how the npc's respond to some of the current events.

If you really feel you need to play this game, I would at least get it on sale like I did. I think with a little fine tuning and more original story content would make this the perfect DragonBall Z game.
I liked it a lot, but it was full of nostalgia. I don't think it's good enough for non-DBZ fans. It can get quite repetitive, but it doesn't overstay its welcome.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

This review doesn't account for the (relatively poor) technical state of the PC version of the game. It focuses solely on the content itself.

Mechanically, it is a decent, if not great game - with the extreme downside of being heavily censored and watered down to PG, with consideration for modern, woke audiences. For this reason, I don't recommend you buy this game at full price, especially if you have not watched the anime or read the manga before. Consider that you are not taking the entire experience home with you, due to the abject censorship this game is subject to.

Provided that you can purchase it on a heavy discount and on the condition that you already know the Dragon Ball story like the back of your hand, play it, though the censorship is prevalent and everywhere. I'm not kidding, I can't stress this enough: practically every scene which depicted anything that could be even moderately objectionable has been censored or removed entirely. 

To be fair, this is a problem that Western dubs that were based on the American script had already accumulated over time due to oversensitive burger audiences, but it's tripled down in this game. If you are from a region which the anime was dubbed from the original Japanese edition or experienced it in the original Japanese, it's going to feel like the story has been robbed of its soul.

Obviously, contains spoilers, but here's a quick list of what's been cut in the main game:

https://dragonball.fandom.com/wiki/List_of_censorship_in_the_Dragon_Ball_series#Censorship_in_Kakarot

4/10 and 3 of those points are because it's Dragon Ball Z

Haven't tackled the DLC's yet as the endgame burned me out and is rather boring.
This is an awesome narrative game following the series closely like some of the old games did.
Something DBZ games have been lacking for ages.
The open world stuff has potential but is mostly filled up with nonsensical ridiculous sidequests, subpar minigames and collectathons.
A shame that for the sidequests I still am forced usually to play a designated character.

All in all well worth it at a discount as the story mode itself is great.
The optional content is lackluster.
Endgame i'll revisit eventually but so far has left me very 'meh'. 

I do hope they make a new Kakarot in the future uniting Z & the movies. Or Super and it's movies. But with a more well thought out endgame/open world aspect.

Update 1:  Finished the 2 dlcs linked to the 2 first Super Movies. 
Pretty interesting. Took me ages to realize they were hidden in the dlc section of the options screen. (assumed it led me to the store)

New abilities/level cap. And an interesting grind system allowing you to grind special items that will help you level up all your characters faster. 
The story of the 2nd part is fun. Horde mechanic is cinematic.
A bit barebones overall.

Regarding the Future Trunks DLC, only just started it.
The big plus there so far seems to be that it is more standalone. Unlocked a medal for the community board but overall it seems more selfcontained and has some specific map mechanics with drones hunting you.
Also you don't get access to your items/resources from the main campaign. Thus making things quite tense.
Final judgement is for when i finish the dlc.

DLC is almost a must though as it does add a lot of content overall.

Update: Trunks dlc is pretty good. And worth picking up. Looses momentum near the end. (post credits content) But it's pretty good. And especially fans of Trunks will love this dlc.

Addendum: 04/06/2023 - picked up the season pass. Still need to start Bardock's storyline.
A HUGE MINUS I STILL THINK SHOULD BE INTRODUCED is either levelscaling or a good New Game +. The time machine is only good for tracking down missed sidequest.

[h1]Fantastic way to experience one of the most famous series in history.[/h1]
Includes all major plot points with far better graphics without some of the distracting fluff the original series had. That being said, it also includes some gameplay fluff that may be distracting but only if you let it.
For those that know nothing about Dragon Ball Z: This is an anime. Duh, right? So you can probably guess the graphics style. That being said, it is fully 3D and very well done- vastly improved upon the original series' graphics. Everything's in English, if wanted, and the storyline is a key feature of this game. You don't really need to know a whole lot about the series to enjoy this game. It is a fighting game, yes, but it feels more like a third person action RPG since there is a lot of character growth in levels, stats, and skills. I haven't beaten this game yet since I've let my son do more than half of the gaming hours I have put into it, but from what I've heard there is a lot of extensive character customization[spoiler[ after the game is won in a New Game+ fashion[/spoiler]. The fighting is very smooth and most of the time (hate it those few times whenever I can't interrupt my combo to dodge or block an attack) you can time things beautifully for a kickass experience. Fighting evolves throughout the game which is great if you want to compare it to Dragon Ball Xenoverse 2, which is basically the same combos the entire game and only super skills changing. Awoken skills, or transformations as they're called in this game, also make a difference in your fighting style which makes perfect sense. You are also able to, but not required to after the first tutorial bit, upgrade your stats and gains using a Community of characters that specialize in different things to provide you with various long-term passive bonuses of your choosing. It works using a mechanic that is similar to a gift/relationship system, but you can do it from anywhere and almost at any time.

The big complaint I have about this game: It's not cooking like people mention, it's not grinding for items like others mention in their reviews (if you don't like grinding then play on an easier difficulty so you don't have to, ya foo), it's that even though you've achieved the experience levels and orbs (orbs work like a specialized experience resource in this game) to upgrade a skill there are still many times in which you have to have a break-out battle to "train" for the skill in order to learn it and use it. This is made a little worse in the way that you can't progress further in that part of your skill tree at all unless you unlock that specific upgrade through the break-out battle (obviously you're required to win it) needed to unlock that skill. Gets annoying, especially when you're in a part of the game where it won't let you locate and use a training node. [strike]Also, even though the new skill is better in every way it doesn't automatically replace the older version of the skill? Maybe people just don't want to use more ki, w/e who cares.[/strike]

Title: Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot - A Love Letter to Fans

Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ

Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot is a delightful action RPG that immerses players in the beloved world of Dragon Ball Z. Developed by CyberConnect2, this game faithfully recreates the iconic moments from the anime and manga, while also adding its own unique gameplay elements and storytelling.

One of the most impressive aspects of Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot is its stunning visuals. The cel-shaded art style beautifully captures the essence of Akira Toriyama's original artwork, bringing the characters and environments to life in vibrant detail. From lush landscapes to explosive battles, every scene is a visual treat for both long-time fans and newcomers to the series.

The gameplay in Kakarot strikes a balance between action-packed combat and exploration. Players assume the role of Goku, experiencing his journey from the Saiyan Saga to the Buu Saga, and even diving into other characters' stories in between. The combat system is fast-paced and satisfying, with a variety of special moves, combos, and transformations at your disposal. The inclusion of iconic battles against powerful foes like Frieza and Cell is a fan's dream come true.

The story is decent if you like the Dragon Ball franchise, the graphics are alright, but the real issues are that this game was NOT optimized for PC, nor does it properly support KB+M. Yea, I know, I see the community post discussing that if you change something in the graphics settings, it will display KB+M controls, but, even then, the controls can't be redefined, and for some reason, you have to change that setting every time you load the game, since it don't save it. 

Fishing, Follow-Ups, and Attack Charging just don't work at all with KB+M. Follow-Ups and Attack Charging, you MIGHT could live without, but you can't beat the game unless you can fish, and you learn that early on, like, before any bosses. To me, that is considered game breaking. The fact that I'm now forced to go buy a controller or find a mod to fix the issues just to progress past the first mission, on PC, is as anti-consumer as it gets. Also, Attack Charging don't even work WITH a controller on PC, so, there's that. The KB+M control scheme it has is unintuitive, but if I could change the buttons, I could make it intuitive. 

Oh, and speaking of mods, there are no mods to fix these issues. How do I know? I asked. I was then labeled as an elitist, so, what little community of players this game does have are unwelcoming, unhelpful and immature. 

In closing, if you're amongst the group of lazy, self entitled gamers that don't give a crap about the anti-consumerism that is continuing to destroy this industry, and you want to hang out with a bunch of immature morons who may not even welcome you, this game is perfect for you. On the other hand, if you're the type of person that expects something that you paid good money for to work, or you want to be part of a decent community then avoid this game.

If you play steam deck offline DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. I only play steam games through steam deck and mainly offline because I play during my daily commute. When I get home I get back on wifi to sync my saves.  for example it says I only played this game for .8 hours, but if you look at my achievements its very clear I played many hours of this game. 

I loved it, and it hit all the right beats for any DBZ fan, however, it happened twice to me where I closed the game and for some reason, my saves disappeared. The first time this happened I was 2 hours in and the game crashed. My saves were gone, but I decided to just play it again because I didn't get that far. The second time though, I was 11 hours in. I made sure that my steam deck said that my saves synced with steam. I then closed the game. When I reopened it my 11 hour save file was gone and it reverted me back to a 4 hour save. I went into my steam account to see if my 11 hour save file was there and it wasn't. I was dismayed, uninstalled this game, and regret buying it. 

I am not the only person to have experienced this issue with this game. And I've never lost my saves for any other game I played on steam, only this one. The devs did a poor job with their save management system. So again, if you mainly play offline or on the go DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.

The combat in this game is boring and monotonous as all hell, you have one attack combo and your super's so you're either just mashing the attack button or spamming kamehameha. Also the side quests and everything in the world is just pointless junk that isn't fun or engaging and leveling up is pointless when you get your exp after reaching different points in the story anyways. This is just another DBZ story game with absolutely nothing else to it, the leveling system seems nice but since they have to keep skills locked til you get to certain points in the story it's meaningless. Although I could handle it being just another retelling of the dbz story if the combat was engaging but like i said it's not.
As a dragonball fan, i love it!

I have not really enjoyed a DBZ game since Tenkaichi 3 and this entry is one of the best games this saga has given us. I did not know that I would still be able to feel the magic and owe from this universe again like I did during my childhood, but Kakarot delivered and more. 

By no way is this a perfect game. Fights can become frustrating as ennemies tend to often block even the strongest of your moves, the soundtrack is good but some musics are way overused and become a little repetitive, there are some missing moments from the anime etc.

But for every wrong thing there are 10 others that are just great. The world is gorgeous, filled with easter eggs and other references that I would not have expected them to add (I particularly enjoyed the Dragon Ball nostalgic pictures spread across the map), cutscenes are gorgeous, the fighting system is very satisfying and really gives you the sense of power and strength of either your Z fighter or the enemy you're up against. Musics are also great, if not too few for my liking. Most dialogues are actually VOICED which adds a lot to the immersion and overall it just feels like a very generous game.

I am glad seeing them adding DLCs to make this game more complete and I would LOVE to see the same formula applied to the original Dragon Ball! I can't recommend enough this game if you enjoyed the original DBZ anime!

Perfection

I have experienced countless games that have tried to capture the essence of their source material, but none have quite reached the pinnacle of perfection like Dragon Ball Z Kakarot. This title not only pays homage to the beloved series but also delivers a gaming experience that is both innovative and thrilling. It is a true testament to the developers' understanding of what makes Dragon Ball Z so special.

The game's astonishing graphics are a sight to behold. The characters are rendered with an exceptional level of detail, and their movements are fluid and true to the anime. Even the most intricate of battle sequences are brought to life with such precision that one cannot help but marvel at the visual spectacle. The game's environments are equally stunning, providing a vibrant and immersive backdrop that transports players to the Dragon Ball Z universe.

But the true genius of Dragon Ball Z lies in its gameplay. The developers have crafted an intricate and rewarding combat system that caters to both newcomers and seasoned fans alike. Players can execute a variety of moves, including combos, special attacks, and transformations, allowing them to fully embody their favorite characters. The game also boasts an impressive roster of fighters.
The story mode, however, is where the game truly shines even more! The developers have managed to distill the essence of the anime's epic narrative into an interactive experience that is both engaging and emotionally resonant. The pacing is expertly crafted, and the game's story arcs are faithful to the source material. Each pivotal moment is presented with a cinematic flair that rivals even the best adaptations in the industry. This game allows players to relive their cherished memories of the series while forging new ones within its digital realm.

In conclusion, Dragon Ball Z Kakarot is an absolute masterpiece, earning a well-deserved 5/5 rating. Its captivating gameplay, breathtaking graphics, and enthralling storyline make it a must-play for fans and newcomers alike. The developers have not only paid tribute to the iconic series, but they have also elevated the gaming experience to a whole new level. Dragon Ball Z is, without a doubt, the perfect way to relive old memories and create new ones in the process.

I paid $14.99 on a flash sale... looks like you can purchase it for $21.24 at the time of this review. DO NOT HESITATE IF YOU'RE EVEN CONSIDERING IT AT THIS PRICE! Feels like a steal I would have easily paid the $59.00 average price for a game of this quality.

*Controller apparently is a must. I use one on my PC, but I've heard the M&K isn't the best options for this game.

I've played for a small chunk of time compared to the amount of game content I have left to play.  I can say that I've played Dragon Ball games since Ultimate Battle, and into Budokai.  I have played the Raging Blast and Tenkaichi series games too. I currently play FighterZ and used retroarch for Legend and DB Kart more recently.  I haven't played much of the MMO games though.  I love the 2-D side fighting along with the three dimensional aspects from RB and UT.  This game is what Dragon Ball really needs to translate the story properly.  This story starts early in DBZ and lets you feel the length of the story in a very positive way! It's fun to play and immerse yourself into the world and be a part of it playing different characters as you progress.  The RPG elements are not overwhelming.  They are simple once you get the feel for it knowing what you're looking at, yet filling.  I am playing on hard which requires you to learn the game.  I am looking forward to more boss battles to beat the challenge.  Regardless on the type of game you want to play, whether it be a fighter, MMO, or open world/railed story mode, you want this game in your collection.  I play this game when I want to roam around and have fun with the story.  The DLC is going to be fun to get into.  It is structured like LOTR Shadow of War/Mordor, in the sense that your dlc stories are like separate slightly smaller games on their own using the same engines and build. Some you can access right away and others require you to beat Kakarot first.  I haven't played any yet because I want to finish the main game first.  I picked up the base game and Season 1 pass on the sale.  So glad I did.  I do wish there were more difficulty settings. A very hard and ultimate difficulty would be a nice addition to the standard three.  OH YEAH! there is a digital version of the card game you can access as well! From the main menu or even in game from terminals in cities! You can collect cards in the main game or while you play the card game itself.  I can't wait.  The card game is loosing online support but from what I read will still be playable against CPU.  So great.  I still have all my old cards!  This game is definitely worth it.  This game is terrific for people wanting a casual or semi challenging RPG and/or DB fans.  My main issue is that I want more content and combat mechanics! HAHAHA Seriously play it.

Experience the emotions, the triumphs, the strife,
As you progress through the game, and emerge as a warrior of life.

So take the journey, as a Saiyan or a Z-fighter,
And immerse yourself in the world of Dragon Ball, brighter.
Dragon Ball Z Kakarot is a game that truly rocks,
Bringing fans and newcomers alike to new heights, unlocking their locks.

This game is absolute trash.

Controls are terrible:

K&M hotkeys are clearly designed by someone who hasn't played PC games since the 90s.

When you go to Settings to change Icons to Keyboard +Mouse it gets reverted back to Type 2 as soon as you turn the game off.

And just after some testing I can confirm that for no reason whatsoever the directions will lock you

--->Quick example: S+ Space is the command for jumping backwards to dodge. Sometimes, for no reason, it will lock you into a forward dodge. It will take multiple times of  using totally  separate actions to "shake it off"

So many poorly written/voice acted cutscenes.

And the fights are literally JUST ABILITY SPAM! It's non stop.

Let me be abundantly clear: THIS GAME ISN'T DIFFICULT, it's just block or dodge in almost the exact same patterns with an increasing tempo based on enemy health.

This game was clearly meant  to be a microtransaction fiasco that took an absolute shit.

The people who say Xenoverse was worse than this are oblivious to this games glaring flaws.

It's a pretty looking game, but has several issues. First, as much as they tried to make this game compatible with a keyboard and mouse, it was meant for a game controller. The game constantly provide prompts to use controller buttons rather than referring to the keyboard and mouse buttons that I'm using; "what button do I mash to cat the fish?". This leads to the second problem, wonky controls. During fights, evading moves are an issue when the game forces you to be up close when your're trying back up. Other problems is trying to search for the key bindings, when some are incorrectly listed, example world map (in the map section press Z not S). When teaching moves, the legend still refers to the game pad when you're working with a keyboard+mouse. 

Great, half way into the game, I can't use the items hotkey to heal mid battle.

Lastly, the tutorial is all over the place. One moment you get spammed with multiple tutorial windows, the next you're trying to find the right key to interact with a dinosaur. Many of these problems can be solved by constantly searching on the forums to find if anyone else is experiencing these problems. Fortunately, there are others out there that do, which is a relief, but implies that this game should have had more beta testers to help smooth this game out. It's also a bit annoying when you're fighting others that have multiple fighting moves, but when playing those same characters, you're unable to pull off those special moves yourself (ex. stunning, beams); the "Super Attacks" feature is broken

DRAGON BALL Z: KAKAROOOOOT!!! Finally the Dragon Ball Game we've always wanted has finally become a reality. I've never met a Dragon Ball game I didn't like. DBZ: Kakarot is the first time I've LOVED a DB title ever. Simple to understand and play, Open World, RPG elements and the nostalgia of the DBZ story line. Whether you're an O.G. fan of the Anime from 96' like myself or maybe you've never heard of DBZ, GOKU aka KAKAROT and the Dragon Balls before today. Either way it doesn't change the fact this game scores a 10 out of 10 in my book. Spoiler Alert: DBZ Anime fans are in for a treat playing as your favorite characters as you follow the original story line. The remastered cut scenes from the original anime bring new life to the story for long time fans to enjoy and feel like their watching DBZ for the first time. Enjoy!

After a decent amount of time with Kakarot I feel I can recommend it to most. The gameplay is a mix of action RPG fights as many DBZ characters and exploring the overworld gathering resources and doing side quests to power up your characters. The fights themselves are usually satisfying and cinematic while doing a great job making you feel stronger as you level up. The overworld isn't amazing but serves its purpose and has many areas and secrets to explore.

Some small gripes I have include boring filler battles (Prepare to fight the same RR army robots a couple dozen times), and the combat becoming a tad stale. Even across many different fights, while the opponent's attacks, voice lines, and cutscenes are quite different, the way you fight and defeat each of them rarely differ. Also the game's built in card game is actually extinct, which is disappointing when a lot of in-game rewards are cards for a game nobody ever plays.

As long as you're a fan of or at least interested in the Dragon Ball Universe, there's enough satisfaction in becoming stronger and progressing the story to keep going to the end.

All in all I would rate Kakarot as follows:

As an open world RPG: 7
As a whole: 8
As a game for DBZ fans: 9

So, I made it a little further in this game than last time I tried it, but my patience is wearing thin. This is, like, almost an objectively bad game. Horrible combat, buggy as fuck, god awful camera. Really has no intention of making you feel (lol) like any of these characters. 

This game is ass easy. You will not die as long as you have an above room temperature IQ. That being said, the combat is atrocious. Your characters are push overs. Every, and I mean EVERY enemy has super armor. Remember that time Vegeta full power decked a saibaman in the face and it tanked his shot like Superman? No? Oh, well that's the whole game. There are no satisfying offensive or defensive tactics in this game. Just mash B three times, dodge to the left or right, and hit B three more times. Every boss fight is like a Destiny health sponge boss that you unload on for five minutes. Just awful. And don't even get me started on those training mode bosses you have to fight to unlock more moves. Ugh. 

It's got cute stuff, good graphics, and some funny moments. However, this is just like every other low budget Dragon Ball video game. Cutscenes are mostly characters standing in place exposition dumping on things you already know. They went balls deep on animating Recoome's fight with Goku, but left out Final Flash lol. 

I know zoomers have taken to calling this game "GOATED AND PEAK" or whatever, but I just can't. The open world is full of Superman 64 rings to collect and nothing else. Well, that's not entirely true. If you like fetch quests that all play out the same then sure, have fun. You like the fishing from FFXV, dude? You like mini games? Alright, have fun catching the four varieties of fish in the game.

The combat in these games is so one-dimensional and just a constant cycle of doing the same moves over and over again.  It makes the gameplay dull and boring. The combat was exactly the same in Xenoverse 1 and 2, just incredibly boring game mechanics held up by a good story and animation.  I swear most people just bought this for the nostalgia.

Dragon Ball Z Kakarot is a must-play for fans of the anime series. The game's graphics are impressive, and the attention to detail in the game world is phenomenal. As a player, you get to take control of Goku, one of the most iconic characters from the Dragon Ball Z series, as well as other characters like Gohan, Piccolo, and Vegeta. The game covers the entire Dragon Ball Z saga, from the Saiyan arc all the way to the Buu saga, so you'll get to experience all of your favorite moments from the show.

One of the best things about Dragon Ball Z Kakarot is the combat system. The combat is fast-paced and intense, and the game does a great job of making you feel like you're really in the middle of a Dragon Ball Z battle. Each character has a unique set of moves and abilities, and you can also unlock special moves and transformations as you progress through the game.

The game also features a robust skill tree system that allows you to customize your character's abilities and stats. You can choose to focus on specific areas like melee combat, Ki attacks, or support abilities, depending on your play style.

Another great feature of Dragon Ball Z Kakarot is the open world exploration. You can fly around the world, interacting with various characters, completing side quests, and collecting items. The world is vast and detailed, and there are plenty of secrets to uncover.

One area where the game falls a bit short is in its side quests. While some of the side quests are interesting and offer unique challenges, many of them feel repetitive and don't add much to the overall experience.

Overall, Dragon Ball Z Kakarot is an excellent game for fans of the series. The combat system, skill tree, and open world exploration are all top-notch, and the game does a great job of capturing the spirit of the Dragon Ball Z anime. The only real downside is the occasionally repetitive side quests.

I enjoyed my short journey and reliving the DBZ series in this game, the game itself is not amazing but its aint bad i would give it [b][i][u]6.5 / 10.[/u][/i][/b][h1]Pros[/h1][list][*]Enjoyable fast paced fighting and rewarding for completely controlling combos, sync and counters.[*]Classic DBZ story with a few skips and adjustment, mostly skipped the awkward stuff.[*]They implemented a few systems and new mechanics I did not see before such as the community and passive skills systems. They weren't perfect/good but I enjoyed seeing something like that.[/list][h1]Cons[/h1][list][*]Side missions are the classic repetitive fetch me X,Y,Z. Very boring and the only reason you'll want to do them are for levels for the end game achievements.[*]This game lacks special case boss fights, for example the battle against freeze is the same as any other fight.[*]Too many robots. I felt like I'm back in Dragon Ball with the RR army all over again.[*]The game may offer open world but sometimes it feels like you just need to fly from point A to B, there is no REAL control over the character and exploration as I would like.[/list]Would buy it only on sale.

Fans of the series and Dragon Ball newbies alike will find a great time in this title.
