Absolutely phenomenal. If you, much like me, grew up playing the Legacy of Goku games on the gameboy growing up then this is the fully realized, 3d, epic-scale game that you've been waiting for. DBZ Kakarot is, in my personal opinion, what the Legacy of Goku series wanted to be but  couldn't because of technical limitations at the time. The combat isn't crazy or epic. It's basic RPG combat. You kill enemies, you gain xp, you grow your stats and progress the story. It's something I've been waiting for since I was about 12, I'm going on 27 now, and I couldn't be happier. As with most modern titles with name brands slapped on the side it is expensive, but I do believe it is worth it.

TL;DR It's Legacy of Goku but 3D

Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot - Hands down the best DBZ game to date yet for me personally. The detail in the battles, the voice overs, the cutscenes!! I enjoyed them all.

The only downside to the whole experience was how the entire world just felt...empty. Sure you can fish and you can play baseball...but that's it. It would've been great if you could enter tournaments with specific conditions and limits, drive around in the world in cars like Goku, Picollo and Vegeta had to do when getting their driver's licence, balance school life with crime fighting for Gohan. There's soooooo many things you can pop into this, but it just feels bland when going from mission to mission. To add to this, I honestly also feel like Bandai Namco really REALLY has just been shitting out the same stuff every time rather than try add more stuff for the player to do.

Other than the rant, this was a great game and I enjoyed it a lot.

To start this review, I'd just like to preface that I have only played the base game and the History of Trunks DLC. I am aware that people take issue with Bandai's handling of pricing, and the Dragon Ball Super DLC. However I will not be discussing those things in this review. I will be updating this as I plan to buy the Bardock Expansion. 

Dragon Ball Z Kakarot is the first real open world experience we've gotten to see in the Dragon Ball franchise. I have grown up playing over a multitude of Dragon Ball games. Seeing all different adaptations to Z's story, I was enthusiastic to see how this game would compare. The game is BEAUTIFUL, there is very obvious care put into this game visually. As the story progresses, the detail of the games CG cutscenes also become more detailed. If I were to guess, this would most likely be to homage the development of the Z anime's style. This game nails world building, sound design, tone setting, in ways that Dragon Ball hasn't gotten before. The song pieces in the game are directly from the anime, now redone in new quality. I usually roll my eyes at another Dragon Ball game release, in which you experience the Saga fights in a very cut and dry manner, However this game has become an absolute essential to me. I have but one complaint with this game. Considering this is still a [u]game[/u] I know I can't expect them to include everything from the original Z, but you get to miss out on what I'd deem some of Z's BEST moments. For instance,[spoiler] the amazing choreography in the fight between Majin Vegeta and Goku are cut down to nothing but a slideshow. They skip out on almost ALL of the 25th World Tournament, they rush Gohan's saiyaman arc, a big plot point in the Cell saga is also dismissed. Goku giving Cell a senzu bean after their fight. In Z, it is clear that Goku sees something in Gohan that everyone else doesn't see, it is a complex father-son dynamic that they share that I feel gets dismissed in Kakarot, and the moment of him giving Gohan the lead to fight Cell is instead now anti-climactic. Candy Vegito is skipped, Vegeta's iconic Final Flash against Cell[/spoiler] is basically skipped, and I'm sure there is more that I could name. To a newcomer, these may not be a big deal to miss out on, however for long-time fans like myself feel bummed out to miss out on these hype and important moments to the story that we enjoyed seeing on our first time. Sometimes the AI can be very annoying as well, but as long as you keep upgrading your characters as your supposed to and make use of the mechanics the game gives you - you'll be fine. 

This game is probably the best retelling of the Dragon Ball Z story in game format, despite it's shortcomings. If they had just taken their time more, I think the game would be a worthy 9 out of 10. I can for sure say the money I spent for the game didn't go to waste. 8/10

7/10 is was a pretty good for being the exact same thing that we have played for the last 25 years, but the fighting in this game was super engaging for me personally just had a blast. "Cutscenes" looked really good made u feel like your watching DragonBall Z in 3D that actually looks good. Now the biggest con for me were the achievements, because there some grinding one in this that require to get certain items to either make meals or to do the training challenges and some of them are really hard to find from just playing the game through normally. Also this game has nothing to do after beating the story really except collecting items, which is alright if your into wasting your time to get achievements. Didn't play any of the DLC cause Bandai doesn't make new achievements to get from purchasing DLC so no point for me. Overall it's good I would recommend playing it maybe not full price though cause if you played one DBZ game you've played them all.

Overall this game is okay if you like dragonball. It hits on all the big story points. The overall production is minimal though, like the game was rushed out. To charge money for the extras they added is a little crazy though. The open world aspects are there but don't really hit with the main game, and the main game's combat is incredibly shallow even up to the majin buu saga. The cutscenes are very samey, the music is subpar at best with the faulconer track mods being the only saving grace and those happen only very rarely. The cutscenes are decently made but I don't really feel like I'm playing dragon ball and 90% of the game is fighting 2 or 3 kinds of enemies. Every 5 hours you might get a boss that does a slightly different move and you can tell from those fights that SOME people cared about this game,probably some writers, too, but for most who worked on it, it's probably just a quick cash grab off nostalgia sadly. If we're lucky we'll get a fully fleshed out version of the same thing sometime in the next 10 years, but if you're looking for a good comprehensive, truly defining dragon ball gameplay experience, go find tenkaichi 3 or wait for the new tenkaichi to release and hope they didn't give it the same treatment they gave this game. Caviat to my negative review is that I'll probably still finish this game because I love dragon ball, but really for 90% of people it's not worth it, especially for the price.

Fun but can be a little repetitive. Its closer to Legacy of Goku than to any of the fighting dbz console games, the combat comes close to the feel of Tenkaichi but suffers from lack of combos that makes combat get a bit boring after a while, The world is cool to explore at first but feels empty with the same enemies always appearing to fight, some variety of common enemies like we got in the LOG games would have been nice and likely could have made the bland combat a bit more entertaining if there was a bit more strategy to beating foes. Some more interesting side content and collectibles (maybe like the lost Namekians in LOG2) would have been welcome. The cutscenes are inconsistent, some being done very well and mirroring the anime scenes they depict, others feel lazy.

If you're a Dragon ball fan you'll probably enjoy it. I haven't tried the DLC yet as its a bit to expensive in my opinion(my opinion on most DLC, i miss being able to just unlock side content and characters instead of being forced to buy content that 15 years ago, would have just been included in the base game.  Maybe ill pick it up during a sale. This game does feel ripe for an original Dragonball story line following Kid Goku and Co and i hope they capatilize on that, if so ill probably buy the DLC on release if it looks promising. Maybe young fans arent as into that idk, I never cared much for Super so id like to see them go back instead of forward.

If your looking for a good DBZ fighting game look elsewhere.(like emulation) BandaiNamco should know by now that DBZ fans want a remake or a game like Tenkaichi 3 more than anything, but I've pretty much accepted that we wont get that and if we do it will be a shadow of its former self and suffer from predatory DLC instead of including the massive amount of unlocks (and incentive to keep playing) that the original tenkaichi had.

Close to 10 hours in, i would say this is a 30 dollar game at most 40. The story telling itself is okay, most of the time the text/speech cut-scenes linger for too long around a 1 second or so where you get an awkward silence, some side quests makes no sense others are really good and are created with the characters personality in mind. Combat itself which is the core of the game is good, its quick and fluid, but then there are the abilities. Galick Gun and Kamehameha beams hit like a wet noodle, they are not the finishers in the anime or manga, but on par with a punch or kick so that is disappointing. The "open" world is littered with balls to collect which in my opinion only hurts the gameplay, very boring just flying around and collecting balls (like 1000s of them) when you also get them from fights. The level grinding from world mobs/monsters is terrible, you get almost no exp and eating meals gives you permanent stat boosts but I am not gonna spend 24 hours eating just to get strong. The graphics considering characters and combat effects are really good, but the textures on the world itself looks like its from early 2000. The difficulty sliders seems to reset itself every time i have started up the game and the vsync option dosent work for me, makes the game run at 32 fps with 1-2 fps variation but the game runs at 60 fps locked 100% but with a lot of screen tearing. considering i payed 60 dollars i am disappointed, the game seems a bit rushed or at least many things seems like an afterthought or bolted on after the core gameplay (story/combat) was finished.

I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 16. My son recently started Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot, a game that's both great, and frankly disappointing. As the title would suggest, it covers the story of the anime Dragon Ball Z, although, I'd say that's probably one of the biggest problems, but we'll get to that later.

In DBZ Kakarot you get to play as almost all of the major main characters of the show, each with their own unique move sets, abilities, skills, and transformations. Said move sets are also quite nice looking, and change based on the form you're in, and if your ki is surged. The base game content isn't SUPER grindy, although it can get a little annoying at times having to collect all of the necessary orbs to level up your skills. Each of the skills are visually impressive, with decent lighting and sound, and in some situations they even have unique short cinematics that play when you use them. The transformations are also similarly visually impressive, and give you that great power-trip that you'd expect when transforming into a being of great power. The music is also quite good, although from what I can tell, most of it is just taken from other DB media (mostly the anime).

Unfortunately, despite those positives I can't recommend the game unless you're a MASSIVE DB fan, and even then I'd still recommend at least waiting for a price drop.

The fact that the majority of the content is from DBZ is a major problem, based on the fact that most other DB games also use DBZ content instead of taking anything from the original DB, Super, or GT. It's so tiring seeing the same thing that you've seen countless times in other games, just with slight differences in art, and gameplay. The gameplay is pretty good, but the story is disappointing. It's just too stale. On top of that, outside of the MAJOR scenes in the DBZ anime (and in some cases even major scenes) all of the story is shown through crappy in-game recycled character animations, and nonsensical visual behaviour from the characters. For example, [spoiler]when you first go SSJ against Frieza, at one point you just stop fighting, Goku is still floating in his battle stance, and then suddenly just switches to the basic idle flight animation you use when traversing the world.[/spoiler] It's so jarring and reeks of laziness. Clipping is frequent, and the majority of voice lines aren't even voiced, they're just subtitled. Characters repeat the exact same noises and phrases over and over and over again in battle regardless of if they match or not. A perfect example is when almost any character charges their ki. They yell very calmly, which fits the charging. However, when they transform into SSJ, SSJ2, SSJ3, etc, they use the EXACT SAME CALM YELLING. In the DBZ Anime and Manga, Goku pretty much bursts his f*cking lungs with how much he screams, yet in DBZ kakarot it's just a calm, recycled yell that you've already heard 100+ times. On top of that he uses the same yell when he surges. This is even more absurd when you surge in the god forms, mainly SSB. The community system is done so poorly as well. Unless you're going for achievements, or you wanna level up your skills/characters a teeny bit quicker, there's absolutely no incentive to putting any time or effort into the system. Why would I spend hours collecting items and levelling up what is basically digital cards for a 10-20% damage boost, when I could just transform into ANY of the forms and become significantly stronger in a split second? The meal system is also unfortunately quite poorly designed. Some of most efficient meals you can use to increase your stats still only increase them by a couple hundred points, when by the end of the game you have literally millions of points just in HP alone... Outside of the character levelling, none of the systems are even slightly interesting or even all that useful.

Edit: As of 22/02/2023 I have played through each DLC, including the new Bardock one, so my review edit is basically just adding to the DLC portion.

The DLCs are a mixed bag. A new power awakens P1 has basically no story, doesn't follow the canon of the show or manga, and is essentially just [spoiler]"get given every form that already exists so new playthroughs can become super op, get given SSG, and use items to become super high levelled, after a few short copy-pasted fights against Whis."[/spoiler] Once you've done that with Goku and Vegeta, that's it, DLC 1 over. A new power awakens P2 is a little better, with a short story that MOSTLY follows the canon of DB Super, but even then, you just get given SSB after a few short fights that are copy-pasted from the previous DLC. And the sad thing is, the forms are super cool, so if you want to use these awesome forms, you first have to play through a sh*t pair of DLCs, although the boss fight at the end of DLC 2 is pretty good, but it's not really worth it to replay it. Trunks - The warrior of hope is definitely better. Future Trunks' story isn't usually covered in DBZ media, so it's a nice breath of fresh air compared to the recycled base game. Both Future Trunks and Future Gohan have some pretty nice movesets, especially Trunks due to his unique moves. A fair few are recycled from Future Trunks in the base game, and from other characters, but the couple unique ones feel nice and have that classic DB flashy-ness to them. The addition of the Future Buu Saga is also a nice addition, so no complaints with this DLC. Bardock - Alone Against Fate is by far the BEST DLC so far. As usual, Bardocks base combos look great and are a massive step up from base game and even the Future Trunks DLC. All of Bardocks moves are also unique, and despite Bardock being quite weak in canon, they all feel extremely strong, and again, have a nice, flashy look to them. The story is similar to the Future Trunks DLC in that it's a nice breath of fresh air. Bardocks crew actually have a little bit of character development via the main quest and sub-stories, so that's a good addition. The only real dissapointment is how short it is. Maybe they could've included the 'Past' portion of the original Bardock story? But regardless, it feels like a step up in quality. One more annoying thing, which thankfully doesn't really apply to DLC 3 and 4, is that you need to grind a sh*t ton of orbs for any of Goku and Vegeta's new god-power moves, which can take hours.

[b]Conlusion:[/b] After the additional 100 or so hours I've put into the game, including playing through each DLC, and even adding mods once I was bored, I still can't really recommend the game, unless you're a massive fan of the gameplay (which I feel gets repetitive easily), a DBZ super-fan that's not tired of the recycled story, or you intend on modding the ever-loving sh*t out of the game. Outside of DLC 3 and 4, the story, animations, and voicing are just so poorly developed, and it feels like very little effort was actually put into them. The only saving grace for the base game is by far the mods, however even that's limited as most of the decent mods broke once the Bardock DLC was released. If you honestly really wanna try the game, wait until it's on sale. Otherwise, steer clear.

[i]TLDR; Outside of DLC 3 and 4, the game and its extra content feels half-baked, over-used/stale, and that very little effort was put into actually making it fun enough to warrant a purchase and proper playthrough unless you're a DBZ super-fan, get the game on sale, or have NEVER played a DB game covering DBZ.[/i]

For every Dragon Ball fan this game on the first run is OMG! From the soundtrack, presentation, exploration, pace, everything is fantastic! But as usual like most Dragon Ball fans we tend to focus on the wrong things when playing a new DB game for the first time. On the second run you see the truth. The combat is basically single button focused, the enemy AI is braindead that does nothing else besides Super Attacks that have a set duration, I mean the enemies don't even evade, they just sit there and tank everything if their super attack animation has started, which is ridiculous. Grinding to level up is useless sibce you get enormous catch up levels with the main story. If you are not a Dragon Ball fan this game is garbage. If you are tho and haven't played it yet, this is a must have for the first play through! After that, bury it and leave the beautiful memories you got out of it be.

Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot is a fantastic game that offers an engaging and faithful retelling of the classic Dragon Ball Z storyline. The game's graphics are top-notch, with beautiful cel-shaded visuals that capture the look and feel of the anime. The game's open-world exploration element is a standout feature, offering players the ability to explore iconic locations from the Dragon Ball Z universe, complete side quests, and find hidden items.

The game's combat system is also well-executed, with fast-paced and satisfying battles that require a good mix of strategy and reflexes. Players can chain together a variety of moves and techniques to create devastating combos, while also dodging and blocking enemy attacks. The inclusion of various playable characters with unique moves and abilities also adds to the game's overall depth and replayability.

Another highlight of Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot is the attention to detail in the story mode. The game covers all of the major arcs from the anime series, offering a comprehensive and immersive experience for fans. The game also includes new story content that adds to the overall narrative, offering fresh perspectives on classic characters and events.

However, the game is not without its flaws. While the game's open-world exploration element is impressive, it can feel a bit repetitive after a while, and some side quests can feel like filler content. Additionally, the game's camera can be problematic at times, making it difficult to keep track of enemies during more hectic battles.

Overall, Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot is a must-play for fans of the series. It offers an immersive and faithful retelling of the classic Dragon Ball Z storyline, with excellent graphics and a well-executed combat system. While the open-world exploration element and side quests could be improved, the game's attention to detail in the story mode makes up for these shortcomings. With that in mind, I give Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot a score of 8/10.

DBZ Kakarot is at its best when it is dishing out fanservice. The major story beats are presented in a flashy & gorgeous fashion, flying around the world is fun, there's tons of details big and small that fans can enjoy, and I really liked the community board where you can arrange badges representing characters to give you powerups, w/ certain groupings dishing out cute exchanges between them as they give you bonus upgrades. This RPG is probably the most realized the DBZ world has ever felt in video games. While its great to see alot of these sidequests add more to the universe, unfortunately there's not alot of variety in them as most of them boil down to fetch quests or combating foes. Combat is also unbalanced, but not in a difficult way: on the default difficulty (they patched more options in later) the game starts out not too hard but after a while it becomes SUPER easy unless you fight villainous enemies, super buffed versions of previous enemies, and even then you'll be strong enough to whoop them in the post-game when you doubtlessly have many levels under your belt, a bunch of powerful abilities, and you maybe learn how OP surge mode is. The game still has alot of charm and love for the source material but it might not maintain long-term interest from people who demand deeper combat unless they're already fans.

For a game that's saying all sorts of things about an open world and free roam, there sure isn't much open world and free roam stuff going on.
Basically you can fly around and recreate all the thrills of Superman 64, beat up on some random encounters that can't hold a candle to you, gather materials for no real reason, or go to the next story mission. And if you get to the story missions, that's where the gameplay actually stops! Get ready for two hours of cutscenes in between like two or three fights. They give you a skip, but even with that option it takes forever to get control back.

The only people I can recommend this game to are the people who want to watch Dragon Ball Z, but have never seen a single minute of it. Because it's all here! Believe you me, there is nothing that's been cut out. There's even some extra stuff thrown in to waste my time! I made it to the Namek Saga and I'm dreading the Frieza fight. His five minutes are going to be up by the time I'm in a retirement home. And speaking of! I love how the game is called Kakarot, Goku is PROMINENTLY featured, and so far I've spent the entire game as Gohan. Thanks guys! Great idea to base a game around a character that spends 90% of his time either in the ICU or straight up dead. Brilliant.

I don't know about others, but I rather enjoy "reliving" the stories. The game play overall kind of sucks, but in my opinion in comparison to let's say "Dragon ball Xenoverse" it was a much better replay of the story line. It has a similar look and feel to Xenoverse but the story lines were super hashed out and I absolutely loved the parts I have plays so far. Xenoverse would be on par with this, but what they lack is a proper chat function. So I would place this game much much higher on the enjoyment scale than the other one because of that simple fact. This game focuses on the story line aspect, and that is how they delivered. It is a little difficult to get use to the advancement processes, but I found out that you can power up your community with your gifts much later. Like in the android saga later. The levels are based on story line, so it is actually better to advance the story line than to grind, and I like that aspect. In other words, I love the fact that if I wanted to I can just play right through the story in real time.. And "CHOOSE" to fight when I want to hunt for battles. I don't like to be forced into them. If you are a lore fanatic you should love the game.

Positives:
+ Free-roaming is a serine experience and puts you in a trance like how swinging in Spider-Man does
+ Visuals are really good and faithful to the source material
+ Combat is super fast and fun
+ Trunks DLC is awesome and a really cool "what-if" kind of thing
+ Fully animated cinematics look absolutely stunning
+ DBZ encyclopedia is really fun to flip through and read

Negatives:
- Fully animated cinematics are few and far in-between, usually only reserved for the biggest scenes of the series. There are a lot of static cutscenes of characters just standing still and barely moving
- Why are there so many moments with no voice acting and only text blurbs?
- Random story omissions or changes are really weird and dumb
- No blood
- No English soundtrack. Japanese soundtrack is inferior and some of the best scenes are neutered due to the bad music. There were mods to change the music, but those mods no longer work after recent patches
- Can't transform in free roam, no alternate costumes
- No engaging side quests and content outside of the main storyline

Overall:
I am the absolute biggest Dragon Ball Z fanatic, but this is one of the most disappointing games I've experienced. Legacy of Goku 2 and Buu's Fury were two of my favorite games from my childhood, and I always dreamt of a console version and this is essentially that. A good game, but not as good as Legacy of Goku 2 or Buu's Fury. If this game is on a deep sale, go and grab it but nowhere near full price.

Like, you'll be fighting the NPC baddies for like 2k experence and then watch a cutscene and get 25k, followed by a story battle and gain another 20k. It's only worth it for the Orbs which are used to unlock moves (and unlock their powered up forms)

There are also mods for it. I personally got a Bruce Falconer mod. It's a little wonky because there are only so many tracks in the game and the game reuses tracks so sometimes the music is off for the situation, but if you don't mod then you don't need to worry about it.

Overall, "Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot" is a must-play for fans of the series, or for anyone looking for a solid action-RPG.

Dragonball Z Kakarot is an amazing game that succeeds in capturing the spirit and energy of the beloved anime series. The story follows the beloved characters of the show, and the game takes you through an interactive version of the entire series. The battle system is dynamic, and allows for a wide variety of combat styles, giving the game an arcade-like feel. The visuals are stunning, and the characters and environments look just like they do in the show. The voice acting is top-notch, and the soundtrack is phenomenal. The game also offers a wide range of side-quests to keep you entertained. All in all, Dragonball Z Kakarot is an excellent game that will keep fans of the series coming back for more.

Fun if you want to relive the tv show in game form. It's got the classic DBZ combat that is satisfying and easy to learn. 

The locations and characters are designed with care and attention to detail. The cinematic's are hit or miss with most of them being stationary talking blobs. Most of the time the character talking will have their back facing the camera so you can't see their lips moving. It's a cost cutting measure for when you translate it to 20 different languages. The game goes from feeling like a really high budget title to the lowest from one scene to the next. All side quests are missing voice acting but all the main missions have the voice acting right from the show.

It has an encyclopedia with information on just about anything you could want to know and even some lesser known facts about the show. If you wanna geek out about DBZ characters then this game has you covered.

For those that want what is the best adaptation of the DBZ show in game form then this is the only option. It's still being developed and added too, which is nice that they didn't just move onto another entry when this game is fine to use.

One of my favorite games of all time. 

A must play for any Dragon Ball fan, especially on PC since the game really shines with the inclusion of mods which increase the difficulty, clear up the HUD, and modify the soundtrack to reflect that of the US Funimation broadcast.

The fights are dynamic, cinematic, engaging and very stylish. The action can be very fast especially in group fights and you need to rely on instincts and fast reflexes to dodge attacks while also managing your energy meters. I recommend using a mod to increase the difficulty and to avoid using health items mid combat if you want to get the most out of it. Every fight can be cinematic and memorable if you go in under leveled and vary your moves. There are also various characters to play as and a variety of different enemy types with their own unique fighting styles and moves.

The story is massive, covers pretty much the whole manga while expanding on many characters and events through side missions. The world also changes throughout the story and NPCs change locations and dialogues, commenting on different events, to give a sense of the passage of time. The graphics are also true to the show and make the world come alive.
Hard sometimes, but fun.

I'm just another angry voice in the crowd at this point, but I also feel cheated on this so I want to share my opinion on the game.  The base game itself was fun and worth $60 on release, but all the DLC that came after were not.  I paid $104 for my Ultimate edition preorder here in the Eastern US and that only included the first season pass.  The second season pass has been released at $40, the cost the game itself was raised from $40 back to $60 here in the US, and reading comments on steam news posts it's even worse in other countries. 
Beyond the greed of the company there is also just pure laziness or spite for PC players as we haven't received any news on a next gen patch that console players already got.  So not only do you have to pay more now to buy the game on PC, but you are actually buying an inferior version compared to the console versions.
I wanted to restate at the end that the game itself was fun when it released, but dropping a new $40 DLC and jacking the price of the game up 3-4 years later for no reason is just plain greedy.

I liked this game a lot! it was quite fun. I was disappointed by a few things, but lets discuss what I liked first. 

-I loved the sub stories for the most part, some I wish were expanded upon because they were quite amusing.
-I loved the progression and how it felt throughout the game.
-the fighting was fluid, fun and easy to grasp, with challenging moments due to ememies ganging up, and/or using super moves that potentially worked well together.
-I like that they went up to [spoilers] the buu arc [/spoilers] so that they could elaborate upon each arc and not overwhelm themselves with too much.

Now some things i didn't like.
-vehicles, I don't know why, but everytime vehicles are put into a dragon ball game, I have not enjoyed it, but with this specific two vehicles, the walker and the car, it felt shoehorned in and like they didn't really think through how to make the challenges with them more fun, I would probably have it so you race on circuits with people, using different attackes depending on the player you are playing as to slow down or break the other vehicles.
-There isn't a satisfying new game plus in this game or any of it's dlcs. you are just able to go back as your characters who were in the saga (which makes lots of sense) but without any late game abilities barring [spoilers] super saiyan god and super saiyan god super saiyan if you have the corresponding dlcs [/spoilers] but like, why can't i use my ultimate special beam cannon with piccolo? that kind of thing makes the game fun by giving you the ability to be overpowered after you've beaten its challenges
-the original z fighters are not able to be played, which is fine, but they are really hard to make into worth while support characters.
-i would say bardock alone against fate, and trunks warrior of hope are the only real worth while dlcs for their story, the plot for the others so far are sparse, though the transformations are nice.

I love dragon ball games. ever since I was a kid and this game although was a nice little stamp for people the game does not feel alive to me, the open world felt bland and I don't really count it open world with it being sections of big areas. battles boiled down to just simple use a super move till it, hits. The cutscenes were great but that's as far as I'll go with it. It stopped being enjoyable after sayian arc and side quest felt pointless and stupid. I never felt character growth of any such here. any grinding felt pointless with them giving enough experience to just move on with the story. And the bloody dlc- holy crap what a way to ruin it for anyone who bought the season pass. the first dlc was a waste. you just grind levels and can fast track yourself to get super sayian if you do it before the main story. the 2nd one was more grinding so you can waste time to level up everyone so they have some use during the main event. They give something new with a whole area filled with enemy's and new supers but it still does not feel anywhere near enough to make it feel new and refreshing after the main story. the freiza fight was nice and a step up. Trunks dlc was the best out of anything we've gotten so far. the characters had amazing fights and the cutscenes were top of the line. it really felt like the world had gone to hell and a threat was waiting for its chance to hit, and it even went a little farther with it then the original episode of trunks. It was awesome! 

But uh- That's where season pass 1 ends. anyone who paid for ultimate edition gets jack past that. and they have the balls to charge $30 for season pass 2 or if you want $20 for the next episode- Nah screw you guys. its $10 at best with only 2-3 hours of content.  

Get the game and dlc on a good sale or off a key site.

ORIGINAL POST Posted: 20 Feb, 2020 @ 2:15pm: 

If you didn't like the show, or the many games that came before this one, you probably won't like this one. Shocker. 

If you DO like the show, and you DID enjoy the games that came before this one, you'll probably love this game and continue to play even after you beat the story. There's a lot to do, and it's a really fun open-world experience. Unlike the majority of the other Dragon Ball RPGs out there, it's a refreshing take on the Dragon Ball Universe. 

Complaints:
- you can't openly play as fusion characters; just 1 or 2 battles and that's it. 
- they miss some important moments in the series (e.g. Vegeta Final Flash, Trunks Vs. Cell, Battle Inside Majin Buu, etc)
- no co-op or multiplayer
- no difficulty settings


Here's to hoping they delve into the Dragon Ball Super territory with future DLCs. 
Or, at least give us some of the movies (Fusion Reborn, LSS Broly, etc) 


Anyway, good game for any Dragon Ball fan. Would recommend ONLY if you enjoy the series.

drag balls

Kakarot is a difficult game to judge on a thumbs up, thumbs down basis.
I'd give it about a 3.7/5.
On one hand, it's probably the most pure and vivid versions of the story for any DBZ game ever, on the other hand, the game seems very bland after 21 hours. It feels like the developers just wanted to make another game retelling the same old tired story with an open world aspect and didn't want to take any real risks with gameplay. The game feels way too easy even on hard mode and restricting myself from healing items. The most fun part of the game is going into battle way underleveled WHEN YOU CAN, because the whole game is artificially level scaled, giving the player massive amounts of XP for simply progressing the story, making hours of battling small enemies entirely pointless.
Combat is fun at first but gets repetitive. The open world falls into the same issues that big open world games have these days. I appreciate the big open world, but there's NOTHING TO DO. All of the side quests are fetch quests or insta-battles. 
I really wish next time they come out with a game like this, the devs put in something really creative, unpredictable, and well...risky. To change things up.

[h1][b][u]OH MOST DEFINITELY YES! SUPER! SAIYAN! GREATNESS!!![/u][/b][/h1]

Literally one of the very best Dragon Ball games I have ever played, outside of the Budokai Tenkaichi series. Trust me I have legally bought and played along with beat almost literally every last Dragon Ball series game available in English, even on consoles, and mobile. I can rattle on for ages about all the other games in the series, however Let's get into some more detail why don't we?

[h1]The following list are the absolute pros of this amazing RPG game![/h1]

[list]
     [*] The leveling system is very in depth, it gives a nice sense of challenge without being too overwhelming.
     [*] Free roam is very immersive! Flying, along with being able to run, and use acrobatics!
     [*] Absolutely amazing storyline that follows the manga and shows almost to a T!
     [*] The battles are decently advanced, but without feeling too arcadelike.
     [*] So many fun and quirky side quests to do!
     [*] Minigames!
     [*] DLCs!
[/list]
This game is just a punch of pure nostalgia, excelent gameplay and a great soundtrack, if you are a true DBZ Fan this is a must buy for your library

In all honesty no I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone. As much as its the only game we will ever get to a free roam dragon ball game. Its still lacking in a great many areas. The rpg system should have never been a thing outside of making power level matter. There are many memories or scenes that are not in the game like the final flash on perfect cell and many others. Cant play as all characters outside of modding the game. It would be great to play as krillin or other characters to level them up on there own over a party dynamic. You cant chose costumes or let alone make your own for the characters but that's a discussion for another time. But above all the game really isn't fun an is kinda tedious at best. Its obvious that a dark soul designed was used as the base where you have to dodge damn near everything only to get a couple hits and whittle down the enemies health which as i said isn't fun an is used to pad the run time for hours which still again isn't fun. The budakai series is a lot more fun than this game.

There is no doubt about it that some optimizations are possible (repetitive fights versus the same opponents while roaming around) and some other minor things, however overall, for a Dragon Ball Fan, the game is fantastic! 10/10

Amazing. How do you do it Kakarot? You've always been like this; ever since the day I first met you. Always ready to meet the next challenge, even if its bigger than you are. It was the same on Namek. You had improved so much that it made Recoome look like he was standing still. Your power had increased so dramatically since our battle on Earth that I thought you had done it. I thought that you had become a Super Saiyan. It tore me apart. How could a low class soldier accomplish so easily what I, I had struggled my whole life to achieve. After three millennia, it has finally happened. A new Super Saiyan has emerged. And somehow, I had become this pompous witness. Then at last it happened, I too transformed. After living every moment of every day for the singular purpose of surpassing you, I finally became a Super Saiyan myself. The prince had reclaimed his throne and fulfilled his destiny. But no matter how strong I became, your power still exceeded mine. At first I thought it was your loved ones and it was your instinct to protect them that spurred you on and pushed you beyond your limits. But then I found myself with a family of my own, and my power didn't increase at all. I used to fight for the sheer pleasure of it; for the thrill of the hunt, while I had the strength unmeasurable. I spared no one. And yet, you showed mercy to everyone. Even your fiercest enemies. Even me. Yet you never fought to kill, or for revenge; only to test your limits, and to push yourself beyond them. To be become the strongest you could possibly be. How can a Saiyan fight like that and at the same time be so gentle that he wouldn't hurt a fly. Oh, it makes me angry just thinking about it. But, perhaps it is my anger that's made me blind to the truth for so long. I see it now, this day has made it all too clear. You're better than me, Kakarot. You are the best.

The only cons at all i could think of about this game is the repetitiveness of the combat, however you only notice it after a couple few hours when you finally understand and get good at the combat only then do you realize that it only takes one good combo then a ki blast then repeat to beat everyone in the game sadly but other than that very good!

I love Dragon Ball Z I truly enjoyed the open world aspect in being able to explore the world but they had that 6 years ago. the story line is slow and boring, there is no immersion because of how annoyingly slow it is. the combat is the worst, I'm not sure how they can make it this bad when they have a blueprint on how to make their games at this point. they put in this dumb mechanic to prevent boring players from whaling on the bosses without worry forcing everyone else to fight in a boring manner to counter it. they have the ability to attack through your attacks (which you cannot do) they have the ability to charge their attack and be invincible (you can attack but can't stop) they want you to sit and dodge but the go red every 2 seconds at times so the fights are just you constantly dodging which is more boring than just whaling on them. it would be different if it didn't happen as often or that you could reliably counter it but the game is so bad that even when dodging you can still get hit. can I continue to play the game in a boring way and beat it? sure but I'm not paying for a game to be boring

DRAGON BALL Z: KAKAROT is an amazing video game that will appeal to all fans of the popular manga and anime franchise. The game features an engaging story that follows the main character, Goku, and his friends as they fight to protect the Earth against powerful enemies.

The gameplay is smooth and the fights are intense and enjoyable. The graphics are beautiful and the characters are faithfully represented. The soundtrack is also high quality and adds a level of immersion to the game.

In addition to the main story, there are many exciting side quests to complete and bonus characters to unlock. The multiplayer mode is also fun and allows players to compete online.

In summary, DRAGON BALL Z: KAKAROT is a fantastic fighting game that will appeal to all fans of the franchise and even those who are not familiar with it. If you are looking for a fun and immersive game, it is an excellent choice.

I've never really been a strong fan on the Dragon Ball Z series, but DBZ Kakarot convinced me to retread into it. This isn't just a "point A to point B" retelling of the story though, as you now have sidequests and even some surprising fanservice here and there (for example, seeing Launch again after her sudden disappearance in the manga).

The presentation is what really pulled me in though, after seeing those bland cutscenes in Budokai Tenkaichi where characters just stare at each other with dialogue, it blew my mind finally seeing scenes being properly recreated to give a cinematic feel before and after a fight.

Gameplay-wise, the game will feel very familiar to those that played previous console DBZ games, it can be a bit button mashy, but you still have those special moves at your disposal that require button combination, and your characters level up all while gathering ingredients to eat foods that boost your stats.

So is Dragon Ball Z Kakarot THE definitive video game of the franchise? That's up to you to decide, but I enjoyed every moment of it, even playing the DLC.

This is a experience that any DB fan needs to try. The animations in the cinematics are very clean, the in-game cinematics are also pretty good. Obviosuly, if you have seen DBZ, you may find this repeating, given that this game is set from the Saiyan Saga going all the way through the Frieza Saga, Cell Saga, and finally ending in the Buu Saga. It has a lot of replayability, many substories that show the love of Dragon Ball that was put in them, showing many different instances that reward the biggest DBZ and original DB fans. The controls are simple to understand, and making a dodge is rewarding. If you get it with the DLCs, it adds a lot more of replayability, showing fragments that are almost coming out the Frieza's Resurrection movie, also the Future Trunks Arc. One of the downsides, in my opinion was the collection of D-Medals. There are 30, 40 all around the different zones. Some of them are sometimes really hard to find, me needing a guide to find some of the ones that I had missing. There is a NPC in every zone that sells the locations of Fishing spots, Mineral's locations, and I don't know why they didn't add an option to buy the actual locations of the D-Medals to show on the map, which would have been a very appreciated feature. Also, the modding community is incredible, adding different suits, modes, etc. The world exploring rewards the players with rare items, fossils or gifts or minerals. The Minerals and fossils can be sold in order to get a good amount of Zeni to then buy healing items or cooking items that help to make meals that have different effects on the party. The gifts are used in the Community's tab, which adds even more effects that occur when "connecting" different characters badges that you get throughout the story and side-missions, giving to make a lot of different interactions and combinations that in-game, make sense. The collecting of the actual Dragon Ball is pretty good, and very different from other games like Xenoverse 2. Here, the Dragon Ball when found, are used to unlock different items, and sub-stories, and after this, they re-spread into the world, not being able to search them again until 20 irl minutes pass, also the locations are totally random, and change in each zone, not landing always on the same place. There is no in-game 100% reward, which I think is pretty weird for a game of this caliber, however, having all the achievements of the game feels good, like in any game. My final words...

"An action anime-RPG that rewards players for the knowledge of the series, and makes non-fans learn the story of one of the best animes ever, while mantaining an entertaining experience"

When Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot is at its best, it‚Äôs incredible. The big moments of each saga are brought to life impeccably with beautiful visuals and effects ‚Äì but more than that, Kakarot also shows love to the smaller, more character driven moments that made fans fall in love with the anime in the first place. As a result, Kakarot is a wonderful way to revisit the story of Dragon Ball Z, whether you‚Äôre a fan or looking to jump in for the first time. However, while it‚Äôs backed by extremely solid combat, it also comes with major drawbacks like poorly implemented RPG mechanics, a general lack of polish, and some disappointingly shallow and repetitive sidequests.

BAD: The issues are largely with all the resource gathering, side tasks and side quests. Its not that theyre in the game, it is an RPG after all.. Its that they are mundane, repetitive and often time consuming. The side tasks are largely blowing things up in free roam and more fighting. The side quests stories can be nice, but alongside them is more fighting or gathering resources. The side quests also do not have voice acting, and the game just really did not make these things fun. I tried to play this game as an RPG, and I wish I had not.

GOOD: I came in uninitiated to DBZ and the DB universe in general. I LOVED learning the story of DBZ and Frieza, Piccolo, Vegeta and all the others my friends had referenced for so long. The animation and overall feel of the game visually was great. I enjoyed some of the battle cut scenes in particular, though the standard cut scenes were all mostly well done. Some people might find the amount of story telling the game does as a bad thing, I did not. The world looked nice and was fun to fly around in too. The storytelling was probably the games biggest strength overall. 

TL;DR I am glad I played it, but it is definitely flawed. 6/10.

I'll start with the Cons since that's a much shorter list:

- The thought of giving Chris Sabat or Monia Rial even residuals off this makes me sick (that's a personal con, not a game flaw)
- The flight controls are abysmal and counter-intuitive. At times it gets close to Superman 64 levels of bad. That's barely hyperbole.
- The frequent overuse of dialogue when being sensed for battle or gathering materials (particularly the latter) can be grating
- There's a wild difference between about 5 levels below a group of mobs versus 5 levels below a boss. The latter will almost always result in death especially when fighting the Villainous Zones.

That's it. That's literally all the flaws I can find. Anything else boils down to learning the game itself and getting good.

The pros:

- The art direction is wonderful and the story follows the Z series faithfully
- The humor is great and the characters are portrayed as you'd expect
- It's the first (non FGC) Dragonball game I've played where I actually felt like I was playing not only these specific characters but they felt distinct enough from one another
- Different builds are viable (Go with physical Piccolo, trust me, it's nuts)
- There's a healthy amount of side quests and time for exploration
- The Community Board is engaging and something you want to fill, mix-and-match emblems without it resorting to tedium
- Hard mode is appropriately challenging without being the "Dark Souls of Action RPGs"


I have played only a handful of truly perfect games in my life. Hades, Witcher 3, Final Fantasy X International come to mind. Both 10/10. So I don't give out 10s or 9s easily, and I won't do so here either. But when I say it's a solid 8 and worth the price, I mean it. Even if you're not a Dragonball fan, it's a 7 easily.

Has gotten dull quickly. The game mixes itself between being an incredibly open-world to trapping you in a tiny area... The difficulty also spikes and falls off often. I really think a lot of the ideas on their own are great! Bringing back many Dragon Ball characters into a game reliving the Z storyline is great too. But the overall execution has been somewhat lackluster even by grindy JRPG standards. Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot is simply a game you want to love if you are fan of the series... but sadly that is all it is...

If you are a fan of Dragonball Z, it scratches the itch for a good Dragonball Z game. While I do like this game, I don't think it is for everyone. 

Pros:
-Playing as many of the Dragonball Z characters.
-Follows the story pretty faithfully and lets you interact with some of the lesser known characters in the story.
-Controls are not too complicated and it's satisfying executing the moves.
-Lots of side missions.

Cons:
-Can only play as the top tier characters such as Goku, Vegeta, Trunks, Gohan, and Piccolo. The other characters can be part of your team but they are regulated to support characters. 
-A bit of a grind when trying to level up at times unless you like doing all the side stories and just flying around collecting Z Orbs to unlock parts of your talent tree for each character.
-Some of the weaker characters (Tien, Yamcha, Krillin) are only support characters, which means you can't directly play as them. Their move sets are also less. Feels like there are some moves missing. This is the main negative for me since I would like to go back through the game and play as someone other than the main characters.
-The fighting mechanic requires a lot of dodging so sometimes it feels like you are just spamming dodges.
-No way to customize what the characters wear.

Other thoughts:
-I would recommend the season pass since the additional games are fun to play and let you unlock Super's level ups.
-I played using a controller and I found I liked playing with it better.
-The game follows the story so there are times you can not change characters. While this could be viewed as a bad thing, this game is about following the story so I didn't list it as something bad.
-There is a lot to the game so definitely look through the menu screen.

[/th][/tr][/table]


[i]This review is based ONLY on performance of the game on the STEAM DECK.[/i]


[h1]The Game Itself:[/h1]


It is time to experience Dragon Ball Z like never before! Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot is an open-world action RPG where you will fish, eat, train, fly, and battle your way through 3 different story arcs in intense cinematic matches. Level up your heroes so you can rise to the challenges you will come across throughout your travels and deepen the bonds with other heroes in the DBZ universe to push your limits even more. And with loads of side quests telling new-never-before seen stories, what more could you ask for?


[h1]Steam Deck Performance:[/h1]


Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot is rated Unsupported on Steam and I have to disagree with the rating. Kakarot runs right out of the box on the stable Proton branch and with a couple of tweaking, it feels almost like it was made specifically for this device. I did play primarily using Proton GE 7-42, but it should work perfectly fine on the stable branch.

I played around a bit with the framerate and felt the smooth 50 was the best. It did come with some higher battery drain, but moving around and battles just felt like significantly better than lower FPS. To help with stability, I did bring the Internal Rendering Resolution to 95 instead of 100. This helped just enough to keep most actions at around 50. I did notice some small drops to 48 when flying fast in open areas and drops to 30 when either in a cutscene or a boss was prepping for an ultimate attack, but this dissipated quickly too.

Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot hasn't really had any other issues that I have noticed so far. Other than some very minor areas where framerate can dip, the game holds strong and sticks under a 16W battery for around 3 - 3.5 hours of battery on a full charge. Don't let that Unsupported rating fool you, Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot not only works on Deck, but this is by far the best way to play!

In-game photos and the settings I used are on our website!

after playing this game a couple times I can say for sure, it's not that great. The sad thing is, they have everything there but ONE thing and that one thing makes it so uninteresting to play. The difficulty. There is none. I ALWAYS play this game on hard and each time I check to make sure it is actually selected. It is seriously that bad. Now I am okay at videogames so this for me completely kills any momentum and leaves me feeling a bit empty. Now I know some copers will think this is a good thing, saying difficulty is the devil or something but even those kinds of people would agree that the "easy" difficulty is like a 1v1 duel with a toddler. Visually, sound wise, this game is unparalleled when it comes to dragonball games. Some situations do have those really awful read the text dialogue but luckily unlike Xenoverse they are not generally in the story besides tutorials. Seriously those kinds of "cutscenes" are a peeve of mine. Haven't played the Trunks DLC yet, and have only heard good things so I will update this review at a later date.

TL;DR Game is way too easy, wait for a sale and consider installing some mods. I do recommend as the game is very beautiful with some of the best cutscenes from any dragonball game

EDIT: The Trunks DLC is incredible, fixes most issues, don't have millions of zeni to buy very spammable healing items, actually had to grind out the bosses

I'm on the fence about whether to recommend this game. There's good arguments to be made on both sides of it. I'll start with the pros:

1) the main storyline is fun, major boss fights (especially against Vegeta, Frieza, and Cell) are challenging but fair; it was a major problem in previous dragonball games (e.g. the Budokai Tenkaichi series) that fights against characters who are supposed to be stronger than you were just as much curbstomps as fights against literal whos, and some games overcorrected this issue with fights that were just blatantly unfair. The major fights (more on this qualifier later) feel a lot better than in previous games I've played.
2) Dragonballs actually playing a role in the game. You can collect them and wish back minor antagonists.
3) Some (again, more on that later) sidequests are fun and tie-ins with other parts of the franchise that aren't major parts of the timeframe of DBZ make fans like me happy.

But onto the cons:

1) Some of the less story-important fights were poorly playtested and unbalanced. Especially Dodoria (as Vegeta) and the Android 20 fight. Characters which, in theory, should be weaker than the player character, become brutal to fight because of repetitive and broken movesets. It isn't satisfying to spend half the fight dodging Dr Gero's energy absorption or watch him regen his entire health bar after you've gotten him down to half of his health and it isn't fun fighting him on repeat for an hour.
2) The game is not content to stay in its lane. I don't know who playtested this game and decided "we need to have fifty different minor enemy encounters that respawn on each map so you can't move around freely, and these enemies will scale with you so it will always be tedious to fight them, and damage you take in these fights will impact fights in the story too." The thing I dread most in this game is just moving around because I don't want to waste a minute fighting aggro'd saibamen and Red Ribbon Army robots.
3) A lot of the sidequests are fetch quests, some of these don't even tell you where to find what you need, you just have to hope the spawning algorithm puts them in a place you'd look. Some sidequests are also bugged and inaccessible.
Solid open world game, great for any fan of the series.

As a DB/DBZ fan since the beginning I have not played any of the other DB games on steam as they are all fighting style games for the most part. What makes this so good is it having a more open world/RPG feel to it. The story is awesome of course because its basically DBZ story line so if you have not watched it in years than you can play it instead of rewatching! The gameplay is fluid but fights can be a bit repetitive but not too badly? Graphics are appealing and not many bugs at all.

This game is great. The story was a huge nostalgia trip for me as this covers the entire DBZ Story line and the DLC covers some of Super/ the movies. Loved this and it's the first game on Steam I've ever 100%-ed. Was a great game and it's worth any price. I bought it on sale for like $20 and would have paid full price. If you like DBZ even a little this is more than worth your time.

Edit: Should also mention, I played this entirely on the Steam Deck. It says unsupported and I believe that is because it lacks the Cloud Save option. Everything played perfect and I had zero gameplay issues at all. Battery life was pretty solid as well with a solid 4-5 hours of play time.

I'd recommend this game to anyone who is fan of DBZ.

The reason this game interested me was because many years ago on the Game Boy Advanced they had "The Legacy Of Goku II" and that game was one of the only RPG DBZ games around(Atleast the only good one).

This game has a lot in common with that game so if you were looking for a more modern take on it then look no further.

The fighting is pretty decent and it feels good progressing your characters skills.

The cutscenes in this game are glorious. Sometimes even beating the actual anime itself.

The aspects I didn't like are the amount of Orbs and medals you need in order to unlock skills. Orbs are actually not a huge problem but D medals are going to start holding you back from learning your skills. Its not a huge problem but it definitely became annoying to have to try search for D medals in the world in order to train and learn new skills.

The two Dragon Ball Super DLCs are not that great but the latest Trunks DLC is excellent. That Trunks DLC has a lot of heart and emotion put into it so its a great addition to the game.

Overall its a fun game to play through.
n
The game that every DBZ fan needs.

It is the premier experience for playing the Dragon Ball Z story in its entirety. 
It cuts corners in some cases narratively from the original anime so as far as story beats goes it's a little more like DBZ Kai. It has loads of easter eggs from both Z and the original Dragon Ball and a lot of the side stories are cute filler that have tongue in cheek references to memes and the overall fandom. The game looks beautiful and is a very accurate representation of the source material visually. The soundtrack sometimes gets a bit repetitive with what tracks you keep hearing and some of the tracks are not to my liking after hearing them as often as you do. The game-play is varied in quality I'd say. The combat system has a little bit of a learning curve and you don't feel like you've mastered it until a little ways into the game, not the most intuitive. But once you have mastered it you do begin to enjoy the fights but then hits a period where it starts to feel stale because you've sort of learned all you can and even if you haven't most of your attacks and abilities are just buffed up versions of what you already knew. So fighting is hit and miss. World exploring and the overall map you can traverse is fun to be in and visually stimulating but after awhile you begin to realize that outside the sub stories there isn't a ton to do in these maps. The world feels lived in especially in cities and towns but none of them offer anything different other than it's location. There's items to find that can do various things for you but again it starts to feel like a chore to go and get them. Besides walking and flying you have other modes of transport which is neat but not necessary since both running and flying is quicker. While the game is called Kakarot you do get to navigate through the game at key moments as other characters, however if you're hoping to play as your favorite side characters than you are out of luck. It is only a handful of people you can play as and the rest are either NPC's or assist characters.

Overall I recommend this game to people who would like to relive the story of DBZ again in an interactive form and especially die hard fans of the franchise but also I would say it is a good way to get to know DBZ if you are unfamiliar with it and don't wanna watch the anime or read the manga. However if you don't enjoy DBZ already and don't have an interest to get into it based on what you already know, I don't think this will win you over. If you're just looking for an action/adventure/RPG I'd say maybe look elsewhere.

One of the best game adaptation of the DBZ franchise. I still remember when games like Tenkaichi Budokai came out and all I was looking for was an accurate adaptation of the anime story into the game. All Ps2 era games were great, the peak of all dragon ball games history, but story wise they always missed something. That something is not missing here on DBZ Kakarot. You never experienced the whole anime yourself? You can just play the game and grasp all the important aspects (with a bit of fillers also) without watching the series. It covers basically every bit of story the whole anime has to offer. Something is still missing here and there (like Goku's endless snake way run before arriving to King Kai's planet) but it's not a big deal to be honest.

Gameplay is ok, I still prefer the Xenoverse style, Kakarot is more centered on boss-like battles where sometimes you just have to dodge an infinite series of enemy attacks, but after you get used to it and learn that the game is just structured this way, you'll make the habit out of it

Music is 10/10, starting from the intro that is basically a remake of the original japanese anime opening (obviously with cha la ed cha la) and a couple of battle themes are taken from the original anime (the japanese version, of course)

Graphics is one of the best I've seen in a db game, much much better than Xenoverse 2 and surprisingly very similar to the anime-like vibes that fighter z have done until now.

9 out of 10, really suggested and a must for a DB fan.

Dragon Ball games finally try and break the mold a bit by providing a brand-new RPG for fans of the franchise to enjoy! Kakarot puts you in the shoes of none other than Son Goku once more to do the tried-and-true Saiyan, Frieza, Cell, Buu arcs again. But this time, it's in the format of an open-world, and there's plenty of leveling and stat allocation in order to hone the Z-FIghters' skills to your exact specifications!

Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot really makes you FEEL like Spider-Ma- Goku, I mean. For real though, it does a good job of giving you a little more insight into the Dragon Ball world, as you can freely explore several maps from the series, and there's dozens of side missions strewn about the world that you can take on as you do the main story that we've all come to love. This game makes it really fun to just fly around and explore the world, looking for items and sidequests, and I don't think it suffers from the issue of collecting tons of different little baubles and trinkets to waste your time.

The combat isn't incredible or innovative by any means- you're going to be performing easy melee combos and breaking it up with big energy blasts and super moves just like every other 3D Dragon Ball fighting game. That's not to say it's not fun; I love blasting baddies and beating bitties as much as the next guy, but if you were strictly looking for some deeper combat, this is not gonna quite scratch that itch for you.

I can confidently say this is the most immersed I've ever been in a Dragon Ball game! It's got so many small side characters from the series that the show seemed to have forgotten about, and is chock-full of references to both Z and the original Dragon Ball, which helps make it seem like one continuous story instead of these chopped-up little episodes. It's awesome seeing so many of Goku's friends brought back!

Any Dragon Ball Z fan will love this- it's graphically impressive, it's nostalgic without being gimmicky, and it's just good, dumb, DBZ fun!

DBZ: Kakarot is good example of a good ocncept with average execution. It is, at its core, a fun game that uses the DBZ universe fairly well. It follows the main plot arcs and adds in a lot of fighting sequences to add the gameplay loop. However, it does miss out on some of the story elements. The game makes more sense if you already know the series well, but it does mostly gloss over the story, losing virtually all emotional impact and awesome moments that the series otherwise had.

Gameplay is quite repetitive once you understand how basic combat works and doesn't scale up in challenge as the game goes on. If anything, the early game is harder as more effort is put into making the boss fights unique, but later boss fights devolve into spamming vanish and switching up melee attacks. The end game comes down to a grind, though fortunately you don't have to do much outside of the core story to finish the game.

It is overall a fun game, but there are many missed opportunities that would've made the game far more engaging as a DBZ game. It does have creative fun with the characters and it's a very good DBZ game, but it's method of telling the story is a bland version of what you watch.

I am very sorry to say that this game is simply not good.
I'm 18 hours in and most of it felt like a filler episode of the show.
dialogue is slow, even when frenetically pressing the skip button. Animations in cut scenes are stiff. Quests in the game feel like they are either pure grind (at least it can be done quick most of the time) or a fetch quest that involves multiple loading screens.
The fights are flashy, but outside the 'big ones' (notable story fights and those for some bigger upgrades) they are insultingly easy on normal difficulty. Even the harder fights are not really fun. Raditz an Vegeta where fine, but after those you start to discover/unlock new abilities that make the whole thing extremely repetitive (if you want to be efficient).
Enemy variety is not that high actually. Some robots that look slightly different but all do the same. Saibamen in various colors. Frieza force soldiers in varieing shapes (I honestly don't know if they behave differently, they die to fast to notice, the fade into the fight sometimes takes longer then the actual fighting). That's it for the goons to this point. For the big bads: They are all here, that's a plus. Until you fight Raditz, Nappa and Vegeta for the fifth time as part of some upgrade. And at this point it isn't cool anymore, it is annoying as hell to be spammed with unrelentling attacks, permanently just evading stun locks until at least one of them is down.
The maps are clustered with currency but I never actually bothered to collect any of it after the first two hours as mandatory fights and side quests cover you in the stuff.
Staying with the maps: They are nice and pick up various scenes from the show. But there is nothing really to find when you explore. Currency? You don't need it. Reccources? For what? Mostly useless upgrades? Dragonballs? They are extremely easy to find (radar + always the same spots) and even then, the wishes you can make unto this point never felt impactful.

I have no problem with the cheesy diaglogue. I bught into this when I purchased the game. Stupid motivations for side quests? Part of the appeal.
The biggest sin of the game is simply that it is repetative, slow and therefor boring for most of the time.
I'll finish it probably, but this is mostly because I already paid.
Recommended only in extremely good sales for die hard fans of the franchise.

Where to start....
I really wanted to like this game, I was a big DBZ fan growing up, and to a small extent enjoyed the Dragonball fighting games.  I was never a huge fighting game fan, and found myself saying "I wish they'd make a Dragonball RPG".

The RPG aspect of the game is very shallow and thoughtless.  Basically just buy whatever upgrade becomes available, no picking a skill tree, or deciding which skill to spend points on.  Levelling outside of the story seems pointless, as every boss battle just gives you a massive and incomparable amount of XP that just puts you where you need to be for the next boss.

The combat is absolutely awful.  It goes something like dodge, dodge, dogge, dodge, punch twice, repeat.  Most fights are bosses, and they just spam the same annoying supers over and over while you spam dodge over and over, and eventually whittle them down.  I guess you can call it an action RPG if action constitutes dodging for 95% of a fight, and hitting the punch button once or twice in between.

The "open world" which is divided into a bunch of tiny little sections, not actually a World, is empty and bland.  Once you collect the Dragon Balls a few times you realise just how pointless most of it is, and just hurry to the next checkpoint to continue the story.  

The game refuses to save my Keyboard+Mouse settings, every time I start the game I have to go into the settings.  At about 45 hours into the game it started crashing constantly in the menus.  I looked up the error UE4-AT and it seems like the game has had this issue for years, on consoles and PC alike, and they just never bothered to fix it.  Don't waste your time or money.

Not that it was the deal breaker for me, but some of the voice acting is just terrible.

Review Update: 100%'d the game, didn't get much better.  Their idea of sidequests I guess is respawning the same bosses 3 or 4 times and making you fight them again.  Combat got "better" in the sense that I could spam 1 move with Vegeta and win every fight, instead of the constant dodge 100 times then punch 3 times.  Might be worth a play if you can get it on sale for $10-20.

I want say I liked this game so bad, but there are so many problems with it that I simply cannot leave a good review. The graphics are awesome, the world is nice but the orbs are a little obnoxious for an "open world" game, plus the narrative is very driven and the side quests are very shallow and not very fun nor worth doing. I loved how the story progressed through the anime at the right pace. The biggest problem I found with this game is that every enemy has the exact same AI. When fighting a boss they literally only charge up their ki and use super attacks. This effectively makes the combat dodge, Special attack, dodge, special attack, repeat. This is very unfun gameplay and when I say every enemy I mean literally every enemy does this. The only time you will catch an enemy using a melee combo is when you are literally in their face and wait 20 seconds for them to do something. Another major problem is the gank fights, especially the one where you fight cell jr. all three of them have relatively big maximum health pools (I played on hardest difficulty), and each of them attack you and you only at all times. So you will be trying to kill one cell jr. but getting hit by 3 kamehamehas at all times, plus they all have solar flare so you just get spammed. So yes, I loved the ambiance, and the narrative that the story followed but the combat in this game is frankly inexcusable when compared to literally any other dragon ball game. I feel that it could've been so much better and I'm sad to even write this review.

IT'S DRAGON BALL Z. WHAT ELSE COULD YOU WANT!?

-Not open world.
-80% of the game is flying in 1 of 2 speeds, collecting coloured orbs in inconsequential maps (yes I did say maps, this is not open world).
-20% is pressing B repeatedly & throwing the same ki blast at bosses.
-Not an RPG. The skilltrees are entirely linear & locked to story states.
-No VA on anything not in the main story. All side missions are textboxes.
-Microtransactions upwards $120 CAD for some tacked-on card game that nobody asked for.

I'm embarrassed this is stuck in my library forever. I'd be ashamed to be in the credits of this. Sagas had more effort put into it & didn't lie to people calling itself an "open-world RPG".

I initially did not care much for the game, but now that I've returned to it on Steam Deck I'm having a lot more fun. It runs extremely well on max settings on the Deck (60 fps) and you get a decent battery life to boot (3-4 hours).

As for the game itself, it's basically what I dreamed the Legacy of Goku games would be. I loved those games as a kid, yet I always wanted a similar experience in a proper 3D open world. DBZ Kakarot aims at that, and while it definitely flounders a bit with some confusing controls and simplistic combat, it's still worth playing to experience the DBZ storyline again in a new way. The open world itself is more or less a series of hub worlds with a few side quests sprinkled here and there, item collecting, fishing, and a light crafting system to flesh out the story a bit more while traveling from plot point to plot point.

As I said, the combat is simplistic. Don't expect Fighter Z combos, or even Tenkaichi 3 duels. It's like a cross between Budokai and Xenoverse, with one-button combos and special attack commands. You basically just mash the attack button, spam the dodge button, and pepper in a few special attacks to win. It's not a challenging game at all, but still gives you enough of a DBZ feel to keep you engaged.

The graphics are very well done, and are probably the best thing about it. The cel shading is outstanding and even the details of the world itself are charming and familiar to fans. All of the cutscenes are voiced by the Funimation crew, which, while decent, you can tell that some of these VAs are tired of repeating the same lines over and over again.

It's worth getting for DBZ fans and those who are looking for an engaging open world brawler. Do not buy it at full price though, wait for a Steam sale and get it with all of the DLC.
