After completing the game itself. I kinda felt I had a bad taste in my mouth. At first when you start playing the game it seems okay. But that's just it. It's just 'okay'.  The characters constantly repeat there phrases evertime they pick-up something uncommon or remotely rare. But approaching end-game everything is pretty much rare, so they're constantly saying 'OH YEAH IT'S SO FRESH' or something within those lines. And it's either one or two lines that are exactly the same. I swear to god I literally had to mute my game because it  was annoying me so much.

I plan to make a video in further depth about why you shouldn't buy this game. Despite the game saying 'Kakarot', the game is no where close telling the story of our beloved Goku. It felt more like 'Dragon Ball Z: Gohan' because you primairly play Gohan for 70% of the game. 20% of it is either Vegeta or Piccolo. And 10% is rarely played by goku, might even be lower then that.

Second of all; I was very upset that I couldn't play any of my favorite Z Warriors from the series. It would of been nice to play as Tien when fighting Nappa, maybe play as Neil against Frieza. Hell let me play as Krillin when they first encountered Dodoria!

As a note, you can only play as 4 or 5 characters which fricken sucks. These characters are Gohan, Goku, Vegeta and Piccolo. I think at somepoint you play as Gotenks and then Vegito but it would of been nice to play one of the other Z-Warriors or at least give me the option to change them during the 'intermissions'. It doesn't even claim to be open world as it advertises. The maps feel more like 'levels' then actual open-world. You'll constantly be seeing a lot of loading screens when traversing because you'll be changing a lot of the places you go to in search for dragon balls or other.

All and all, this game is not worth your wallet. Even at a 50% discount. I would move away from this game. Even $10 for this game feels a bit much. A lot of the characters are very ugly and bland. Just look up a video of the Frieza era, you can see what I mean. They even got the voice actors wrong for the builds of the characters. (although it was a bit hilarious).

- True Dragonball Fanboy

Just a quick heads up! It's going to be a long one (shows 14 hours played, but let's be real I've had this on console since release).

----

Ah. Here we have a pretty divisive game among the hardcore fans. I suppose I can count myself among the hardcore, since I've played every single Dragon Ball game (OG, Z, whatever), and I've finished about 80% of them. If you can find it in a wiki, I've played it and probably finished it. My absolute favorite DBZ game can be found in the PC Engine, surprisingly similar to Kakarot called Dragon Ball Z: Idainaru Son Goku Densetsu.

That game has a Buu saga Gohan trying to recount the tales of his dad to Goten, who at that point hadn't met him. It goes through Goku's most significant fights up to that point, which goes from Tao Pai Pai all the way to when he gave his life in the battle against Cell. All the while, different characters such as Bulma will pop up and add their two cents about how they remembered Goku. Keep in mind that during this time, Goku seemed to be dead for real. It's a celebration of Goku and his achievements, and I loved it as a kid (even made me tear up way back when haha). While most will agree Kakarot is closest to the Legacy of Goku series on the GBA, that series was also following the spirit of the little-known PC Engine game.

At the end of the day, they're all games that seek to celebrate the life of Goku, as he is and always will be the foundation of the IP. Does this game live up to all the hype surrounding it? Well, it depends on what you were looking for. 

Many fans of DBZ are in it for all the crazy battles and iconic moments, but a large percentage are hot off the heels of Xenoverse 1 and 2, which offer a different spin on the decades-old story. Those who are looking for something new and genuinely game changing in the Dragon Ball Z universe won't find it here. Fortunately, Xenoverse 2 is STILL somehow coming up with DLC, so there's a fantastic outlet.

What about gameplay? Once again, those who come in expecting the intricacies (and craziness) found in Xenoverse or even Dragon Ball FighterZ won't find it here. The gameplay is serviceable, and can be surprisingly addicting for those who want to spend their time trying to get extremely annoying bosses into a stun state ‚Äî which unlocks fantastic animations for super attacks. You can even hit them with a blast that exits the planet if the final blow is a super beam from surge mode while transformed. That said though, the IP has many games with more complicated and intricate gameplay, such as FighterZ.

So what does Kakarot have? Well, do you remember the moment when Goku first arrives at King Kai's and jumps for joy? What about when Goku takes out Nappa with the Kaioken and holds him up with a single arm? Did you see Goku's face at that moment? It's almost like you ripped the scene out of the manga/anime and put it in the game's engine. These developers went through great lengths to develop these cutscenes. They could have just as easily used the in-game models, make them look angry/surprised/whatever and left it at that. Xenoverse certainly did, since who would be crazy enough to reanimate the face to match the source material 1:1 in regular cutscenes? Kakarot's devs did.

What about that moment when Vegeta yells at Nappa to stop when the big guy gets carried away and disobeys him? In that moment Vegeta looked like how he was originally drawn. Many will complain about how the game lacks cutscenes and polish as you go, and I absolutely will not fault them for that. However, this game goes through the Saiyan saga, to Frieza, to Cell, to Buu ‚Äî that's no easy feat. Keep in mind that what I was talking about earlier was just around one small part of the game. The devs did everything they could to replicate the soul of the series and translate it into beautiful scenes. Even the gameplay, simple as it is, tries its best to emulate the hectic style of fighting, all with a similar level of polish.

I was personally disappointed when Vegeta's final flash and Trunks' attempt to take out Perfect Cell wasn't given any attention, but the devs themselves said it pained them to pick and choose what to focus on due to time constraints. This is a game that the developers were obviously passionate about. You can FEEL their ambition in every second the game plays out. In fact, many of the issues people complained about is primarily due to them overreaching, rather than underperforming. 

Remember when the trailers first came out and we wondered if it was going to go up to the Frieza saga? They pushed so hard it went all the way to Buu, and I appreciate how hard they worked. Is it a perfect game? No, it isn't. However, did the developers succeed in what they set out to do? Absolutely. They were also testing the waters with A New Power Awakens, and decided to finally step it up a notch with Trunks' DLC story. The same passion and creativity can be felt all throughout the DLC, and now we know Bardock's coming, alongside a new season of DLC. It's a good time to be a Kakarot fan.

This is my favorite modern Dragon Ball game for all the reasons I shared above. I appreciate it because it feels like a love letter from the devs. Hell, all you'd have to do is watch the opening to get an idea of what you're getting into. The game is a celebration of Goku, hence the name, Kakarot. You won't regret buying this.

First time player of the game and of what I played of it up to this point, in which I can say that DBZ: Kakarot is "somewhat" of a fun game and I'll probably finish it to the end (mainly to give it a fair review, rather than just barely playing for a few short hours and flat out saying "it isn't that good")... I however must also say, that I find myself quite disappointed thus far, as it has not met my satisfaction of what I would consider a well made DBZ game... for reasons I'll discuss below.

First of all, for a game called Dragon Ball Z: "Kakarot", it sure feels like you spend more time playing as other characters, more than what you actually do playing as Goku (aka "Kakarot", as titled in the game's name)... seriously, you start off as Goku up to the point that you defeat Raditz, which then from there you play as other characters (Gohan, Piccolo, Vegeta) up to the point that you fight the Ginyu Force... then after defeating Captain Ginyu and Goku getting his body back, you go right back to playing as the other characters again, until Goku recovers in time to fight Frieza, in which I defeated and guess what; I once again play as the other characters, while Goku is off in space (P.S. not to sound like a Goku fan boy here, as I'm honestly just aiming to make a point).

Furthermore, aside from playing as other characters, more than what you actually do playing as Goku ("Kakarot", as the name suggest in the game's title name); that isn't the biggest downer about the game... what's far more disappointing is that, you don't get to experience Goku's "hard earned efforts" in training to become stronger (training on King Kai's Planet, before the fight with Vegeta & Nappa... training on the way to Planet Namic, before the fight with the Ginyu Force as well as with Frieza, etc)... nope... instead, when it comes to playing as Goku again, he just "magically" gains tons of Exp out of thin air (out the wazoo, etc)... his strength doesn't feel earned at all, it's like as though he just magically becomes strong enough to defeat what foe(s) he aims to fight at the time.

Another thing I noticed that doesn't make sense, is that somehow some characters have higher BP (Battle Points, aka Power Level) than other characters with higher level... I mean seriously, Gohan at level 33 has a lesser BP than some of the characters known to be weaker (aka Yamcha, Tien, etc) that is like level 9.... um.. come again?? you gotta be freaking kidding me... not that the BP actually does anything in the game anyway, as it doesn't effect characters stats (HP amount, Ki amount, Melee Attack, Melee Defense, Ki Attack, Ki Defesce)... like seriously, Vegeta & Piccolo having a high BP at this point, isn't doing a significant amount of damage to the enemies, compared  to characters that don't hardly have "half" the amount of BP of what they have.... here, take a look at this screenshot for example.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2835349028

As I recall in the Anime (and I don't think I'm mistaking), after Goku's awakening; at the point where Goku meets Cell for the very first time when saving Tien and Piccolo, he didn't fight Cell at any point during that time (matter of fact, the ONLY time that Goku fought Cell, for the first time, was during the Cell Games aka Tournament)... so why the heck did they do that in this game, where Goku fights Cell (2nd form) upon meeting him??... so lame, the creators need to go back and re-check their sources... but whatever though, that's the very least of things aside from just getting the story wrong.

I find it really annoying trying to charge up my Ki  (especially while getting spam attacked from time to time) in order to do special attacks, and yet the computer can just spam attack you with Ki energy attacks without seeming like they need to charge up Ki at all (matter of fact, the computer doesn't even have a Ki gauge, just has an HP gauge and a Stun gauge).

Let's see... anything positive to say about the game, I'd say the idea of eating food to gain additional stat points would be one, being that in the Anime or even the Manga, Goku and other characters (mainly Saiyans for sure) are known for eating like gluten's... in which case, gaining stats boost from foods in the game, actually gives you a good reason to go hunting and such for ingredients, etc. so I kinda somewhat do like that aspect of the game..... oh and the game graphics are spectacular, I'll definitely give them credit in that regard.


(To be continued, as I'm sure I'll probably find something else to mention as I progress further)...

Are you a Dragon Ball Z fan? If the answer is YES then you will probably like this. 7/10

Background: I am a DBZ fan. I discovered my love for DBZ in my young teen years and I've loved the series ever since.

All the silliness of the DBZ universe aside. This is a fun game. It's not a fighting game, it's an RPG, meaning LEVEL DOES MATTER... I played this on Hard knowing I was only going to play this through once.

The game captures the feel of the show pretty well. The battles are epic, the Ki attacks are immense and flashy. The melee combat is... ok... The game boils down to, "Melee enemy until they glow red, then back off as FAR AS YOU CAN... once enemy does move hit them with Ki ability... repeat... seriously...

The game has it's set piece moments and any DBZ fan knows what they are. Everything else is filling in the gaps between these set piece moments. There are some truly fantastic side missions that have an unbelievable amount of charm that fills out the world and the characters in surprising ways. Ways untouched by the anime....

Speaking of the anime... the games story is... different. All the important beats are there. Raditz. Saiyans. Frieza. Androids. Cell. Buu. Beyond... It's all there as expected (more or less) but the in between parts are different. Not bad, just... different. If you're a DBZ purist this game will anger you. If you're a fan who enjoys the series and accepts the good and the bad, you'll have a great time.

My score of 7/10 is mostly due to the stale nature of the gameplay. Because it's an RPG where enemies can be unblockable and unstoppable, so you run away and wait for an opening then attack.... rinse, repeat. It doesn't feel as good as some of the fighting games where the combat and attacks are more responsive. Melee abilities in this game should mostly be avoided. Far too often the enemy can interrupt your melee pursue animation and send you flying, opening you up for serious damage. There are some abilities that are useful and do high damage, but nothing that outdoes a ranked up Ki ability.

When it comes to the grind for EXP and resources. AVOID thinking that the orbs in the world are worth it. You will always get the most value for orbs by fighting enemies. If you need orbs, go to an area where you can instant finish enemies (flying right into them and auto-winning) flying around like this is... boring, but effective and is useful to gain experience and the orbs necessary to upgrade your abilities. You may not feel the need to grind orbs until you hit higher levels where each ability cots 20k+ of each orb type...

This game is a love letter to my childhood, albeit a love letter written by a stalker who only knows what I like through a random assortment of shady pictures and shreds scavenged from my garbage... but it's still sweet... in a strange.. unsettling way...

If you're not a DBZ fan but are interested. Play it on easy and breeze through the game. You'll more or less understand the story and be able to talk to your fellow nerds. 7/10

I was feeling super nostalgic for DBZ and this game had been sitting in my library for a while. I decided to give it a go. At first, I was taken by surprise at the visuals. This is, in my opinion, the best looking DBZ game out there. The cutscenes are really stunning and the attacks that story enemies perform are stunning. This game looks like how you think the anime looked when you look back on childhood memories. 

The problems starts with the quests, combat, and world. I understand the point of the game was to make it a full RPG with an expansive story and side quests, but in doing so, I feel like a very path was taken. Side quests feel boring and tedious (beat these copy and pasted enemies in this area, go fish for 10 fish in order to get some eggs for Master Roshi type deal). The combat is very button mashy. You can mash your attack button and follow it up with one of the other 3 face buttons in order to end the button mash combo in a different way. It's just not very fulfilling. I feel like this could have been improved upon by just adding a second attack button in order to string along some very basic combos. The one button attack string just isn't fun. Lastly, the open world, while expansive, gives you nothing really fun to do aside of collecting some flying orbs, and seeing the memorable cast of character running around the various areas.

I'll go ahead and cut it short by echoing what many have said before me. Visually, this game is great. If you want to turn your brain off and experience the story of DBZ in a new light, this is an amazing title. If you're looking for anything more than that (good gamplay, combat, fun) you might want to look elsewhere.

[h1] [u] My All-Time Favourite Anime gets a fitting Story-Based Video Game Entry! [/u] [/h1]

This game is fantastic! It has great game play that doesn't feel like it gets stale throughout its runtime, as well as a story that retells the story of [i]Dragon Ball Z[/i] from start to finish!

The main game starts with the Saiyan Saga and ends with the Buu Saga, retelling every story beat very faithfully when compared with the Anime! There is also lots of side content to dive into within the game including things like Side Missions, Collectables, etc.

This game currently has DLC, depicting 3 Dragon Ball Z movies, I highly recommend all of these as well:
[list]
[*] [i]Dragon Ball Z: Battle of the Gods[/i]
[*] [i]Dragon Ball Z: Resurrection F [/i]
[*] [i]Dragon Ball Z: The History of Trunks[/i]
[/list]
With at least 3 more DLCs currently planned to be released in a second season pass, the first being a depiction of [i]Dragon Ball Z: Bardock - The Father of Goku[/i]


I personally recommend this to anyone who has watched [i]Dragon Ball Z[/i] or has thought about delving into the series as this is a wonderful way to dive into the series in an interactive way! This game will get you caught up in order to watch Dragon Ball Super should you wish to.

First game on Steam I've 100%.  There are certainly some flaws with the systems, but overall, if you enjoy fighting games with a better story line than most out there, then this is the game for you.

Kakarot strikes an unusual genre balance between an arena fighting game and a semi-open-world action-RPG. Put another way, it feels sort of like a Dragon Ball powered version of Yakuza in its free-roaming segments, and then shifting to a traditional Xenoverse/Tenkaichi-like fighting game once combat starts. And as an arena fighter, it‚Äôs great. Combat is simple, focused on one-button combos and a customizable selection of four special moves, but loaded with little intricacies that go a long way when it comes to keeping the action from ever becoming thoughtless. You‚Äôre always locked on and tethered to your opponent, too, allowing you to move toward, away from, and orbit around them midair with ease, and you can switch between targets with a simple flick of the right stick.

While this may seem very button-mashy ‚Äì and to an extent it is ‚Äì it‚Äôs a combat system that nonetheless forces you to be reactive to what your opponent is doing. Most enemies have dangerous attacks that absorb strikes in order to deal one of their own that can immediately stop you in your tracks and leave you stunned, forcing you to carefully balance offense and your extremely mobile defensive options. Fortunately, Kakarot‚Äôs combat is smartly designed so that you can always evade to cancel out of a combo and get the hell out of the way when you can see something dangerous is being obviously telegraphed.

Ki management is also very important, as your ki meter dictates not only your special move usage but also your ability to use vanishes to instantly get close and punish projectile attacks, your ability to use a super dash and follow enemies up after knocking them away, your ability to use a burst of energy to knock an opponent away when they‚Äôre about to break through your guard, and of course your various transformations, including going Super Saiyan. I really like the way Kakarot uses Ki, tying just as many useful defensive techniques to it as it does offensive, making it a vital rechargeable resource during battle.

There‚Äôs also a tension gauge that fills over the course of a fight, and once it‚Äôs full you can activate a Surge mode which allows you to cancel special moves into each other. That means you could string together a series of kamehamehas, one after the other, for massive damage ‚Äì as long as you have the ki for it, of course. It‚Äôs a nice trump card to have once things get tough, and especially satisfying since you get an awesome ‚ÄúSuper Finish‚Äù animation when you end a fight with a Surge-powered beam attack.

Since Kakarot is single-player only and doesn‚Äôt need to be balanced with competitive play in mind, developer CyberConnect 2 was able to go a little bit wild with its enemy design and give them special moves that would typically be too powerful in PvP. Cell, for example, can split into about 20 weaker versions of himself, all of which start preparing attacks aimed directly at you, while Kid Buu and Frieza can create planet-sized energy bombs that force you to rush out of the blast zone or suffer massive damage. It makes these villains feel appropriately epic to fight.

I haven't played a Dad Simulator like this since Fallout 4. Cant believe I slept on it.
Even tho it is strictly an Asian dad simulator (for Anime dads to practice fatherhood) and the culture differences are rather stark, I was still able to enjoy my time as a virtual dad in this unfamiliar space.
As per usual, when I find a gem like this boy, I neglected my irl family and played thousands of hours offline, so my displayed playtime in no way reflects actual time spent engaging in the advanced father simulations.
Ruminating on the moments I mentally highlighted as a physic anchor, for when my irl family disappoints me and it cant be overstated how often they disappoint me, I couldn't help but notice that there was a slight problem with the boy-son-child of the game.
It might be my lack of a frame of reference regarding raising an Anime child, but what troubled me the most was my inability to control the types of people my Anime child was permitted to interact with. This Kame Roshi man was clearly a molester. I know it was implemented in the game to warn of the dangers, however, I felt a dialogue option to confront Mr. Roshi or alert the authorities of him would of been realistic to the simulation. If this had of been developed by Bethesda we could of expected such options. I would like to speculate that they would of scripted an event whereby you attend Mr. Kame Roshi's trial and  give a witness statement in the dock, you and then your boy-son-child. I digress.
It is because of this that I unfortunately cannot recommend this game as there are many fantastic Father Simulators on the market these days.
This is is still a great game. Please don't let my 'one thing that annoys me' deter you. It is a fantastic way to get an insight into raising an Anime child from the perspective of an Asian father.

I almost forgot to mention one of the most important features this Dad Quest game has that so many others forget to include. This is the fishing mechanic. No Dad Quest Father Simulation game can boast the full robust experience of operating a virtual father if they lack this key component.

To start I have to say that I'm 1) VERY harsh on my reviews, and 2) a Dragon Ball fan. That being said...I'll keep it short. 

The game is fun and responsive enough in battle, flying around is a joy. Gathering items to get stronger is a chore, and takes way too long. If you're not strong enough to beat a boss and assuming you're at max level...you have to gather supplies and cook food to get stronger, and that takes far too long. It's nice though that you even have the option to do that in this game, whereas other games would block you from progressing altogether. 

This game would get about an 8 out of 10 if it had enough content, but it feels like it was rushed out for the sake of profit by the studio when you're playing it...so for that I have to give it around a 6 out of 10. It's a high score for me to give any game, but there no denying that it's accessible to new players if you're willing to chill out and gather food for hours/days of playtime at which point you WILL feel unstoppable. 

Here's what I'll end with...if you have zero patience for RPGs, it's about a 6 out of 10 - you will have fun but will be challenged at times. If you're willing to grind for hours, it can be incredibly rewarding and you will feel like the game is anywhere from an 8 out of 10 to a 9....I don't see anyone thinking it's perfect because the DLC is far too short. Having said that...the cutscenes and missions etc. that you DO actually get are high quality in my humble opinion.

When I was a kid I remember seeing an english cracked version of an SNES game: Dragonball Z Super Gokuden...
In that game you could live out Son Goku's story as an RPG in like full 16  bit, and it blew my mind in the late 90s. This is like a 25 year re-envisioning of that game with a full transition into scale rendered 3d. Amazing. 
Awesome features, combat, storyline, and collectibles in game. For sure try it out if you were a fan or want a full story (starting with dbz). On another note, it's a super cool throwback to late 80s-90s anime/manga and the soundtrack is dope.

Dragon ball Z: KAKAROT...Is a game. I've 100% the game with all achievements and it really only took me 39 ish hours.

The game is okay, the gameplay gets boring really quickly and if you buy the DLC you can blitz through the game in a matter of hours due to you being able to get SSJ god before you even met Raditz, obviously that's up to you weather you do that if you own the DLC. The cut scenes are the highlight of the game making iconic scenes from Dragon ball z look amazing and feel fresh however its only really the big moments in each saga that look good as the rest of the cut scenes are just okay but when its good its really good. It does miss out some bits here or there which i find personally fine. I know Dragon ball Z well enough to fill in the blanks but its kind of a bummer if you are looking forward for some scenes and they just aren't there.

The game despite its flaws is fun. You can play the filler driving episode which i haven't seen a lot in Dragon ball games and they add characters like Launch which i find a nice touch however this game is so filled with content that is more or less useless/meaningless. The driving mini games, Baseball with Gohan, an entire fucking DBZ card game with an online and in game purchases? for some reason.

If you want to play another game that retells the story of Dragon Ball Z with cool cut scenes, go ahead this game is for you but if you are looking for a new more fresh take on a dragon ball game? This isn't your thing.

I personally had two highlights of the game, The cell saga had some of the cut scenes in the game and is one of my favourite arcs in all of Dragon ball so i did have some fun with it and the random secret ending where Mira and Towa from the Xenoverse games show up and you have to fight Towa...Yes that is a thing and i found it cool but its give or take. 

6/10 make Xenoverse 3

Having refined the combat system from the Xenoverse titles, as well as incorporating some animation cutscenes that make FigherZ look outdated, there are certainly merits to this game and I enjoy it, however I would be amiss to not admit this game is mostly poor: It attempts to be an RPG-Lite experience with various mini-games, cannon-fodder enemies, an empty open-world with so, -so- many fetchquests. Having completed the cell-saga at time of writing doing all the sidequests that appear, they certainly feel repetitive, and mechanics like resource-gathering, crafting and cooking, not using boosted flying and using options like nimbus instead, and much much more are all really disconnected from the core gameplay and feel very tacked-on and poorly-thought-out. 
That being said the combat and story of this game are still really fun, worth getting on a sale.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

WOW. Huge Dragonball fan, since I was a kid. I haven't had this much genuine, addicting fun since Tenkaichi 3.

I'll break it down as quickly as I can. If you're a fan, do yourself a favor and get this game soon! I held off, had my doubts. I was wrong. What seemed to me as a franchise cash grab, showed me that there is true passion put into this game. It's the small things too. Allowing you to build and drive Toriyama-esque vehicles, even though you can fly at 10x the speed. Letting you cook, explore. Even map layouts are scarily accurate. It made me personally feel like a kid playing that DBZ game we all always wanted.

OK, now gameplay. The fights are insane. Smooth, punchy to godlike maneuvers that tear up landscapes as you fight. Each character feels different from each other, each with an expansive skill tree. This is not a versus game. Don't go in expecting that. The combat is very much intended to make you feel like a super saiyan badass, so it's tailored to be smooth, fun and CINEMATIC. Something these games have lacked... for a while. Exploring the world is fun and full of options. Also, exploring and fighting is a smooth transition. I believe that's important in a dragonball game. 

It's a gorgeous looking game (which is set to receive an even bigger facelift soon) From, gorgeously rendered landscapes and cell shading to hand-drawn, visceral cutscenes that at times make it seem like you're watching a remastered version of the show, the game is easy on the eyes.

I truly believe that if you're a fan of this series and want to get lost in the best in-game interpretation of this world's story, you need to do yourself a favor and play it. BUT i also believe that from the perspective of someone curious about the series that knows nothing, this game does a great job of telling the story to new comers with the added benefit of being a part of it themselves.

Simple really. I play FighterZ for the versus aspect and this for that single player escapism Dragonball never seemed to get right, until now.

Excited for Season 2 expansions as well!

Get the game, explore this awesome world we all love. Fight. Be powerful. Save the universe. Have FUN!

I've wanted to play this game since launch, and not one of the complaints about it made me change my mind. Not because I ignored them or anything, but because I know my priorities. Dragon Ball Z Kakarot is slow, full of shit that does NOT matter (the orbs, the giant skill trees of every character, the fact that Yamcha and Chiaotzu are available support characters, the crafing/cooking mechanics, a LOT of quests, side-mechanics, etc) that does actively get in the way of your game sometimes AND the fact that this is JUST the Dragon Ball Z story without movie plots or even the filler episodes (just because it has the car episode does not mean this has like. anything else)
But. I don't mind! I don't mind grindy, easy, slow games like this sometimes. It's bad, sure. It's easy. I mean it's better it be easy than difficult, because any actual difficulty it offers is more frustration than challenge.
I think Kakarot is a fun game. It's fun. I'm always having fun with it. This is the DragonBall Z game that I've always wanted. 
I never realized this until I played it myself, however. The name of the title doesn't clearly reflect what this game actually is, which is a full retelling of the anime.
Calling the game "DragonBall Z: Kakarot" implies that this is a game all about Kakarot (Goku), when in fact you only get to play as him about a 1/3 of the time. I get that the whole DB series has always been about Goku in general, so it's a minor nit-pick. The point is that the naming convention kept me from immediately realizing that this wasn't just a story about Kakarot, but in fact a somewhat definitive DBZ experience.
My favorite thing about this game is how it expands upon the greater lore of the universe(s) in ways that would still fit neatly into canon. There are even some extra lines of dialogue peppered throughout that fill in glaring plot holes and address various well known fan theories. This really is a treat, especially with most of the original cast voicing them.
The open world design and Action-RPG style is, like I said, what I've always wanted in a DBZ game.
The battle system could be a lot better. I would've preferred a fighting game style system with access to a character's entire moveset through the use of combos, but the simplicity of it lends itself well to an RPG, I suppose...at least it isn't card-based for once. (Although there is a mini-game for those of you who are into that.)

First DBZ game that takes you through the story in a long time. They were a dime a dozen 10+ years ago, but we needed a modern one. The game does skip some iconic moments such as Gohan going berserk on 3rd form Freeza after Piccolo gets Death Beam Barraged, or Vegeta going Super Saiyan in Space. Or rushes other moments Like Goku Going SS3 for the first time. 

This is what Fighting games should be. (this is technically an Action RPG but plays the same as an Arena Fighter). Not nearly as much double standards for the AI then the player (AKA difficulty by annoyance) as most Fighting games.

Time wise the main story is about 40 hours, plus post game side quests and grinding, then DLC. I don't own them (yet?) but I've heard they don't add that much time/content. [Future Trunks arc, Battle of Gods and Resurrection F] I do hope they add the Broly and Super Hero movies as DLC.

[h1]Only watched Dragon Ball, who this?[/h1]

[b][u]PROS[/u]:[/b] This is a well designed arena fighter, jumping around from 1v1 to 3v6 battles.  The controls feel tight & responsive.  Techniques are easy to use, as are the transformations.  Everything is unlocked through an upgrade menu skill tree, using orbs to make the way down to the bottom, with some techniques hidden behind training battles.  The visuals & soundtrack all pop, using many tracks from the show itself, though missing the insert songs.  As for the story, it's exactly what you expect from a Dragon Ball game.  The side quests, though, provide additional content, attempting to explain both what was going on during major events, as well as showing off some characters that borderline disappeared in the second half of the series.

[b][u]CONS[/u]:[/b] This is an RPG at heart, & as a result, the endgame is loaded with grind.  Although the core game gives plenty of opportunities to gather orbs & provides you with plenty, a fair amount of the endgame requires an insane amount of them.  The higher level challenges can also feel incredible cheap to attempt to playthrough.  It also feels like the game has a lot of bloated downtime between the chapters, with some side missions & challenges feeling rather unrewarding (though admittedly it is amusing having Son Goku cruising about in a car).  A fairly big miss, however, is the lack of the entire first half of the story, with the game kicking in at Raditz's arrival.  Finally, there's the oddly detailed free card game DLC.  This is entirely dependent on the user playing, but it feels like a cheaper version of Magic the Gathering.  Personally, I didn't enjoy it, but I could understand someone putting more hours into that instead of the main game.

[b][u]ACHIEVEMENTS[/u]:[/b] The achievement list is actually very simple.  Though it's varied & may seem like a challenge, the majority of them will actually be completed just playing through the story & completing side quests.  The only one that will provide some challenge is the battle with Mira.  My recommendation is to actually boot up the first DLC as soon as you can.  The rewards make leveling up very simple, & should not be passed on until the endgame.

[b][u]FINAL[/u]:[/b] This is actually a well designed arena RPG that has enough content to pull you through to the end of the game.  Though it feels a bit laggy in content from time to time, & the lack of the first half of Dragon Ball is missed, the positives outweigh the negatives.  Definitely worth a look, & not only just for Dragon Ball fans.

This game has/had promise to be the greatest Dragon Ball game ever made...however it has some rather jarring issues that really hold it back. It can still be a fun and engaging experience but the voice acting drops off when you are not playing the main questlines which would have been acceptable 10+ years ago but now it feels quite dated especially considering how high quality those main quest moments are.
The side content also is a bit odd at times...for instance before you leave earth the main quest insists that the largest threats to the planet are the saiyans whom are roughly around level 20ish however there are a number of level 50 robots just chillin out in the open in the same zone as those same saiyans and nobody seems concerned or even mentions them...you would think SOMEONE would udder something along the lines of forget about those monkeys Ultron is here run for your lives!
They have been adding content pretty consistently though which is commendable given they are trying to keep up with where the show is to the best of their ability.
Then all of a sudden they release a card game... this card game can only be played online...yes the shoe horned a gacha mtx card game into a single player rpg...this card game actually cant be played in the normal game itself though so if you want to play that you cant just play with npc's along the way, instead you need to wait for someone else to show the slightest amount of interest to play a game online...which can take a while.

The only acceptable reason in my eyes for them to shoehorn in an unwanted card game riddled with microtransactions would be to raise additional funding to bring the voice actors back in to record quality audio for all of the quests and dialogue...BUT... I seriously doubt that's what the publisher has in mind... which is most unfortunate as I was very optimistic about this game before launch. There is nothing more immersion breaking than the stark contrast of quality voice acting of the main story along side bargain bin quest audio. Cyberconnect is notorious for this behavior and it really shows how dated their formula has become these days. The card game is a new move for Cyberconnect, however its Bandai's go to move which will surely drag Cyberconnect's reputation through the mud when they really just needed a win. This game was so promising and came so close to delivering only to fall flat and then make an abrupt U-turn into oncomming traffic.

I still would recommend it for a Dragon Ball game in general but you should avoid the card game like the plague that it is.
It's getting so exhausting to buy games these days, the industry as a whole is nothing but a disappointment and they are so shameless about it that it's hard to ever feel inclined to praise a game when they get something right.

This game is a masterpiece! This is how I imagined a DB game when I was a kid. This is a must buy!
The gameplay can be stale at times but I think it is a more accurate retelling of the beloved story of DBZ that I have seen in any Dragon ball game I have played.

I'd give it a 6.5 out of 10.

Kakarot is not an RPG, it's more like a main-canon action adventure with minimal RPG elements. I see it as "another way to experience the DBZ story" that is more interactive, but little else. I do recommend it as an "occasional diversion" if you happen to be in one of those "what should I play?" moods. IT's good in small doses, like a few hours in a day or two to take a break from other things. But I'd get it on sale (which I did) because I wouldn't call it "worth the full price" especially since the DLC is so expensive, even though I intend to get it eventually.

Especially because if you bought this, chances are you already know the story pretty closely. I do not recommend it for new fans for the Dragonball universe. I'd go watch the anime for that. (If you want only the main plots, please watch Kai or look for ways to skip the filler because there is a LOT of it.) Maybe the older Budokai and Tenkaichi games, but those are really hard to find, and yet still leave parts of the story out.

If you've never watched Dragon Ball Z, the core gameplay likely isn't enough hold your interest, but for those of us who haven't watched DBZ in a decade, Kakarot serves as a beautiful retelling (and a quite enjoyable game). 

It's an open world action RPG that follows the storyline of Dragon Ball Z (and with DLC, much of Super). There may be better examples, but: if you combine the combat of [url=https://youtu.be/tBB5FonUU64?t=174]Idainaru Dragon Ball Densetsu[/url] (1996, PS1) with the scope and pacing of [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jo8H1urQC1I&t=5261s]Super Saiya Densetsu[/url], that's Kakarot. 

The combat is relatively simple and can become tedious‚Äîespecially when flying around various sections of the world, bumping into random goons‚Äîbut the boss battles can punish you without discovering various tactics for an enemy (especially on Hard mode, which can be toggled). When not battling, watching a cutscene, or reading dialogue, various section of the Dragon Ball Z universe open up for semi-autonomous exploration. 

You don't have to engage in exploring (sticking to the story), but the developers have sprinkled in a great amount of Dragon Ball lore, and there's several mini-games (e.g. time attack with hover cars, cooking, fishing) that involve materials across the lands. They also include a whole card game.   

The art work and animation is phenomenal. Music and voice acting: excellent. The environments capture the Toriyama art style and coloring. I wouldn't mind seeing a non-interactive storyline using this engine.

The game is single player and story driven, so replayability may be limited, but it does such a fantastic job of recreating the anime in video-game form that I'd recommend buying it at full price (at least over rewatching the entire series!). If you're not that antsy to relive the story, but are a fan through and through, <$60 (with DLC) should be more than enough value.

It feels like a living breathing world where you're really feel like you're a part of the DBZ universe. My 12-year-old self would have pooped himself seeing a game like this. I will come back and update this once I've really gotten much further into the game, BUT

So, if 9 year old me could have played this game, I probably would have thrown up from excitement.
This is everything I'd ever dreamed of for video games as a kid. Being able to BE Gohan would have melted my little adolescent mind. 

So far, this appears to be an incredible and almost-perfect blend of the actual Dragon Ball Z plot-line into a video game. There's a great amount of side missions, world to explore, and added mini-games or mechanics to really make the Dragon Ball world come to life. 

The gameplay itself? Fucking Superb. I've played plenty of the DB games, but I've always wanted to see something more open-world and more free to transition- like being able to just take the fuck off and start bombing somewhere flying, and to just stop flying anywhere, and then explore the world around.

I will edit this review in a month or two when I've really gotten far into the game, just to make sure it still holds up.

Combat is fast, feels powerful, and has a good amount of customization so it never feels dull. Bosses can be genuinely challenging on Hard difficulty. There's some minor inconsistencies with the source material (mainly cut filler and such), and there are some design and game mechanic choices that seem superfluous, but it's an enjoyable, solid experience. Definitely worth the price of admission.

As of this moment I just beat the game on normal difficulty. I am WAY late to the party.

The game isn't a fighter, which a lot of fans dislike about it I guess, but instead an RPG that tells the story of Dragon Ball Z. It has little easter eggs of Dragonball which is neat. My only real complaint about it is that the normal difficulty is super easy. The game consists of you grinding for levels, spamming a single button for combo build up, a button to charge ki, and then hold two buttons to perform super attacks. It's bare bones at best. Even compared to Xenoverse which has light/heavy and supers/ultimates. If you're looking for some challenge, this probably isn't going to be it.

So why did I hit recommend? Because of the following.

I've been a fan of Dragonball and Dragonball Z since the 90s. I absolutely love this series in all it's forms (Except the live action. It shouldn't have ever happened.). I even enjoyed GT with all it's quirks and odd bits. Super is a refreshing addition as well. However, those aren't in this game (if you don't include the mini-series DLC additions which I'm not at this moment). 

What is in this game is amazing story telling, amazing cutscenes, and that feeling I had as a kid watching the series play out for the first time. I've seen the animation dozens of times, even the Abridged stuff, and after the first handfuls of replays I lost that feeling.

The swelling of pride, of sadness, of anger, or joy when my favorite characters did the impossible. Or sitting on the edge of my seat when I am watching the battles play out. Sure I knew before playing the game how every fight ends, but the way the devs made the cutscenes play out with the way that the voice actors gave feeling to the characters. Even the new additions added to the cutscenes (like making Frieza/Buu/Cell look absolutely sadistic looking in their final scenes) was enough to make my heart race and had me feeling like that kid again.

I do wish I could have played as more characters than the four that I played for the most part of the game. You could probably guess who those four are, I won't spoil it even though it's been out for 2yrs now. Sure you get access to some support characters and a few new ones at the post-game, but still would have been nice to try to main Krillin.

TL;DR:

The game is easy as spamming two buttons and a joystick direction. 

The story, cutscenes, and the additions to the story made me feel like I was in the 90s watching the show for the first time.

Would I suggest buying it? On sale sure.
Complete it? At least the story.
DLC? Eh, I've done the first God DLC and it's okay. Super small.
Replay Value? For DBZ Fans I'm sure there will be some. I intend on going back and playing the DLC and Maxing out characters and doing all the sub-story missions.

Dragon Ball: Kakarot is a great game especially for all the DBZ fans. The game contains the main story arcs, featuring the iconic main character Son Goku and his friends and foes, fighting to save the Earth. A surprisingly good action game, with all the DBZ flair of yelling at your opponents to get more powerful. Kakarot is a bit of a misnomer: you spend far more time playing as other cast members, especially Gohan. The power curve of the game itself is solid; you don't have to spend tons of time grinding and if you do the main story and side quests you'll be right where you should be for fights.

That said, don't be tempted by the "villianous enemies" to try and grind up and fight them when they first appear; you'll end up overleveled and trivializing the main story fights. Which can be disappointing; I used DLC1 to level up early and ended up restarting because I felt way too overpowered.

The story and concept of this game is great but the fighting is very horrible in this game. If you're fighting an opponent one-on-one it's okay but if you're fighting multiple opponents it's quite annoying and not fun to play. The fighting is just not smooth and fluent like other dragon Ball z games. .The stun meter is always full so when you get up close on them you wind up just stunning yourself which is stupid and nothing like any of the other dragon Ball z games fighting games I have played. I'm puzzled why they even put that feature in the game when you yourself don't have the a ability to stun them just from blocking. Anytime you use one of your special long range blast moves they will either just dodge it or you will get hit by one of the other fighters and get knocked out of it. The barrage you get from the other people you're fighting just does not make for good smooth gameplay when fighting. I found when I even use my special attacks like the Spirit bomb it hits them and does no damage sometimes. I have had to even spam the Spirit bomb in multiple fights because it auto locks on one of the few special's in the game that do that just to win a fight against multiple apponents, this makes the gameplay boring. I don't recommend getting this game unless you get it on discount. Otherwise I would recommend getting dragon Ball z fighters or xenoverse 2 (which has its own problems also) but it certainly more enjoyable to play than the fighting in this. The Budokai series was the last real great dragon Ball z fighting series in my opinion that was out. How you go from smooth gameplay like that from back in the day to the janky garbage you put out now is just amazing and shows that you need to hire better talent.

As an avid fan, I have played numerous DBZ games over the years. Most of them have felt like something akin to Mortal Kombat but with DBZ characters. This does not. This feels like you are an active member in the game. I understand why some people have called it a "button masher" and to some degree it is, but that is also the nature of fighting games. That's like calling a driving game boring because all that you do is hold down the gas pedal. It's missing the forest for the trees. Yes, you mash buttons repeatedly, but you also can string together combos that are not moronically extensive, but still feel somewhat like you're doing them with direct intention, and not just hoping you get a combo by mashing every button all at once. Enough about the combat though. The story is what I absolutely love.  You basically get to "play" the entire show from Raditz onward. You can level up different abilities, use different team members, and I loved the aspect of the Community Board that lets you level up every character. Overall this game was so well done. It was so much better than what I expected. I would give it a solid 9/10. My only minor complaints is that if you are not careful you can skip side missions by continuing the main story without knowing that you can't complete them later. Especially early on. 

If you're a DBZ fan, I HIGHLY recommend this game.

This game is brilliant. I've played a fair few Dragon Ball games, the Raging Blast series, the Budokai Tenkaichi series, the Xenoverse games even the Dragon Ball game for the Kinect for the Xbox 360 and this has to be one of the best experiences in a Dragon Ball game I have ever had. Most Dragon Ball games like to give a spin on the main story or have the focus shift from the story to just the battles between the characters, and that's a good thing, DBZ is over 30 years old now with a lot of game instalments in that time so its nice to see something new. Kakarot includes so much detail in the story, in the animations, the new fights, the cut-scenes and the numerous side quests that it feels like each battle is brand new out of the box. People criticise the free-roam which while its definitely no Witcher 3 or Skyrim (and come on who was expecting that here) in a DBZ game it is by far the most inclusive and fun free-roam to date and I had a blast in it and the battles are in a similar position, they may be simple and not light-years ahead of what we have seen in recent DBZ games but they are the most well executed and just plain enjoyable battles in a Dragon Ball game I've had in years. So yeah, good game.

As a old fan of the show I thought I'd pick this up to see how it is. From the videos and reviews I thought it would be pretty cool. 

Played it for all of about 20 minutes before stopping. While this might be a good game what I saw in those 20 minutes was really annoying.

1: Booting up the game I saw something like 30 text pop-ups about stuff I had "unlocked" that meant absolutely nothing to me because I haven't even played the game yet.
2: The tutorial fight was okay albeit somewhat simple.
3: The movement in the open-world area sucks bigtime. This game feels like something from the late 90s or early 00s. Really stiff jumping, very clunky.
4: Open world zone immediately presented an annoying "escort the slow npc" thing which served absolutely no purpose but to slow the game which was really annoying considering how janky+fast the movement is in this area
5: The fishing thing with the random quick time events was annoying. Not hard but annoying. At this point I am just skipping all the dialogue because up until now 90% of the gameplay has been "read this text box" or "listen to these characters be annoying"
6: The little emblem thing was the last straw. "Put it NEXT to Goku" was being shown to me but no matter where I clicked it just wouldn't do anything but repeat this message. Finally it worked after clicking the exact spot it wanted me to put it despite me having clicked that area multiple times. Maybe this is a controller issue I dunno but it was really stupid.

Anyway...
I'm presently pretty frustrated by this game and quite disappointed. It looks super cool from the videos and screenshots but it feels like a game that would have come out 20 years ago. It is clunky, annoying and vapid. 

I will be giving it some more time this weekend but my initial feelings aren't good. At present I wouldn't recommend this to anyone but the hardcore DBZ fan and/or people who may not notice/care about the really clunky gameplay.

This game is a great follow up to the spirit of the Legacy of Goku series of games.
It has a huge open world with a some nice things to find, and ok side quests to do.
The battle system is easy to learn, but had some good room for complexity. It's very reminiscent of Xenoverse, but with some welcome changes. You're able to utilize ally attacks against enemies which make for an interesting strategic element of a battle. Plus I always appreciate when I don't have to use up an attack slot for charging up ki.
The character interactions might be my favorite part of this game. There's older characters in Dragon Ball's history that make reappearances and its always welcome to see them come back.
Overall, I'd recommend this game for anyone who wants a new Legacy of Goku game, but with an updated battle system and a much more expansive world.

If you are a fan of 'Dragon Ball Z'' anime, this game is for you. Battles are never boring, you have so much to do besides fighting. You can free roam in the world, completing sub-stories and many other fun stuff. You can experience all of the Sagas in the game, also buy "Trunks: Warrior of Hope" DLC, its really worth it! I am recommending this game! Final score? 8.7/10.

If you are planing on getting this game, first go and play the demo, if there is ever a demo that you can get, get that demo first, and if you enjoyed it, I'd suggest getting the game.
Now for the review, of what I've seen so far.
The start, the tutorial is easy, but to a new player can also be challenging, and is a great way to intoduce the controls, BUT if you're using KB+M, change your button icons in settings, it should show as type B when you first open it, you'll have to do this every time.
Saiyan Saga, for your fight with Raditz, do the two side quests that you can so that you will have your best chance against him, next is Nappa and the plants, by this point you hopefully have done the quests, but you still will have to farm up XP, now Vegeta, he was a PAIN to fight, even on normal, even when I was in close to the same level as him.
Frieza Saga, this was easier overall than Vegeta was to fight, once you got the power boost it was a cakewalk, nothing much to say.
Android Saga, you never fight 16, which personally I would love to be dunked by 16, but is still challenging with the fight against Vegeta as Trunks.
I have yet to finish the game, but so far the Cell Saga is good. Personally I can't wait for the Cell games portion.
So far, 8/10, if the grinding wasn't required and it was all down to playstyle and being tactical, I'd personally call it a perfect 10. But it is a nice 3D DBZ game. I hope that GT stuff is in the game, or gets added if it's not already in.

What is a [i]Kakaroto[/i]? 

An RPG. One that faithfully recreates the story of Dragon Ball Z, in the most pleasant of ways, but isn't without its faults.

 [b]The Good[/b]
In-depth storytelling and cutscene direction that's actually worth a buck. Kakaroto's take on each and every saga, & some of their most iconic beats, have been, for the most past, faithfully recreated alongside a soundtrack that's been lifted straight from the show.

Visuals be no slouch either (albeit some "engine.ini" tweaking was required to tone down the crappy bloom), attention to detail is abundant throughout, and the sheer amount of love and care put onto some of the most iconic landmarks is tangible.

Speaking of maps, the game's been divided into a dozen or so explorable area's, and they've been sized just right. Not one is either too big and empty or too little and claustrophobic. Traveling from one side to the other is often a quick affair.

Character modeling is on another level though. Each boasting crazy high polys and all intricately detailed.

The more you progress through the story, train, and attain new moves & transformations, the greater, more impactful your actions will be. Some to the point of brokenness, like the maxed out versions Vegie's Big Bang Attack, Goku's Spirit Bomb. It's amusing.

There are two distinct types of "currency" (kind of), and each serves its distinct purpose.

Zeni (money). You earn it by farming for ingredients (meat, fish, spices, vegetables, fruit...), minerals, mechanical parts, even gifts (which can be used to upgrade your community boards), and all can be sold for prices of the variable type.

Z balls (of which there are 6 types in total), easy to come by, they're scattered everywhere & can be used to upgrade your skill trees.

With that said, there's one set of special balls to collect, 7 of them actually, and these are of the wish guaranteeing type. They allow you to ask for severe amounts of all of the above. Or you can wish your enemies back to life. Like Rasditz and Napa. King Cold and The Gunyu Force. ...and so on. These "what ifs" are the best kind of side mission you can get.

[b]The Bad[/b]
Skill trees too. Unlocking more and new upgradable slots/techniques (ones specifically marked by an icon), requires the beating of training sessions. But to beat each training course, one must be at a similar level as of the required. Which wouldn't be too much to ask.

Problem is, reaching higher levels, needs story progression, and even though farming's a bit of a requirement (but not overly imposed), what comes out of it the most, is Z Balls, maybe some items, but not much else. 

Generic battle encounters, other than Vilaneus Enemies (and even those), barely give any meaningful amount of XP, making all of the leveling process, feel not only a tad little bit on-rails, but never truly satisfying.

Speaking of battles. The game's severely lacking in enemy variety. Each random encounter (can usually be avoided) consists of the same 2 or 3 types of robots, a drone or two, and colour swapped Frieza soldiers. Not fun. 

Combat in of itself, ain't anything to write home about... It's fluid and does the job, but is simple and button mashy, which leaves a lot to be desired given the game's colossal size.

Sub Stories, aka, side missions. They serve their purpose and earn the player decent amounts of XP. At their best, they give insight on the littlest of details, raging from early Dragon Ball to later Z, even some the most obscure facts are thrown around.

But they're just not fun, and can be divided into 2 types. 

It's either, go there and fight the same random enemies over and over. Or... go there and collect some rare items. Maybe a mix of both if lucky.

It's a bore fest, really.

[b]The Ugly[/b]
Menus, menus, and more menus! Oh man... There's a butt load of them and they never go away. The more you play, the more chapters you beat, the more menus you get introduced to!

It got odd, fast... and for each one, a pop-up tutorial or two. 

Speaking of tutorials, they're everywhere, for everything you do, for everything you earn, for everything you unlock, you get a random tutorial pop-up for it, constantly breaking the flow of the game.

Making Kakaroto's all the more confusing, a lot of it overlaps after a while, making it hard to keep up.

What about battle buffs? 

Oh my... You can get some characters to make you the most delightful meals, and each meal earns you exclusive buffs of variable stats and duration. But the problem stems from the fact that there's just too many, each requiring all sorts of ingredients, some more common than others.

Some cutscenes suffer from pre-render syndrome, and their resolution was capped at 1080p & rendered at the lowest possible bitrate imaginable.

[b]Final Verdict[/b]
Kakaroto's a long, long game, that tells the story of DBZ exceptionally well, and is fully loaded with fan service, but falls short of being truly great.

Therefore earning a rEvo's rating of 6/10.

Grade:
(If you are a fan of Dragonball): B+
(Otherwise): D- 
 
2nd edit - The more I play this game the worse it becomes..., once the DB hype runs out, the combat quickly goes from awful, to annoying, frustrating and infuriating, especially against multiple opponents.
Fights very quickly devolve away from DBZ fantasy into dodging like a coward until a small window open when you can do one attack of some kind and then go back to avoiding fighting again,


Cons [Combat]:
- a mosquito sneeze is enough to interrupt a Super Sayan God....,
- game actively punishes you for trying to do melee combat,
- enemies constantly abuse super armor, 
- multiple enemies will keep you interrupted and chain stunlock you often,
- game is obsessed in putting you versus multiple opponents while denying you your own team mates,

Cons [Combat mechanics]
- multi hit moves poorly connect with enemies and will often miss,
- "guided" Ki moves don't work properly,
- some special attacks work with combos some do not - game wont indicate this until you try out,
- blocking is next to worthless as it will be broken and open you to damage while stunned,
- enemies can magically perfect dodge your attacks,


Cons [Skill/RPG System]:
- skills/upgrades are gated by story progression and level,
- game allows you to waste time unlocking certain skills but then blocks you from being able to use them until arbitrary points in the story,
- random encounters give barely any experience but game is constantly trying to force you into them, often one after abother,
- food stats gains are some sort of a troll attempt, you gain 1000 HP when your chaarcter is sitting on milions,

Other Cons:
- big explosions/clouds of dust /terrain obscuring your vision while enemies keep beating you up,
- open world is pretty but filled with nothing interesting,
- side quest add some flavor but are only voiced by "grunts" and are rather boring,


Pros:
- You can go Super Sayan and punch Frieza in his ugly mug,
- can visit many locations from DB Universe and meet almost all of the characters,
- decent graphics - characters recreated well to match anime,
- 1 vs 1 battles are Ok.

I spent an hour working for the money to pay for this game, and then I wasted several hours of my life playing it, thinking, "I'm sure it'll get better."

This game is not an RPG. It's more like a 3D hack and slash that progresses you through the story of Dragon Ball Z. A significant downgrade from a game like Xenoverse 2.

I got attacked by the same two, very similar, looking enemies about 100 times, while flying around the open world, trying to collect endless orbs, which I need in order to learn new abilities.

I progressed through the story, and I did some empty feeling quests.
The whole experience was extremely tedious. It felt like a waste of time.

What's worse is... I don't know if developers/publishers are paying for, or possibly spamming 5-Star & Thumbs Up reviews on their own games... or what's going on... but look this game up on Google, you'll find plenty of paragraph-long, 5-Star reviews that are word for word copies of each other, posted by different users.

All I'm saying is something is fishy.

I'm starting to feel like reviews in general are completely meaningless these days.

It's a truly an awful world we live in, where you don't know how good anything is,
but in reality, everything sucks more, and more, and more, every, single, day.

Save your hard-earned money. That's my recommendation.

Im currently 30 years old and still remember when I watched my first episode of DBZ back when I was around 9. So yeah I recommend this game if you want to relax and have a good time experiencing the story that started it all.

I have loved playing DragonBall Z games since I was a kid and have been continuing to play them now in my mid 20's. I'm honestly so disappointed with the directions these past few games have gone in terms of game play and fighting mechanics. With the technology we have now, you would think the creators would be able to make a solid, immersive, all around,  game in these past few years. We have all loved the Budokai, Budokai Tenkaichi, and Raging Blast games but there has been nothing close to those calibers in years. These same old, spamming buttons, repetition, tag team games is all we get now. I miss the transformation scenes, the way each super looked, the way ultimate finishers felt, so exciting and fluid. I always buy these games in hopes that they would incorporate some of those exciting mechanics in a new way, but it's just been disappointment.

Fans of DBZ will have fun. It's a very cool concept to be able to fly around to various story locations as DBZ characters. The game gets very repetitive, though. Both the fighting and the sub stories get very repetitive.

Firstly, I want to tell anyone reading this that I haven't finished the game but have put in enough hours to give a decent review. I'm not a DBZ fanboy and I wasn't one to watch the show so the story was new to me in every aspect. My sister loved the show and I appreciated the artwork. 

The gameplay and story are quite fun and I think that anyone who is a DBZ fan will absolutely love the game. I have tried other DBZ games and this is the only one that has held my interest. I will be going through and beating the rest of it.

I do have one complaint that I think others should keep in mind before buying the game. The side quests and intermissions between major plot events are horrible. They are what makes portions of the game almost unbearable. Most of them you can skip but there are some that you have to complete. These side quests sum up to fetch quests. The most horrible of them all is one where you have to get a royal tomato by getting a specific fish that only spawns sometimes at certain locations so you end up gathering up a ton of resources that are not related to the side quest itself. I took me almost half an hour (I wish I didn't have to admit this) to find the item needed. It comes down to my own stupidity to waste that kind of time on something pointless. 

Other than the side quests the game is enjoyable and I would recommend DBZ Kakarot on sale.

If you're a fan of Dragonball, Dragonball Z and/or Dragonball Super, I highly recommend Dragonball Z Kakarot. It's an Action-Adventure RPG set in the world of Dragonball Z where you play, variously, as Goku and friends starting with the Saiyan Saga and leading all the way through the Buu Saga. Downloadable Content includes 3 extra adventures: The Future Trunks Saga, and two adventures that give an alternate telling of the beginning of Dragonball Super which allow you to gain Super Saiyan God and Super Saiyan God SS abilities.

What you see is what you get. The >90% positive reviews are very well deserved in my opinion, and if you have any doubts, there's the demo.

Basically an interactive anime with very straightforward fights. Most people pull through, just look at the achievements and their completion rates, despite the long play times. (We play long hours because we are watching cut scenes). I have enjoyed this a lot, I think the genius of Toriyama shines through even though it's not the comic.

BUTs:
- A game controller is almost required, the keyboard support is really poor. Also, make it an XBox controller, if possible.
- If you are one of those who skips the cut scenes, don't get this game, as you would be skipping 70% of the content.
- The game is teen-rated so it doesn't show blood in the fights.

First things first. The Title of the game is misleading. It should be DBZ: Gohan, since you play like 80% of the game as Gohan. I did not mind but just so you know what you are dealing with here.

So I just finished the main story and I'll probably keep on playing it and will buy the dlc's. I had a lot of fun with this game so far and I have to say that this is, right after budokai tenkaichi 3, my favourite dragon ball game out there. Unfortunately I still have to give it a negative review. I'll explain my complains in detail below, but here are my main points, why I just can't recommend to buy this game to anyone here. 

1. The pricing for this game is way too high. Don't get me wrong I like to pay money to people who brought me a lot of fun with their work. But I still can't wrap my head around the pricing for this game since it is very flawed in many ways and the technical side of this game is not nearly on the level it should be for a game from 2020. For 20 bucks this game is totally worth it (I got it for 20) but anybody who buys it for 60 bucks or more ist just wasting their money. There are far better games out there with better pricing and you can watch the series online for free.
2. I do not think this game is for anybody who is not looking for a nostalgia trip through one of his favourite storys of all time. The game is so flawed and everything in this game but the flying and the combat could have been implemented better. I probably only enjoyed the game, since I was able too look beyond all these flaws and my monkey nostalgia neurons just fired like hell everytime I saw something nice.

So lets come to pros and cons:

Pros:
- super fun combat (they just nailed it)
- really good cutscenes (when it comes to the main story)
- occasionally funny dialogs in sidequests wich arent in the main series
- some sidequests are really good
- flashy fights
- the game really looks and feels like the anime
- first time you are able to explore the whole world yourself
- the game sounds really good (soundtrack, voiceacting and soundeffects are just on point)
- the rpg system makes the game a whole lot more interesting, since you have to somehow manage the strength of the characters
- good mini games
- Well it is a Dragonball game. This is a pro in my opinion
- You get to play the episode where Goku and Picollo go to driving school

Cons:
- The game doesn't look too good if I am honest. You can look over that fact since it looks so charming. The characters look nice, if you focus on the combat and if you are blind, well yes then it might look good, but if you take a closer look this game looks really crappy. The trees look like lego sets if you take a closer look and the whole world just looks like they either did not have enough time to put enough detail in the world or, what i would guess, they were simply too lazy to make a more detailed world.
- The map is a f**ing wasteland. I love that you are able to explore the world by flying around it but this world is only pretty and nice if you look at it from the sky. This map is really f**ing empty and tbh there is not much to find on it other than little fotos that give you a nostalgie trip to the first series. 
- The NPC's are some of the worst I have ever seen. These are just walking zombies who well.... just walk and stand in the middle of nowhere and do literally nothing. The world does not seem like there are living people in it. It seems like they had 20 npc models, made 2 walking and standing animations for male and female and just placed them around the map. For a full price game this is really the worst you could do and it is embarissing.
- The Sidequests .... well ..... the Sidequests.... While some where pretty funny and had some interesting interactions between the characters or even interesting fights, other sidequests are really repetetive garbage with no soul or meaning to it what so ever. Plain and boring missions where you fight against robots, saibaman or freezer soldiers for some stupid reason or where you have to find some random items that are all over the map ( The map is not really small).
- I will not talk about every mechanic here but let me put it this way. There are a lot of optional gameplay mechanics here that seem nice at first but are in fact obsolete since they dont impact your fights in any significant way. So these mechanics just feel like a total waste of time.... and there are a LOT of these mechanics ..... It just seems like a waste of potential these mechanics have. It is a pity.
- To see everything in this game you have to grind a bit and this can get boring pretty quick since the world is empty, boring and everything is kinda soulless outside the main campaign.


So in conclusion:
- I really liked the game. I think it is not bad but I would not call it great either. It is good if you are a fan of DB in general, it is "meh" if you aren't familiar with the series.
- Should you buy this game ? Not for the full price. Wait for sale and grab it for a cheap price. BUUUT since it is a full price game .... I will give it a negative review because no human being with more than 2 brain cells can justify this price for a game that is this flawed and looks like it was made in 2012.

Would greatly recomend to any fan of DragonBall whether casual or diehard.

I've been a huge fan of dragon ball since I was a kid. I've seen every episode from the original anime up to Super and read nearly every chapter of the manga (I'm not current on Super), so needless to say an openworld game in this universe had me pretty excited. That being said this game is not worth the time you'll waste in it. It's grindy, repetitive, and annoying. Characters say the same 5 lines of dialogue over and over in the open world and you are constantly attacked by trash mobs that scale to your character's level. The combat is boring and incredibly easy, and the only reason your progress through the story will be halted is when you need to grind for levels so you don't get OHKO'd by the next boss. It covers the story of Dragon Ball Z so I mean nothing you haven't seen before in a myriad of other games, now you just have to deal with annoying repeating dialogue and get forced into fighting random Red Ribbon robots that are as strong as you are for some godforsaken reason. Now the animations are gorgeous and rewatching Z in this way was kind of cool, but we've all seen it so many times that it didn't really excite me like if they had started from OG Dragon Ball. Not to mention the game is called Kakarot and due to Z mostly being Gohan's story that's who you play as the most. All in all I'd give the game a 5/10, it's just uninspired and very obviously trying to profit off of fans love for the series.

The best Dragon Ball Z game based on the Story. Lets face it Xenoverse 2 Is awesome for being its own thing. Kakarot is everything I have always wanted from a Dragon ball Z game but the main aspect I praise the most is the ability to Continue to pass limits. although towards end game this becomes more about eating for the PERMANENT STAT BOOSTS, but if you work on this through the story you wont feel the grind of so much. This becomes very important for not only fighting Beerus but the 100 man battles as well in the DLC. Take it from someone who started training with whis from level 5 to Max and then fought beerus just to struggle worse than my first run through when I made a point to eat before every big battle and just to heal never using healing items unless in battle.

If you're a DBZ fan you'll definetly enjoy this and even if you're not, the fighting can be very fun at times.
However I found that the first two hours of the game feel incredibly slow as you try to get used to the controls which are pretty abysmal when you're not used to them. Flying around in a open world is also kinda fun until the random encounters start becoming hella annoying and you wish you could be doing literally anything else. The story is nothing new, it basically starts with the Saiyan saga and ends at the Buu saga.
Overall I'd say give this game a try but get it while it's on sale.

I picked this up on a whim after remembering playing some of the old Dragonball z games on PS2

And... hot dang, so far I'm really impressed! I've just reached the cell saga and I have to say I am having a ton of fun! Boss fights are interesting, Raditz being the hardest so far.

Was it an easy fight in the anime? Great! You'll likely stomp! Was it a hard fight in the anime? Oh- shit- prepare for a fight!

The only thing that kinda hits me is that you have to limit yourself a little to enjoy it. You can win almost any fight pretty easily as long as you aren't severely under levelled. Why? There's food that gives you perminant stat boosts and there's no limit to the amount of recovery items you can bring.

However, without focusing on cooking the meals and just cooking it when I'm in the area/ randomly picked up some ingrediants aaaand setting limits on using recovery items for yourself- feels really balanced. I think it'd only be a problem if you grinded that stuff.
