If you're a fan of Dragon Ball, you'll likely enjoy this game. The combat is smooth and fun, the game looks amazing; and there's some fun stuff to do outside of the main story like races, upgrading machines, destroying towers/frieza ships, hunting etc. There are also plenty of sidequests to do, however some of them tend to be pretty stale consisting of fetch quests.

So far my review has been fairly positive, so you're probably wondering why i'm not recommending this game. And the main reason for that is due to the bugs/glitches that the game still has. There are times in the game where I have been softlocked and had to reset the game, losing some progress as a result. And the most damning being that one day I log on, and I have lost literally all of my save data. The game acts like I have opened it for the first time, i've tried everything, digging into the game files etc; no luck. Which is unfortunate, because I was grinding this game to try and get 100% (I had 2 achievements to go). I don't feel like playing the entire game again just to do this, and so i'm not recommending based on my experience.

Maybe this won't happen to you, but it has happened to multiple people; me now being one of them.

Completing 100% of the game feels really nice.

First of all, despite the minute flaws of the game, I'm very satisfied with it.

The game tells the entirety of Goku's saga from the beginning of Dragon Ball Z, and covers a few alternate stories like Trunks' timeline, and the movies that would become the start of Dragon Ball Super. Other than that, there are a bunch of fun stories treated as side quests, and a few minigames to keep you entertained, while hardly being a necessity to completion of the game.

Story mode alone is refreshingly long; there are a great amount of battles and each one is punctuated by either a cinematic video, or a fully-voiced summary of what happened in the original series. It does skip some parts, and modifies another ones to fit better the format of a videogame, but all that is understandable.

The meat of the game, and gameplay would be a sort of 3D fighting game while exclusively flying. There is only a melee attack button that makes combos by itself, with four different finishers - each exclusive to each character - and a customizable palette of 'super-attacks' which would be the iconic moves that each character has been using in the series canonically. Characters Level up and learn or improve on their abilities. Keeping up with the Level the game wants you to is hardly a challenge if one goes around hunting for side-quests or defeat a few enemies here and there for some extra experience and items.

There are several currencies in the game, and the flight controls are fair. It is a little regrettable that while each level is absolutely littered with 'Z orbs', a currency needed to learn or improve moves, they become irrelevant very early on. Why would you spend half an hour hunting for a few hundred while a single battle offers you several thousand, and you abilities require tens of thousands to level up? It's a shame that it's such an obvious fix, as simply adjusting prices, scaling, or making each orb collectable in-world worth multiple of itself.

There are a few mechanics that I did not care for. The first DLC, A New Power Awakens, is nothing but a grind-fest. Granted, that's precisely what the movie it's based on was, making the characters stronger as they train, but they went a little overboard. I believe the game would work better with a LOWER level-cap. Why grind all the way up to 300 when and 200 would have achieved basically the same? I realize it was a sort of challenge and the game can honestly be beat without even rivaling the level of the final boss, but it's just food for thought.

The 'horde battles' at the second DLC, the second part of 'A New Power Awakens', are honestly dull and uninteresting. The characters are just not meant to face that many enemies at once, which most of them die from one hit and are hardly a challenge. Spamming the same area-of-effect attacks is hardly a fun activity. They're mostly optional, but as a new mechanic you pay for, it is honestly a pretty bad one.

That's all the gripes I had. The voicing of the characters is great, the inclusion of the original Japanese voices is a treat, as it is to re-live Goku and friends' adventures through a pretty damn good retelling of it, with graphics that both look pretty, but pay tribute to the original animated shows (take notes, people who do DBS). I doubt any fan of the series would be disappointed to add this one to the collection.

Best Game from the franchise.

I did appreciate the effort the developers put into this game.
You can:
- Fly, YEPPA!
- Fly at a higher speed, YEPPA!!
- Fly underwater, YEPPA!!!
- You can hunt, mine (both actions are cheap but I guess we could say that) and fish.
- Use a Skill tree.
- Craft a few robots.
- Destroy Red Ribbon Towers and Frieza's ships lying around the map.
- Do subquests.
- Defeat special enemies on the world map.
- Gather the Dragon Balls and summon Shenron.

The Main Story Line is really well made, it's probably one of the closest to the original DBZ manga I've ever played so far.

Is there any flaw?

Sure, a few:
- Some subquests are utterly stupid, you want to skip them. They're not just hard, they're practically a bit unfair, sometimes just boring, and this sucks in a game so simple such as this one.

- I didn't like the fact they added lev.42 special monsters when you are still level 10, why adding enemies so early that can OHKO you? FYI, you get to level 40 when you're around the Cyborg Saga.

- A few scenes have been basically censored and some kills have been softened: some of your enemies will die by a Ki Blast in a cutscene, and not by beheading (Guldo) , for example. 
Chances are, whoever buys this game, has watched the original show or has bought the manga, so what's the point of this "censorship"? 

- You can't play as Mr. Popo, otherwise the game would be over in an instant.

- Certain iconic moments/fights have been cut.

Other than these small (but maybe a bit annoying) details, it's totally recommended, well done.

The Good: The game does a great retelling of the DBZ storyline, what manages to not get captured in gameplay is explained in a nifty cinematic. The open world is stunning and instantly allows you feel transported into the DBZ series. 

The Bad: *Disclaimer* my negative points are mostly from a completionist standpoint and shouldn't deter anyone from checking this game out. Firstly, the mini-games available are awesome and fun, but quickly feel pointless. Cooking being added to generate stat buffs is a great touch, but I feel like more could have be done with Bulma, possibly to add an item development system. I'm a big fan of the ole Budokai Tenkaichi series, and being able to collect equipment/wish for items from Shenron gave those titles a great feel; which I think would have worked here as well. Second, the encounter/open world combat with random villains is nice at first, but after a half hour of random fights while you try to pick apples; you'll quickly find yourself avoiding enemies as much as you can.

Overall: A great addition to the DBZ franchise and well worth a runthrough if you're a fan of the series.

[h1] Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot (2020), 86/100 [/h1]

[i] - Nostalgia is over 9000! [/i]


[b] PLUS [/b]

- Faithfully recreation of the Dragon Ball Z saga.
- All the characters, world and lore that you know and love from the anime.
- Fantastic and recognizable soundtrack.
- Colorful and flashy combat.
- Varied minigames and collectibles.
- No missable content, you can replay everything once you finish the main story.


[b] MINUS [/b]

- It's not a fighting game, expect a RPG with lots of fights.
- Main story and quest levels are fixed, overleveling them removes all the (little) challange.
- Dull sidequests, fight this or fetch that. Worth it just for the NPC and lore nostalgia.
- Open world illusion, few and small maps, lacks variety.
- Pricey, wait for a sale.


[b] RECOMMENDATIONS [/b]

- Aoe attacks are essential. Vegeta's Big Bang Attack is monstrous.
- Auto transformation skills are useful.
- Play the DLCs after finishing the main story, or you will easily overlevel it.
- There is only one autosave slot, keep your own saves regularly.

[i] Played Build ID 7518452, May 2022, Windows 10, Lenovo Legion. [/i]
[i] - Stable: One crash to desktop and a pair of interface glitches, the autosave fixed that. [/i]

Looks great, good graphics and story are all there, and I have played numerous DBZ games in the past, but the combat and controls are seriously some of the most annoying of any DBZ game I have played (spam dodge/block, spam Ki attacks). Gorgeous game and story for DBZ fans, just annoying controls, personal opinion.

Side Note - Game also crashed regularly with "UE4-AT fatal error"  Currently running Windows 10 64bit with GTX 1080Ti, i7 10700k cpu and 32GB DDR4ram. I tried all the recommended fixes and nothing worked. So I had to play for 20 mins at a time waiting for the next crash, even then still beat the game, but was tedious. Look online to see I am not the only one to come across this and others with AMD hardware still sometimes have same issue, so beware.
